If fluid recurs after myringotomy and aspiration, a grommet is inserted for continued middle ear aeration; remains in place for weeks or months.

Tympanotomy or Cortical Mastoidectomy

Required for removing loculated thick fluid or other pathologies like cholesterol granuloma.

Surgical Treatment of Causative Factor

Procedures like adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy, and/or maxillary antra washout may be needed, typically performed during myringotomy.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is atropine not recommended for use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option A)

Explanation

  • Atropine is not recommended for use in acute congestive glaucoma.
  • This is because atropine is an anticholinergic that causes pupil dilation, which can exacerbate the already elevated intraocular pressure in acute congestive (or angle-closure) glaucoma by further obstructing the drainage of aqueous humor from the eye. This can worsen the condition.
  • Over 60 drugs have been linked to acute angle-closure (AAC) glaucoma, particularly in individuals with ocular predispositions. These include topical anticholinergic pupil dilators (e.g., atropine, cyclopentolate) and systemic medications such as topiramate, sulfonamides, duloxetine, and phenothiazines. Patients on these medications, especially those with AAC risk factors, should have regular ophthalmic examinations.

 

Acute anterior uveitis (Option B): Atropine can be beneficial in this condition as it helps to relieve ciliary muscle spasms, reduces pain, prevents the formation of posterior synechiae, and keeps the pupil mobile.

 

Malignant glaucoma (Option C): Atropine is the first line of treatment for management of malignant glaucoma. It dilates the ciliary ring and relaxes the ciliary muscles which causes stretching of zonules that will pull back the lens, thus opening the block.

 

Corneal ulcer (Option D): Atropine can be used in this case to help relieve pain associated with ciliary muscle spasms, reduces pain, prevents the formation of posterior synechiae, and improve vascularity.

questions.text:
A chronic cigarette smoker has now joined a construction company. His pulmonary function test results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

Initial lung volumes were:


	FEV1-0.9L
	FVC-1.9L
	FEV1/FVC-0.4


After bronchodilation:


	FEV1-1.9L
	FVC-3.9L


FEV1/FVC-0.4

choices.text: Restrictive lung disease with bronchodilator reversibility
Restrictive lung disease without bronchodilator reversibility

questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option D)

Explanation

In people with asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), bronchodilator reversibility test is commonly used. The purpose of the test is to determine whether the subject's airflow has improved as a result of taking the bronchodilator medication. The given pulmonary function test results indicate a diagnosis of obstructive lung disease with bronchodilator reversibility as the FEV1/FVC is less than 0.7, so it is an obstructive disease, and after bronchodilation there is an increase of >12% in FEV1; hence it is reversible. Improved lung volumes after bronchodilation indicate a response to the bronchodilator, which is a feature of COPD.

 

Vascular disease does not typically present with bronchodilator reversibility. (Option A)

 

Restrictive lung diseases are characterized by reduced lung volumes (Option B), but the given lung volumes do not suggest restriction. Additionally, improved lung volumes after bronchodilation indicate a response to the bronchodilator, which is not typically seen in restrictive lung diseases.


The lung volumes provided do not indicate restriction (Option C). Additionally, the lack of improvement in lung volumes after bronchodilation contradicts this option.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a first-line drug for the management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Azathioprine is not considered a first-line drug for the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). It is primarily used as an immunosuppressant in organ transplantation and certain autoimmune conditions but is not typically recommended as an initial treatment for RA due to it’s inconsistent efficacy and high toxicity.

 

Sulfasalazine (Option A) is one of the disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) commonly used in the treatment of RA. It helps reduce inflammation and joint damage and is considered a first-line treatment option for RA.

 

Hydroxychloroquine (Option B) is another DMARD used in the management of RA. It has anti-inflammatory properties and can help control symptoms and slow disease progression. It is often prescribed as a first-line treatment option, especially in mild to moderate RA.


Methotrexate (Option C) is widely recognized as the first-line DMARD for the treatment of RA. It is highly effective in reducing symptoms, preventing joint damage, and improving long-term outcomes. Methotrexate is considered the anchor drug and is often prescribed as the initial treatment for most patients with RA.

questions.text: Mark the correct statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease.

choices.text: Skip lesions are present in Crohn’s disease
Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn’s while transmural involvement seen in ulcerative colitis
Inflammatory bowel disease doesn’t have a genetic predisposition
Crohn’s is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment

questions.solution:
Skip lesions refer to the characteristic feature of Crohn's disease where there are areas of inflammation that are separated by normal or unaffected segments of the bowel. This pattern of involvement is not seen in ulcerative colitis. Skip lesions can occur throughout the entire gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus, in Crohn's disease.

 

In Crohn's disease, the inflammation can involve all layers of the bowel wall, which is known as transmural involvement. In ulcerative colitis, the inflammation is limited to the mucosal layer of the colon and rectum. (Option B)

 

Both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis have a strong genetic component, indicating a predisposition to developing these conditions (Option C). Family history of inflammatory bowel disease is a known risk factor.

 

Crohn's disease is a chronic condition that requires long-term management and treatment (Option D) to control inflammation and maintain remission.
 

Learning Objective:
Distinguishing features between Crohn’s Disease and Ulcerative colitis

Clinical features

Crohn’s Disease

Ulcerative colitis

Affects

Any part of GIT from mouth to anus.

Primarily, the colon is involved.

Rectal involvement

The rectum is often spared.

It almost always involves the rectum, hence associated with rectal bleeding.

Skin lesions, Bowel wall thickening, Strictures, and Perianal manifestations

Common

Rare

Inflammation

Transmural and segmental

Mucosal and continuous involvement

Granulomas

Noncaseating granulomas are characteristic of Crohn’s disease.

Granulomas are not typically present.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the hospital with symptoms of fever and chills. A fever profile test is conducted, which rules out malaria and dengue as the cause. However, the rK39 test comes back positive. What is the preferred treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with fever and chills, with malaria and dengue ruled out, but rK39 test positive, which strongly indicates visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar), which presents with fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and pancytopenia.

The rK39 antigen test detects antibodies against Leishmania donovani, the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis.

The treatment of choice for Kala-azar is Amphotericin B, particularly liposomal Amphotericin B, due to its high efficacy and safety profile.
 

Griseofulvin (Option B) is an antifungal medication that works by inhibiting microtubule function, thereby interfering with fungal mitosis. It is primarily used for treating superficial fungal infections like tinea capitis and onychomycosis.

Dapsone (Option C) is an antimicrobial drug that inhibits dihydropteroate synthase, disrupting folic acid metabolism. It is mainly used in leprosy (Hansen’s disease) as part of multi-drug therapy (MDT) and for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) prophylaxis in immunocompromised patients.

Hydroxychloroquine (Option D) is an immunomodulatory drug that interferes with antigen presentation by lysosomes. It is widely used in autoimmune diseases like SLE and rheumatoid arthritis, as well as in malaria treatment and prophylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the management of frostbite is incorrect?

choices.text: The area is dried and cleaned

questions.solution:
Antibiotics are commonly prescribed in the management of frostbite to prevent or treat secondary bacterial infections that can occur as a result of damaged tissue. Analgesics, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or opioids, may be used to manage pain.

 

In severe cases of frostbite where tissue damage is extensive and irreversible, amputation may be necessary to remove dead or gangrenous tissue (Option A) and prevent the spread of infection. Therefore, amputation can be a part of the management in severe cases.

 

Rewarming the affected area (Option B) is a critical step in the management of frostbite. It should be done using warm water (not hot) or by placing the affected area in a warm environment. Rewarming helps to restore blood flow and prevent further tissue damage.

 

After rewarming, the affected area should be gently dried and cleaned to prevent infection. (Option D) Cleaning helps remove any debris or contaminants from the damaged tissue.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with limping gait and left hip pain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Avascular necrosis

 

Explanation:

This patient likely has avascular necrosis (AVN), a condition where bone cells die due to a lack of blood supply.

  • It often affects weight-bearing joints like the hip, knee, talus, and humeral head, with the hip being most common.
  • The X-ray shows flattening of the top and side of the femoral head, a typical sign. However, MRI is the best for diagnosing and staging AVN.
  • Initial investigation for avascular necrosis (AVN) is typically an X-ray, but it may not show signs until at least 3 months after onset.
  • X-ray findings include increased bone density and a crescent sign, indicating a tangential fracture line below the joint surface.
  • Radio scintigraphy with mTc-sulphur colloid or CT scan can be used.
  • MRI is the preferred choice due to its ability to detect early marrow changes and bone ischemia.
  • Intramedullary pressure measurement and biopsy are other options for diagnosis.
  • Biopsy, though invasive, offers early detection and intervention possibilities with medical treatment.

 

Tuberculosis of the hip (Option A): Irregular and hazy joint margins, destruction of bone on either side of the joint, erosions, and reduced joint space are classical plain X-ray findings.

 

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option B): It primarily affects small joints of the hands. Hallmark radiographic findings include marginal erosions, soft tissue swelling, osteoporosis, and joint space narrowing.


Ankylosing spondylitis (Option C): Spine and sacroiliac joints are involved. Plain X-ray of the spine shows erosions at the corners of vertebral bodies with reactive sclerosis, vertebral body squaring, and a characteristic bamboo spine appearance.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man came with complaints of unilateral knee pain. X-ray examination showed reduced joint space. Histopathological examination of the affected joint is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Osteoarthritis

 

Explanation:

In histopathology, there is loss of Articular cartilage. Reduced joint space on X-ray and unilateral knee pain is highly suggestive of osteoarthritis.

  • The clinical manifestations and X-ray showing joint space narrowing, irregular joint surface, subchondral sclerosis, and osteophyte formation are consistent with a diagnosis of Osteoarthritis.
  • DMARDs target immune and inflammatory pathways to slow disease progression in conditions like Rheumatoid arthritis and are not used in osteoarthritis.

 

X-ray features seen in Osteoarthritis:

Radiological features

Pathology

Joint space narrowing

Focal areas of loss of articular cartilage

Osteophytes

Bone growth at the joint margins

Sclerosis of subchondral bone

Sclerosis of underlying bone

Bone cysts

Cyst formation in underlying bone

Bone attrition

Loss of bone

Apparent effusions

Varying degrees of synovial inflammation

Not visible on radiographs

Fibrosis and thickening of the joint capsule

Treatment:

Supportive therapy:

  • Weight reduction
  • Stress management
  • Local heat provides relief of pain and stiffness
  • Quadriceps strengthening exercises - improve stability of the knee joint
  • No unnecessary knee movements.

Medical treatment:

  • Paracetamol
  • Topical NSAIDs
  • Intra-articular injections:
    • Local anesthetic
    • Corticosteroid
    • Hyaluronic acid

 

Surgical treatment:

  • Osteotomy
  • Joint replacement (Partial or total) - in advanced disease stages
  • Arthroscopic procedures - minimally invasive procedures.

questions.text:
A woman presents at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following signs can be elicited at this gestation?


	Goodell's sign
	Osiander's sign
	Internal ballottement
	Lightening
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2

 

Explanation:
At 8 weeks of gestation, Goodell's sign and Osiander's sign can be elicited.

 

Goodell's sign (Option 1): The softening of the cervix, noticeable as early as the 6th week of pregnancy, is a classic sign of pregnancy.

Osiander's sign (Option 2): Pulsations in the lateral fornix due to increased vascularity, often observed around 8 weeks of gestation.

 

Sign

Description

Time of Occurrence

Goodell's Sign (1)

Softening of the cervix

6th week

Ladin's Sign

Softening at the midpoint of the isthmus anteriorly

Around 6 weeks

Jacquemier's/Chadwick's Sign

Dark bluish-red coloration of the vaginal mucosa and cervix

6-8 weeks

Palmer's Sign

Regular & rhythmic uterine contractions

4-8 weeks

Von Braun-Fernwald's Sign

Irregular softening and enlargement of the uterine fundus

5-8 weeks

McDonald's Sign

Easy flexibility of the uterus on the cervix

7-8 weeks

Hegar's Sign

Firm cervix contrasts with the softer fundus, with a compressible, softened isthmus

6-10 weeks

Piskacek's Sign

One half of the uterus is firmer than the other half (lateral implantation)

6-12 weeks

Osiander's Sign (2)

Presence of a softening, compressible, and enlarging uterus, often felt with palpation

8th week

Placental Sign

Cyclic bleeding occurring up to 12 weeks of pregnancy

Up to 12 weeks

 

Internal Ballottement (3):

Palpation technique to detect fetal movement by bouncing the fetus away and then back.

Elicited between 16-28 weeks of gestation.

  • Before 16 weeks: Fetus too small.
  • After 28 weeks: Fetus too large.

Limitations:

  • Scanty liquor amnii (low amniotic fluid).
  • Transverse lie of fetus.

 

Lightening (4):

Relief of pressure symptoms due to the engagement of the presenting part into the pelvic cavity.

Felt around 38 weeks of gestation, primarily in primigravida (first-time pregnancies).

questions.text: The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all of the following except:

choices.text: Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
Reduction in the risk of ectopic pregnancy
Protection against sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV
Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Protection against sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV

 

Explanation:

Oral contraceptives (OCPs) provide numerous non-contraceptive benefits. However, they do not prevent sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV. Barrier methods, such as condoms, are necessary for protection against STDs.

 

Mechanism of Action of OCPs

 

Combined Oral Contraceptives (COCPs): Contain ethinylestradiol and progestins.

  • Suppress ovulation: Inhibit FSH and LH release from the pituitary.
  • Cervical mucus thickening: Progesterone prevents sperm penetration.

 

Progestin-Only Pills (Mini-pills): Act primarily by altering cervical mucus and endometrial environment.

 

Hormonal Content

Primary Mechanism

Secondary Effects

Estrogen

Suppresses FSH

Stabilizes endometrium, reduces bleeding

Progestin

Suppresses LH

Thickens cervical mucus, thins endometrium


 

Non-Contraceptive Benefits of OCPs

 

Reduction in ovarian cancer risk (Option A)

Suppresses ovulation, reducing exposure to gonadotropins that may induce ovarian epithelial damage.

Reduction in endometrial cancer risk (Option B)

Progestin opposes estrogen's proliferative effects on the endometrium.

Reduction in ectopic pregnancy (Option D)

Suppresses ovulation and reduces pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

Management of PCOD

Regularizes menstrual cycles and reduces androgen levels.

Improvement in acne

Reduces androgen levels, decreasing sebaceous gland activity.

Menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea

Reduces endometrial proliferation and menstrual blood loss.

questions.text: A 16-year-old presents with absent menses. Examination shows widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and Tanner grade 1 breast development. USG shows streak ovaries. Investigation shows raised FSH, raised LH, and reduced estradiol. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Turner syndrome

 

Explanation: The patient's clinical features strongly suggest Turner syndrome.

 

Turner syndrome

 

Etiology: The most common sex chromosome abnormality in females with the classical karyotype 45, XO.

 

Pathophysiology: Loss of one X chromosome leads to streak ovaries with inadequate estrogen production, resulting in hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. The reduced estrogen levels fail to provide negative feedback, causing elevated FSH and LH.

Clinical Features:

  • Physical: Short stature, webbed neck, shield chest, widely spaced nipples, low posterior hairline.
  • Reproductive: Primary amenorrhea, infertility, absent secondary sexual characteristics (Tanner stage 1 breasts).
  • Cardiac: Coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve.
  • Renal: Horseshoe kidney, congenital anomalies.

 

Feature

Turner Syndrome

Kallmann Syndrome

 

(Option B)

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS)

(Option C)

Mayer-Rokitansky- Küster-Hauser (MRKH) Syndrome

(Option D)

Cause

Complete or partial absence of one X chromosome (45,X or mosaicism)

GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) deficiency

Defect in the androgen receptor gene (X-linked)

Mullerian agenesis (absence of the Mullerian ducts)

Reproductive Organs

Streak ovaries (non-functioning)

Normal uterus and vagina

Normal ovaries and uterus

Testes present but undescended (cryptorchidism)

Absent uterus and vagina

Absent uterus

Normal ovaries

Breast Development

Usually absent or delayed

Usually absent or delayed

Normal or near-normal

Normal

Axillary/Pubic Hair

Usually normal

Usually absent or delayed

Minimal to absent

Normal

Karyotype

45,X or 45,X/46,XX

46,XX

46,XY

46,XX

Other Characteristics
  • Short stature
  • Webbed neck
  • Lymphedema
  • Heart defects
  • Learning disabilities
  • Delayed puberty
  • Infertility
  • Female external genitalia despite male chromosomes
  • Normal external genitalia
  • Primary amenorrhea

questions.text:
Consider the following actions under AMTSL (Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor). Arrange them in the correct order:


	Uterine massage
	Give uterotonic (oxytocin 10 IU)
	Exclude the presence of another fetus
	Controlled cord traction
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 3,2,4,1

 

Explanation:

The correct sequence in Active Management of the Third Stage of Labor (AMTSL) is 3, 2, 4, 1, which is the recommended order to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

 

Steps Before Starting AMTSL:

  • Confirm delivery of the baby.
  • Exclude the presence of another fetus in the uterus.(Statement 3)
  • Assess fetal condition, position, and lie.
  • Prepare the uterotonic drug.
  • Check maternal vitals and overall condition.
  • Ready instruments for cord clamping.
  • Inform the mother about the procedure.
  • Check for signs of placental detachment.


 

1. Injecting Uterotonics

Inject uterotonic (e.g., Oxytocin 10 IU) within 1 minute of delivery of the baby or immediately after the delivery of the anterior shoulder. (Statement 2)
  • Most important step in AMTSL.
  • Oxytocin (10 IU IM/IV infusion) is the preferred uterotonic.
  • Not recommended by WHO: carboprost.
  • Administer within 1-3 minutes of delivery.

2. Delayed Cord Clamping

Delay cord clamping for at least 1 minute after birth.
  • About 80 ml of additional blood goes to the fetus.
  • Helps prevent fetal anemia by allowing time for placental blood flow to transfer to the baby.

3. Delivery of Placenta by Controlled Cord Traction

Perform controlled cord traction using the modified Brandt-Andrews technique. (Statement 4)
  • Controlled cord traction should be done after administering uterotonics.
  • Technique: apply gentle downward traction to the cord while counter-traction on the uterine fundus facilitates placental delivery.

4. Intermittent Assessment of Uterine Tone

Assess uterine tone intermittently to ensure uterine contraction is maintained.
  • Done every 15 minutes for 2 hours post-delivery.
  • Only in settings where skilled birth attendants are available.
  • Uterus is pushed upwards and backward while cord traction is downward and forward.

5. Uterine Massage (Optional)

Perform uterine massage only if uterine atony is suspected or after placental delivery. (Statement 1)
  • Not recommended as a routine intervention to prevent PPH in women who have already received prophylactic uterotonics (Oxytocin).
  • Now an optional component of AMTSL in cases of uterine atony or PPH management.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for vulval cancer except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vulval hamartoma

 

Explanation:
Vulval hamartoma is a benign growth composed of disorganized but normal tissue elements found in the vulva. It does not predispose to malignancy or increase the risk of vulval cancer.

 

Vulval cancer is a malignant tumor affecting the external female genitalia, most commonly the labia majora. Approximately 90% of vulval cancers are squamous cell carcinomas.

 

Risk factors of vulval cancer

 

Chronic Vulval Irritation

Persistent irritation or inflammation (e.g., from infections or allergies) can cause cellular changes, increasing cancer risk.

Immunosuppressive Conditions

HIV, pregnancy, and other immunosuppressive conditions lower immune surveillance, increasing cancer risk.

Smoking (Option C ruled out)

A carcinogen that impairs immune function, significantly increasing the risk of vulval and other cancers.

Condyloma (Anogenital Warts) (Option D ruled out)

HPV infection (serotypes 16, 18) causes condyloma and is strongly linked to vulval cancer.

Sexually Transmitted Diseases (STDs)

HPV (serotypes 16, 18) is the main STD linked to vulval cancer, leading to persistent infections and cellular changes.

Vulval Dystrophies (Option A ruled out)

Chronic conditions like lichen sclerosus and lichen planus cause tissue changes that increase malignancy risk.

questions.text: What is vagitus uterinus?

choices.text: Cry of baby in the womb
Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cry of baby in the womb

 

Explanation:

  • Vagitus uterinus is a Latin term that translates to "uterine cry" or "womb cry." It refers to the cry or sound made by a fetus while still inside the mother's womb, typically in the later stages of pregnancy.
  • This is a rare phenomenon where the fetus is capable of producing vocalizations.
  • In certain circumstances, these sounds can be detected during ultrasound examinations or heard by the mother, although this is not commonly observed.
  • Vagitus uterinus is a fetal vocalization and has no association with any infections or pathological conditions. (Options B, C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the perimortem cesarean section?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Upper segment cesarean section

 

Explanation:

Perimortem cesarean section (PMCS) is a life-saving emergency procedure performed on a woman in cardiopulmonary arrest or who is expected to die imminently.

 

  • PMCS involves a classical upper-segment cesarean section where a vertical uterine incision is made.
  • This is done to allow quick and efficient delivery, particularly in critical conditions.

 

Indications for Upper Segment Cesarean Section (Classical Cesarean Incision)

 

Risk of Lower Uterine Segment Complications
  • Densely adherent bladder from previous surgery.
  • Leiomyoma in the lower uterine segment.
  • Cervical cancer involvement.
  • Previous radical trachelectomy for cervical cancer.

Placenta-Related Issues
  • Placenta previa with anterior implantation.
  • Placenta accreta syndrome.

Maternal Obesity
  • Massive obesity that prevents safe access to the lower uterine segment.

Fetal Indications
  • Transverse fetal lie with ruptured membrane and impacted shoulder.
  • Transverse lie with the back-down position.
  • Very small or breech fetus.
  • Small fetal head entrapped by contracting uterine fundus following membrane rupture.
  • Multiple fetuses that may be malpositioned or preterm.
  • Large fetal malformation or conjoined twins requiring extra space.

Perimortem Mother
  • In cases of maternal cardiac arrest where immediate delivery is necessary to save the fetus, a classical cesarean section is often performed due to the urgency and limited time.

 

Lower Segment Cesarean Section (LSCS) (Option A) is not performed during PMCS due to the urgency and anatomical constraints in a perimortem scenario.

 

Pfannenstiel incision (Option B), a horizontal incision in the lower abdomen, commonly used in routine cesareans, is time-consuming and unsuitable for perimortem cesarean section.

 

Done in the operating theater (OT) (Option D): PMCS can be performed anywhere, including outside an OT, as time is of critical importance. Guidelines do not mandate that it must be done in a formal surgical setting.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with 35 weeks + 5 days gestation complains of epigastric pain, headache, and blurring of vision. Her blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. She is in labor pain. Examination of the cervix shows a 3 cm dilatation with a bag of liquor. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 weeks
Give steroid cover and wait until steroid cover is complete
Treat hypertension, administer MgSO4, and consider termination of pregnancy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Treat hypertension, administer MgSO4, and consider termination of pregnancy

 

Explanation:

This pregnant woman shows features of severe pre-eclampsia, including:

  • Blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg (≥160/110 is a criterion for severe pre-eclampsia).
  • Symptoms of end-organ involvement: Epigastric pain, headache, and blurring of vision.
  • She is also in active labor with cervical dilatation.

 

Management Plan:

Antihypertensives: Administer labetalol, nifedipine, or hydralazine to bring down BP.

Seizure Prophylaxis: Use magnesium sulfate (MgSO₄) to prevent eclampsia.

Delivery/Termination of Pregnancy: Delivery is the definitive treatment for pre-eclampsia, and since the patient is already in labor, termination of pregnancy should proceed to protect both maternal and fetal health.

 

Algorithm for Treating Preeclampsia

Initial Evaluation

  • Perform comprehensive maternal and fetal evaluation.
  • CBC with platelet estimate, serum creatinine, LDH, AST, ALT, and proteinuria testing.
  • Fetal evaluation: USG for estimated fetal weight, amniotic fluid volume, and fetal antepartum testing.

Decision for Delivery vs Expectant Management

  • 34+ Weeks Gestation: Deliver promptly upon maternal stabilization or with labor/prelabor rupture of membranes; do not delay for steroid administration.
  • Before 34 Weeks Gestation with Severe Preeclampsia: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care setting if maternal and fetal conditions are stable.
  • 37+ Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Opt for delivery rather than expectant management upon diagnosis.
  • Before 37 Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Managed as an outpatient; requires frequent fetal and maternal evaluation. Deliver only if specific conditions necessitate immediate intervention.

Management During Expectant Management

  • Closely monitor maternal and fetal conditions.
  • Serial laboratory testing: CBC, liver enzymes, serum creatinine.
  • Use antihypertensive therapy for acute-onset severe hypertension (systolic ≥160 mm Hg or diastolic ≥110 mm Hg).
  • Administer antenatal corticosteroids and monitor for 48 hours if delivery is indicated before 34 weeks gestation.

Regularly check for Conditions Necessitating Delivery Regardless of Gestational Age

Maternal Conditions

Fetal Conditions
  1. HELLP syndrome
  2. Pulmonary edema
  3. Eclampsia
  4. Suspected acute placental abruption, or vaginal bleeding without placenta previa
  5. Uncontrolled severe-range blood pressure
  6. Worsening renal function
  7. Persistent headaches, epigastric/right upper quadrant pain
  8. Visual disturbances
  9. Motor deficits
  10. Altered sensorium
  11. Stroke
  12. Myocardial infarction
  1. Abnormal fetal testing
  2. Fetal death
  3. Fetus with low survival likelihood (lethal anomaly, Extreme prematurity)
  4. Persistent reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery

Postpartum Management

  • Monitor blood pressure and symptoms post-delivery.
  • Consider NSAIDs for pain management instead of opioids.

 

Conservative management (Option A): Not appropriate due to the severe features of pre-eclampsia, which pose a risk to both the mother and fetus.

 

Administer tocolytics and deliver at 37 weeks (Option B): Tocolytics are contraindicated in severe pre-eclampsia, as delaying delivery increases maternal and fetal risks.


Give steroid cover and wait until steroid cover is complete (Option C): While steroids are beneficial for fetal lung maturity, waiting for completion is unsafe in severe pre-eclampsia due to immediate maternal risks.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in placenta previa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Warning bleeds

 

Explanation:

Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment, either over or close to the internal cervical os.

 

Clinical Features:

  • Warning bleeds: The hallmark of placenta previa is recurrent, painless vaginal bleeding that occurs after the second trimester, often referred to as "warning hemorrhage". The bleeding is usually mild and not immediately fatal. This is called a sentinel bleed.
  • Uterus characteristics: Typically relaxed, soft, and non-tender, unlike the tense, tender uterus seen in placental abruption.
  • Fetal heart sound: Usually present unless there is significant separation of the placenta.

 

Management Considerations: Per-vaginal examination should be avoided in suspected cases of placenta previa due to the risk of provoking further bleeding. Examination can only be safely performed in the operating theatre, where a cesarean section can be immediately performed if needed.

 

Risk Factors for Placenta Previa:

  • Multigravida (more than one pregnancy)
  • Advanced maternal age (>35 years)
  • Previous cesarean section or myomectomy
  • Abnormal placental size and lobes
  • Prior curettage

 

Types of placenta previa:

 

placenta previa" data-author="" data-hash="11010" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/lFzE0hOTAaZX5MDnmcVy1745333115.jpg" />

 

Types

 

Definitions

I

Low lying

The placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment but does not reach the internal os.

II

Marginal

The edge of the placenta is at the margin of the internal os.

III

Incomplete/partial central

The placenta partially covers the internal os of the cervix.

IV

Central/complete

The placenta completely covers the internal os of the cervix.
  • Types I and II can be anterior or posterior.
  • Types I and II are minor degrees, and types III and IV are major degrees of placenta previa.

 

Revised Classification:

 

Types

Definitions

True Placenta previa

The placenta covers the internal os

Low lying placenta

The placenta lies within 2cm of internal is but does not cover it

Dark painful bleeding (Option B), uterine tenderness (Option C), and increased/large uterine size (Option D) are seen in placental abruption, not placenta previa.

questions.text: A surgically resected specimen of an ovarian mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mature cystic teratoma

 

Explanation:

The specimen with a tuft of hair in a cystic space is indicative of a mature cystic teratoma, also known as a dermoid cyst.

 

Mature Cystic Teratoma (Dermoid Cyst):

  • Benign germ cell tumors.
  • Typically unilocular or multilocular and may contain a variety of tissues, including sebaceous material (oil), hair, and teeth.
  • The cysts are lined by squamous epithelium and often contain structures like bone, cartilage, thyroid tissue, and neural tissue.
  • Most patients are asymptomatic, but some may present with abdominal mass, acute pain (due to ovarian torsion), or rupture of the cyst leading to peritonitis.

 

Management: Treatment typically involves excision of the cyst to prevent complications such as torsion or rupture.

 

 

Types of Germ Cell Tumors (GCT)

Description

Teratoma

Mature cystic teratoma of the ovary

Most common germ cell tumor. They have components of all 3 germ layers

2 Types:

• Mature Teratoma (MC GCT Overall)- Dermoid/Cystic, Benign 

• Immature Teratoma- Malignant, monoclonal type

Dysgerminoma

• MC malignant germ cell tumor

• HPE- Seminoma-type cells seen 

• Tumour Marker- hCG, PLAP, LDH

Yolk Sac Tumor

 

• The most malignant and worst prognosis

• HPE- Schiller Duval bodies: Central vessels with tumor cells around a cystic space

• Tumour Marker- AFP, Alpha-1 antitrypsin

Embryonal Cancer

• Highly aggressive malignant tumour

• Tumour Marker- AFP, hCG, Estrogen

Choriocarcinoma

Two Types:

  1. Gestational Choriocarcinoma
  2. Non Gestational Choriocarcinoma

 

Tumour Marker- hCG

Mixed Type

• Presence of more than one germ cell element (Dysgerminoma + yolk sac tumor)

• Tumour Markers- hCG, AFP

Immature teratomas (Option A) are malignant tumors and often have a solid, trabeculated appearance. They may contain hair, sebaceous material, cartilage, and bone but lack the well-organized cystic structure seen in mature teratomas. Immature teratomas also tend to have areas of necrosis or hemorrhage.

 

Mucinous cystadenomas (Option C) are benign tumors that present as multicystic lesions with delicate septa and glistening mucin within the cyst. They do not contain hair or teeth, distinguishing them from teratomas.

 

Serous cystadenomas (Option D) are benign ovarian tumors that are typically multicystic with papillary epithelium within fibrous walls. Unlike teratomas, they do not contain hair, sebaceous material, or other specialized tissues.

questions.text: What can be said about this graph?

choices.text: The baseline shows that the fetus has tachycardia.
This is a uterine contraction graph.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) This is a non-stress test.

 

Explanation:

 

The given graph, showing only the tracing for the fetal heart rate (FHR), indicates a non-stress test (NST).

 

Non-Stress Test (NST):

  • It is a non-invasive test used to assess fetal well-being by monitoring the fetal heart rate and its response to fetal movements.
  • It is typically performed in the third trimester of pregnancy.
  • The mother is placed in a semi-reclining position, and two belts are placed around her abdomen to measure the fetal heart rate and detect fetal movements.

 

Indications for NST:

  • Post-term pregnancy.
  • Decreased fetal movements.
  • High-risk pregnancies (e.g., hypertension, diabetes).
  • History of previous pregnancy complications.
  • Suspected intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

 

Primary parameters evaluated during an NST:

 

1. Baseline Fetal Heart Rate (FHR)

2. Beat-to-beat Variability:
  • Normal: 110-160 bpm
  • Bradycardia: less than 110 bpm.
  • Tachycardia: more than 160 bpm.
  • Fluctuations in the heart rate from one beat to the next.
  • Amplitude range of 6-25 bpm (considered normal).

3. Accelerations
  • Temporary increases in FHR above the baseline.
  • Reactive NST:
    • At least two accelerations in a 20-minute period.
    • Each acceleration should be 15 bpm above the baseline and last for at least 15 seconds (for fetuses older than 32 weeks).
  • Non-Reactive NST: Fewer than two accelerations in a 20-minute period.

4. Decelerations

Temporary drops in FHR below the baseline.

  • Early Decelerations: Usually benign, occurring with uterine contractions.
  • Variable Decelerations: Can indicate umbilical cord compression.
  • Late Decelerations: Concerning as they may indicate uteroplacental insufficiency.

5. Fetal Movements
  • The presence and frequency of fetal movements are monitored, as decreased movements can indicate distress.

Interpretation:
  • Reactive NST: Indicative of normal fetal oxygenation and autonomic function.
  • Non-Reactive NST may require further testing, such as a Biophysical Profile (BPP) or Contraction Stress Test (CST).

The baseline shows that the fetus has tachycardia (Option B): Tachycardia is defined as a baseline fetal heart rate above 160 beats per minute. The tracing in this graph shows a baseline fetal heart rate below 160 bpm, so tachycardia is not present.

 

The beat-to-beat variability is less/inadequate (Option C): Beat-to-beat variability refers to the fluctuations in the baseline fetal heart rate, excluding accelerations and decelerations. A variability of 6-25 beats/min is considered normal. This graph shows normal beat-to-beat variability, and thus, this option is incorrect.

 

This is a uterine contraction graph (Option D): This graph shows only fetal heart rate tracing and does not include any data on uterine contractions. A cardiotocogram (CTG), which includes both fetal heart rate and uterine contraction tracings, would be required for uterine contraction monitoring.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding recurrent ovarian cancer?

choices.text: Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months

 

Explanation:

If ovarian cancer recurs more than 6 months after the last platinum-based chemotherapy, it is classified as platinum-sensitive, meaning the cancer is still responsive to platinum-based treatments.

The classification of recurrent ovarian cancer into platinum-sensitive, platinum-resistant, and platinum-refractory is based on the time interval between the completion of primary chemotherapy and the recurrence of the cancer:

 

Category

Definition

Treatment

Platinum-sensitive

Ovarian cancer that recurs more than 6 months after completing platinum-based chemotherapy.

Treated with platinum-based therapies such as carboplatin, paclitaxel, or gemcitabine.

Platinum-resistant

Ovarian cancer that relapses within 6 months of primary platinum-based chemotherapy. (Options A, B and D ruled out)

Treated with palliative, non-platinum chemotherapy. Drugs such as Bevacizumab in combination with paclitaxel, doxorubicin, or topotecan.

Platinum-refractory

Ovarian cancer that progresses during primary chemotherapy, often with a worse prognosis.

Treatment options are limited; may include alternative chemotherapy agents or clinical trials.

questions.text: Nonimmune hydrops is seen in all, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Human immunodeficiency virus

 

Explanation:

Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is not a known cause of nonimmune hydrops.

 

Hydrops fetalis is diagnosed by the presence of two or more fetal effusions (e.g., pleural, pericardial, or ascites) or one effusion accompanied by anasarca.

 

Hydrops can be classified into two types:

 

  • Immune hydrops: Associated with red cell alloimmunization.
  • Nonimmune hydrops: Occurs due to other causes unrelated to immune mechanisms.

 

Immune Causes
  • Rh Isoimmunization
  • Other Blood Group Incompatibilities

Non-Immune Causes

Structural Defects

Cardiovascular Causes: Ebstein anomaly, Tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve, Hypoplastic left or right heart

Arteriovenous Malformation

Vein of Galen aneurysm

Chromosomal Abnormalities

Turner syndrome (45,X)

Triploidy

Trisomies 21, 18, and 13

Hematological Disorders

Hemoglobinopathies

Decreased erythrocyte production

Fetomaternal hemorrhage

Lymphatic Abnormalities

Cystic hygroma

Systemic, pulmonary lymphangiectasis

Infections

Parvovirus B19 (Option D)

Syphilis (Option C), Cytomegalovirus, Toxoplasmosis

Rubella, Varicella, Herpes simplex (Option B)

Listeriosis, Leptospirosis

Chagas disease, Lyme disease

Kidney and Urinary Tract Anomalies

Congenital nephrosis

Bladder outlet obstruction

Bartter syndrome

Placental, Twin, and Cord Abnormalities

Twin-twin transfusion syndrome

Twin anemia-polycythemia sequence

Placental chorioangioma

Idiopathic Causes

Unknown etiology

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the biophysical profile?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Daily fetal movement count

 

Explanation:
Daily fetal movement count is not a component of the biophysical profile (BPP).

 

Biophysical Profile (BPP)

 

Parameter

Normal Criteria

Breathing Movements

>1 episode lasting >30 seconds

Amniotic Fluid Volume

≥1 pocket measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (Option A ruled out)

Fetal Tone

≥1 episode of active limb or trunk extension with return of flexion (e.g., opening and closing of the hand) (Option B ruled out)

Gross Body Movements

>3 discrete body/limb movements

Non-stress Test (NST)

Reactive pattern (Two accelerations of 15 seconds duration, 15 bpm, in 20 minutes) (Option D ruled out)

 

BPP Scoring and Interpretation

 

BPP Score

Interpretation

Management

10

Normal, non-asphyxiated fetus

No action required; Routine monitoring

8

Normal, non-asphyxiated fetus

Repeat test weekly or biweekly for high-risk pregnancies (e.g., diabetic, post-term)

6

Possible fetal asphyxia

Repeat testing; If score ≤6, consider delivery

4

Probable fetal asphyxia

Repeat test same day or deliver if AFV is abnormal or >36 weeks

0-2

Almost certain fetal asphyxia

Immediate delivery

 

BPP Score and Outcome:

 

  • A BPP score of <4 suggests a fetal pH of <7.2, which indicates fetal distress and potential acidemia.
  • A BPP score of 0 represents 100% fetal acidemia, indicating severe metabolic acidosis and a very high risk of stillbirth or perinatal mortality.


 

Modified Biophysical Profile
The modified biophysical profile (mBPP) includes only two components:

 

NST (Nonstress Test)

Fetal heart rate acceleration in response to fetal movements

AFI (Amniotic Fluid Index)

Measurement of amniotic fluid volume

 

The mBPP is primarily used for routine surveillance, particularly in high-risk pregnancies, and takes less time (around 10 minutes).

 

Interpretation of MBPP

 

Non-reactive NST or AFI <5

Non-reassuring (abnormal result)

Reactive NST and AFI ≥ 5

Reassuring (normal result)

questions.text: According to new WHO guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits recommended to have a positive pregnancy outcome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 8

 

Explanation:
The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to achieve a positive pregnancy outcome.

 

 

WHO Recommendations

Indian Recommendations (National Guidelines)

under Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY)

Minimum Visits

8 visits

4 visits

 

WHO Antenatal Care (ANC) Recommendations (2016 Update)

 

Visit No.

Timing

Visit 1

Up to 12 weeks

Visit 2

At 20 weeks

Visit 3

At 26 weeks

Visit 4

At 30 weeks

Visit 5

At 34 weeks

Visit 6

At 36 weeks

Visit 7

At 38 weeks

Visit 8

At 40 weeks

 

Indian Antenatal Care (ANC) Recommendations

 

Visit No.

Timing

Components of Care

Visit 1

Up to 12 weeks

Register the pregnancy, initial screening (blood pressure, hemoglobin, blood grouping), and tetanus vaccination.

Visit 2

16–20 weeks

Monitor weight, hemoglobin, and provide counseling on nutrition and lifestyle; ultrasound for fetal development.

Visit 3

24–28 weeks

Screening for anemia, blood pressure monitoring, offer iron and folic acid supplementation.

Visit 4

32–36 weeks

Focus on fetal monitoring (position and movements), tetanus vaccination if needed, and provide education on labor and delivery.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of dilation and curettage (D&C) in sequence:

 


	Serial dilation
	Curettage
	Uterine sound
	Assessment of uterine size and direction
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 4-3-1-2

 

Explanation:

The correct sequence of steps for a dilation and curettage (D&C) procedure is 4-3-1-2 (Assessment of uterine size and direction → Uterine sound → Serial dilation → Curettage)

 

Steps of Dilatation and Curettage (D&C):

 

  • Empty the patient’s bladder.
  • Perform the procedure under general anesthesia or diazepam sedation, with or without a paracervical block.
  • Place the patient in lithotomy position, clean the area with antiseptic, and drape.
  • Conduct a bimanual examination to assess uterine size and position. (4)
  • Insert a posterior vaginal speculum to visualize the cervix.
  • Grasp the anterior lip of the cervix with Allis tissue forceps or vulsellum.
  • Introduce a uterine sound to confirm uterine position and measure uterocervical length. (3)
  • Dilate the cervical canal with graduated dilators, applying traction with vulsellum. (1)
  • Curette the uterine cavity using a uterine curette in a clockwise or anticlockwise direction from fundus to internal os. (2)
  • Remove the vulsellum and speculum.
  • Preserve curetted material in 10% formol-saline, label it, and send it for histological examination.

Complications:

  • Infection
  • Hemorrhage
  • Cervical lacerations
  • Uterine perforation
  • Post-operative uterine adhesions

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except?

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 minutes and 8 contractions in 60 minutes with changes in the cervix.

Cervical dilatation > 2 cm.
More than 80 percent effaced cervix.
Cervix posterior in position.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cervix posterior in position.

 

Explanation:

The diagnostic criteria for preterm labor (PTL) do not include a posterior cervix as a defining feature.

  • A posterior cervix is typically associated with a lower Bishop’s score and indicates a lower likelihood of preterm labor.
  • On the other hand, a cervix in the anterior or midline position is associated with a higher likelihood of preterm labor, as these positions favor cervical dilation and effacement.

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Preterm Labor:

 

  1. Contractions: Regular uterine contractions occurring at least once every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain. (Option A ruled out)
  2. Cervical Changes:
    • Cervical dilation > 2 cm. (Option B ruled out)
    • Cervical effacement > 80%. (Option C ruled out)
    • Cervical length (on TVS) < 2.6 cm.
    • Funneling of the internal os > 1 cm.
  3. Symptoms: Pelvic pressure, backache, vaginal discharge, or bleeding per vaginum.

 

Predictors of Preterm Labor:

 

Clinical predictors:

  • History of prior preterm birth.
  • Multiple pregnancies.
  • Active genital tract infection.

 

Biophysical predictors:

  • Uterine contractions >24/hour.
  • Bishop score >4.
  • Cervical length <25 mm on transvaginal ultrasound.

 

Biochemical predictors:

  • Positive fetal fibronectin (fFN) (>60 ng/mL) in cervico-vaginal discharge.
  • Elevated levels of IL-6, IL-8, and TNF-alpha.

Modified Bishop's Score:

Parameter

Score 0

Score 1

Score 2

Score 3

Cervical Dilation

Closed or ≤1 cm

2-3 cm

4-5 cm

≥6 cm

Cervical Effacement

0-30%

40-50%

60-70%

≥80%

Fetal Station

-3 (high)

-2 (presenting part at ischial spines)

-1 to 0 (at the level of the ischial spines)

+1 to +2 (below the ischial spines)

Cervical Consistency

Firm

Medium

Soft

Very soft

Cervical Position

Posterior

Mid-position

Anterior

Very anterior

 

Total Score Interpretation:

  • Score 0-3: Unfavorable for labor induction.
  • Score 4-5: Fairly favorable for labor induction.

Score 6 or above: Favorable for labor induction and higher chances of successful vaginal delivery.

questions.text: A pregnant lady at 20 weeks of gestation presents with acute onset fever and pain in the right lumbar region, associated with chills, nausea, and vomiting. Urinalysis reveals the presence of E. coli, and a diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis is made. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the management of acute pyelonephritis in pregnancy?

choices.text: Hospitalize, send urine and blood cultures, and start on antibiotics.
Maintain urine output >60 mL/hr; intravenous crystalloids can be given.
Discharge if afebrile for 72 hours; continue antibiotics for 6 days.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Discharge if afebrile for 72 hours; continue antibiotics for 6 days.

 

Explanation:

The patient can be discharged once afebrile for 24 hours, not 72 hours, and antibiotics must be continued for 7 to 10 days, not just 6 days.

 

Management of Acute Pyelonephritis in Pregnancy:

 

Hospitalization: Recommended for all patients, except for rare uncomplicated cases that may be managed outpatient.

 

Culture: Obtain urine and blood cultures (if fever >39°C) to identify the causative organism, typically E. coli. (Option A ruled out)

 

Intravenous Hydration: Aggressive hydration with intravenous crystalloids is crucial to maintain adequate urine output (≥60 mL/hr) to prevent dehydration and maintain renal function. (Option C ruled out)

 

Antibiotics:

  • Start with intravenous antibiotics: Ampicillin plus gentamicin, cefazolin, or ceftriaxone.
  • Once the patient is afebrile, transition to oral antibiotics. (Option B ruled out)

 

Duration of Antibiotic Therapy: Continue antibiotics for 7 to 10 days to ensure complete resolution of the infection.

 

Monitoring:

  • Monitor vital signs, including blood pressure, pulse, temperature, and oxygen saturation.
  • Also monitor urine output to detect signs of worsening sepsis.

 

Follow-up: Repeat urine culture 1-2 weeks after completing antibiotic therapy to ensure eradication of the infection.

 

Renal Sonography: If there is persistent infection or lack of improvement within 48-72 hours, renal sonography may be performed to rule out urinary tract abnormalities (e.g., obstruction, calculi).

questions.text: All of the following coagulation factors increase in pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Factor XI

 

Explanation:

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state to facilitate hemostasis during labor and placental separation. In pregnancy, most coagulation factors are increased, except for Factor XI and Factor XIII.

 

Hematological changes in pregnancy:

 

Factors Increasing

Factors Decreasing
  • Fibrinogen
  • Coagulation factors 7, 8, 9, 10
  • Insulin
  • LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein)
  • Apolipoproteins
  • Transferrin and TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity)
  • CRP (C-Reactive Protein)
  • Placental phosphatase
  • Total alkaline phosphatase
  • Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)
  • Iron and Ferritin
  • Neutrophils
  • Hemoglobin concentration
  • Total plasma protein
  • Globulin
  • Albumin
  • Platelets
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)
  • Urea/Creatinine/Uric acid
  • Factor 11, 13
  • Sodium (Na)
  • Potassium (K)
  • Calcium (Ca)
  • Magnesium (Mg)
  • Iron stores and Ferritin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?

choices.text: Start colloid initially, 4 times the blood lost
Primary PPH occurs within 24 hours of childbirth
PPH is the loss of 500 ml of blood in vaginal delivery
Causes include retained placenta and uterine atony

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Start colloid initially, 4 times the blood lost

 

Explanation:

The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends using intravenous crystalloids (like normal saline or Ringer's lactate) rather than colloids for fluid resuscitation in the management of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

 

Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH)

 

Vaginal Delivery: Blood loss > 500 mL. (Option C ruled out)

Cesarean Section: Blood loss > 1000 mL.

 

Types of PPH:

  • Primary PPH: Within 24 hours of delivery (Option B ruled out)
    • Most common cause: Atonic PPH
  • Secondary PPH: After 24 hours of delivery to 12 weeks
    • Most common cause: Retained bits of placenta (Option D ruled out)


 

Causes of Primary PPH

Cause

Description

Factors increasing risk

Uterine Atony (Most common)

The inability of the uterus to contract effectively after delivery leads to a soft and boggy uterus and continuous bleeding from the placental site.
  • Grand multiparity
  • Overdistension of the uterus: Multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, large baby Malnutrition, and anemia
  • Antepartum hemorrhage: Placenta previa and placental abruption
  • Prolonged labour
  • Anesthesia
  • Oxytocin use.
  • Uterine malformations
  • Other factors: Obesity, h/o PPH, advanced maternal age (over 40 years), tocolytics and magnesium sulfate

Retained Tissue

Prevents proper uterine contraction, causing primary PPH with continued bleeding and incomplete contraction.

Although more commonly associated with secondary PPH, retained placental fragments can also be a cause of primary PPH.

Trauma to the genital tract

Cervical, vaginal, or perineal tears are a significant cause of primary PPH. This type of bleeding occurs despite a well-contracted uterus.
  • Assisted deliveries
  • Rapid labor
  • Large babies

Thrombin (Coagulopathy)

Involves disorders of blood clotting, which are a less common cause of PPH. They can be acquired or congenital.
  • Placental abruption
  • Jaundice in pregnancy
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Intrauterine device (IUD)

 

Management:

Initial Fluid Resuscitation: Start with crystalloids (up to 2 liters) for fluid resuscitation, with blood transfusion if needed.

  • Crystalloids like normal saline or Ringer's lactate are the first choice for fluid resuscitation in PPH.

Blood Transfusion may be needed depending on the severity of blood loss.

Colloids may be considered if there is a need for packed RBC transfusion once blood is available.

questions.text: All of the following statements about anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) are true, except:

choices.text: It is best tested in the fasting state on day 3 of the menstrual cycle
It is a lipopeptide secreted from granulosa cells of early antral follicles
It correlates with the pregnancy rate of IVF cycles
It decreases the sensitivity of pre-antral follicles to FSH

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is a lipopeptide secreted from granulosa cells of early antral follicles

 

Explanation:

  • AMH is not a lipopeptide but rather a glycopeptide. It is secreted by the granulosa cells of the pre-antral and early antral follicles of the ovaries.
  • In males, AMH inhibits the development of the Mullerian ducts, playing a key role in the sexual differentiation of males.
  • In females, it helps regulate follicular development and oocyte maturation.


Role in Female Reproduction:

  • Follicular Development: AMH actually helps prevent the premature recruitment of follicles by inhibiting the sensitivity of the pre-antral and small antral follicles to FSH. This means that higher AMH levels are associated with better preservation of the ovarian reserve, as it delays the onset of follicular development. (Option D ruled out)

 

  • Ovarian Reserve Indicator: AMH levels correlate with the number of antral follicles and are considered a strong marker for ovarian reserve.

 

AMH Levels and Fertility:

  • High AMH Levels: Elevated AMH levels (>10 ng/mL) are often associated with conditions like Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) and may indicate a higher number of available follicles.
  • Low AMH Levels: Reduced AMH levels (<1 ng/mL) suggest diminished ovarian reserve, which may impact fertility potential.
     

AMH Testing:

  • Purpose: AMH testing is utilized to assess ovarian reserve, predict ovarian response in assisted reproductive technologies like IVF, and evaluate conditions such as PCOS. (Option C ruled out)
  • Timing: AMH levels remain relatively stable throughout the menstrual cycle, allowing for testing at any time. However, measuring AMH on Days 1-3 of the menstrual cycle can provide a more accurate assessment of ovarian reserve. (Option A ruled out)

 

Clinical Implications:

Fertility Assessment: AMH levels assist in evaluating a woman's fertility potential, guiding decisions regarding fertility preservation and treatment options.
IVF Prognosis: In IVF cycles, higher AMH levels are associated with a better ovarian response, leading to higher egg retrieval numbers and potentially increased success rates.

questions.text: A and B in the graph below represent which of the following ions, in terms of permeability for action potential generation?

choices.text: A is Na+, B is K+
A is Na+, B is Ca2+
A is K+, B is Ca2+
A is Ca2+, B is K+

questions.solution:
Answer: A) A is Na+, B is K+

 

Explanation:

 

  • Resting Membrane Potential (Point A on graph): 

    • At rest, the neuron's membrane potential is around -70 mV.

    • K+ permeability is higher than Na+ permeability due to the presence of K+ leak channels.

    • However, the overall permeability to both ions is relatively low.

  • Depolarization Phase (Between Points A and C):

    • Voltage-gated Na+ channels open faster than K+ channels.

    • Rapid influx of Na+ ions, causing a rapid rise in membrane potential, causing a steep slope.

  •  

  • Peak of Action Potential (Point C):

    • Na+ permeability is at its maximum.

    • K+ channels are also opening at this stage but have not reached their peak.

  •  

  • Early Repolarization Phase (Point D):

    • Early phase of repolarization.

    • Voltage-gated K+ channels are fully open, resulting in the highest permeability.

    • Na+ channels are rapidly inactivated during this phase.

  • Late Repolarization and After-hyperpolarization (Points E and F):

    • K+ permeability starts to decline as the membrane potential moves towards its resting state.

  • Slow closure of K+ channels results in a period of hyperpolarization, where the membrane potential falls slightly below the resting potential (Point F).

questions.text: An elderly woman underwent surgical resection of her bowel; after a few months, she presents with easy fatigability and tiredness. Blood smear evaluation shows macrocytic anaemia. Resection of all of the following can cause this, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Duodenum

Explanation:

Resection of the duodenum is least likely to cause Macrocytic Anemia, as it typically leads to iron deficiency anaemia, which is microcytic and hypochromic.

  • Causes:

Folic acid Deficiency

Vitamin B12 Deficiency
  • Site of folate absorption - Jejunum (Option A ruled out)
  • Seen in: Alcoholics, pregnancy
  • Causes neural tube defects
  • Neurological symptoms are not seen
  • Normal methylmalonic acid
  • High homocysteine
  • FIGLU test positive
  • Site of B12 absorption - Ileum (Option C ruled out)
  • Seen in: Vegetarians, pregnancy, Diphyllobothrium latum infection
  • Neurological manifestation: Subacute combined degeneration
  • High methylmalonic acid
  • High homocysteine

 

Vitamin B12 Absorption and Transport:

  • Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum.
  • Haptocorrin, secreted by the salivary gland, binds to B12 in the stomach and enters the duodenum.
  • Haptocorrin is separated from B12 by pancreatic enzymes and binds to IF.
  • Absorbed B12 is transported by transcobalamin II.
  • It is stored primarily in the liver and has a large reserve capacity to last several years.
  • Vitamin B12 is a cofactor for:
    • Conversion of homocysteine to methionine.
    • Methyl malonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA.

Stomach (Option D) produces intrinsic factors, which are necessary for vitamin B12 absorption in the ileum. Resection of the stomach, particularly in cases like gastrectomy, can cause vitamin B12 deficiency and subsequent macrocytic anaemia.

questions.text: Vessel A has a length of L and a diameter of D, and vessel B has 2L and 2D. Considering the flow is laminar through both cylinders, the flow through B is how many times as much as the flow through A?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) 8 times

 

Explanation:

Flow is equal to the pressure difference divided by resistance. So, flow is inversely proportional to the resistance of the vessel.

 

According to the Hagen–Poiseuille equation, resistance can be directly measured by the following formula.

 

R = 8hL/pr4

 

Where,

  • R = resistance.
  • h = viscosity.
  • L = length.
  • r = radius of the vessel.


 

From this equation, the resistance of a vessel is inversely proportional to the fourth power of radius and directly proportional to the length of the vessel..

 

So, if the radius and length are doubled, the original and other parameters remain constant, then the resistance will be:

  • R = L/(r)4.
  • R = 2/(2)4
  • R = 2/16 = 8.

 

So, the resistance will decrease by 8 times, and flow will increase by 8 times.

questions.text: Which of these is the most life-threatening injury that can be identified by assessing the breathing component of the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tension Pneumothorax

 

Explanation:

  • Tension Pneumothorax is the most life-threatening injury that can be identified by assessing the patient's breathing component.
  • It occurs when air accumulates in the pleural space, increasing pressure on the lungs and heart, leading to lung collapse and impaired blood flow.
  • It can rapidly cause cardiovascular collapse and is fatal without prompt decompression.

 

Life-threatening Injuries

  • These can be remembered as the ‘deadly dozen’.
    • Six Immediately life-threatening injuries were managed during the primary survey.
    • Six Potentially life-threatening injuries were detected during the secondary survey.

 

Immediately life-threatening injuries

Potentially life-threatening injuries
  • Airway obstruction
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Open pneumothorax
  • Massive haemothorax
  • Flail chest
  • Aortic injuries
  • Tracheobronchial injuries
  • Myocardial contusion
  • Rupture of the diaphragm
  • Oesophageal injuries
  • Pulmonary contusion

Cervical spine injury (Option A) can cause neurological complications, but it doesn’t directly compromise breathing, making it less life-threatening compared to other injuries in this context.

Blunt cardiac injury (Option C) primarily affects the heart, potentially leading to arrhythmias or cardiac rupture. While it can be life-threatening, it does not directly compromise breathing, unlike other injuries.

Laryngotracheal injury (Option D) can cause airway obstruction and breathing difficulties, but tension pneumothorax is more immediately life-threatening, rapidly leading to respiratory and cardiovascular collapse if untreated.

questions.text: Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by which of the following proteins:
questions.solution:
Answer: D) Divalent metal transporter – 1

 

Explanation:

Divalent metal transporter-1 (DMT1) is a transmembrane protein located in the apical membrane of enterocytes. It is responsible for transporting ferrous forms of iron from the intestinal lumen into the enterocyte. DMT1 is expressed in the duodenum, the first part of the small intestine where iron is absorbed from the diet.

 

Transferrin (Option A): It binds and transports iron in the bloodstream, but not into enterocytes.

Ferroportin (Option B): This protein transports iron out of enterocytes into the bloodstream, not into the enterocyte

Hepcidin (Option C): It regulates iron homeostasis by inhibiting ferroportin, thus reducing iron export, but it does not transport iron into enterocytes.

questions.text: What preoperative intervention can be administered to minimise intraoperative bleeding in a 32-year-old female patient diagnosed with Grave's disease, presenting with eye symptoms and an enlarged thyroid, who is scheduled to undergo a total thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Potassium iodide

 

Explanation:

The most appropriate preoperative intervention to minimise intraoperative bleeding in a patient with Grave's disease scheduled for a total thyroidectomy is Potassium Iodide.

  • It reduces thyroid vascularity and size, helping minimise bleeding during surgery.
  • Mechanism: It inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis and decreases the thyroid gland's vascularity.

 

Lugol’s Iodine

  • It is a Saturated Potassium Iodide Solution (5% iodine + 10% potassium iodide)
  • Dose: 3 drops TID for 7-10 days.
  • Role:
    • Reduce Vascularity: Used pre-operatively to reduce the vascularity of the thyroid gland. This helps in minimising bleeding during surgery and prevents complications. (Option A)
    • Prevent Thyroid Storm: Decreasing vascularity also helps prevent thyroid storms, which can occur if there is an excessive release of thyroid hormones during or after surgery.
    • Iodine's Effect: Iodine has a transient effect on thyroid function by inhibiting the release of thyroid hormones from the thyroid gland. This phenomenon is known as the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.
      • In Toxic Multinodular Goiter, Lugol's iodine may not achieve the goal of temporary euthyroidism and instead may exacerbate hyperthyroidism due to the Jod-Basedow phenomenon.

Propranolol (Option B) is a beta-blocker that can be used to manage the symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as tremors, palpitations, and anxiety. It does not affect thyroid vascularity or directly reduce intraoperative bleeding.

Propylthiouracil (PTU) (Option C) is an anti-thyroid medication used in the management of hyperthyroidism (by inhibiting thyroid hormone production) but does not reduce thyroid vascularity or intraoperative bleeding.

Betamethasone (Option D) is a corticosteroid that has anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive properties. It can be used for inflammation and immune suppression but does not reduce thyroid vascularity or intraoperative bleeding in thyroid surgery.

questions.text: What causes the detachment of myosin from actin filaments?

choices.text: Attachment of ATP to the myosin head
Cessation of calcium release from the sarcoplasm

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Attachment of ATP to the myosin head

 

Explanation:

The detachment of myosin from actin filaments occurs when ATP binds to the myosin head.

After the power stroke (when myosin pulls on actin), ADP and inorganic phosphate (Pi) are still bound to the myosin head. When ATP binds to the myosin head, it causes the myosin head to detach from actin. This detachment allows the muscle to relax and prepares the myosin head for the next contraction cycle.

 

Stimulus (e.g., hormones, neurotransmitters, or stretch)

￬

Calcium channels open, allowing Ca²⁺ to enter the cell from the extracellular fluid.

￬

Formation of Calcium-calmodulin complex

(Intracellular Ca²⁺ binds to calmodulin)

￬

The Ca²⁺-calmodulin complex activates myosin light chain kinase (MLCK)

￬

MLCK phosphorylates the light chains of myosin

￬

Phosphorylated myosin interacts with actin filaments.

￬

The interaction between myosin and actin causes contraction

  • Smooth muscle can maintain contraction with less energy expenditure than skeletal muscle (Latch-bridge mechanism).
  • Relaxation: Occurs when Ca²⁺ is pumped out of the cell or back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and myosin is dephosphorylated.

 

Cessation of calcium release from the sarcoplasm (Option B): Calcium ions are essential for muscle contraction. They bind to troponin, causing a conformational change that exposes myosin-binding sites on actin. In the absence of calcium, the cross-bridge cycle halts, preventing the power stroke.

 

Conformational change in Troponin T (Option C): Troponin T helps regulate tropomyosin's position on actin, which controls the binding of myosin to actin, facilitating muscle contraction.

 

Dissociation of ADP and Pi (Option D): The dissociation of ADP and inorganic phosphate (Pi) from myosin triggers the power stroke, driving muscle contraction.

questions.text: Hand rub can be utilised in accordance with the standard hand hygiene protocol in all locations listed below, with the exception of:

choices.text: If the hands are visibly soiled
While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) If the hands are visibly soiled

 

Explanation:

As per the WHO Standard Hand Hygiene Protocol, hand rub is not suitable for visibly soiled hands, and handwashing with soap and water is required to remove dirt and contaminants.

 

Indications:

  • Wash hands with soap and water when visibly dirty or visibly soiled with blood or other body fluids or after using the toilet. (Option A)
  • If exposure to potential spore-forming pathogens is strongly suspected or proven, including outbreaks of Clostridium difficile, hand washing with soap and water is the preferred means.
  • Use an alcohol-based hand rub as the preferred means for routine hand antisepsis in clinical situations if hands are not visibly soiled. (Option A)
    • If alcohol-based hand rub is not obtainable, wash hands with soap and water.
  • Perform hand hygiene:
    • Before and after touching the patient. (Option D ruled out)
    • Before handling an invasive device for patient care, regardless of whether or not gloves are used
    • After contact with body fluids or excretions, mucous membranes, non-intact skin, or wound dressings
    • If moving from a contaminated body site to another body site during the care of the same patient (Option B ruled out)
    • After contact with inanimate surfaces and objects (including medical equipment) in the immediate vicinity of the patient.
    • After removing sterile or non-sterile gloves. (Option C ruled out)
  • Before handling medication or preparing food, perform hand hygiene using an alcohol-based hand rub or wash hands with either plain or antimicrobial soap and water.
  • Soap and alcohol-based hand rubs should not be used concomitantly.

 

Technique:

  • Apply a palmful of alcohol-based hand rub and cover all surfaces of the hands. Rub hands until dry.
  • When washing hands with soap and water,
    • Wet hands with water and apply the amount of product necessary to cover all surfaces.
    • Rinse hands with water and dry thoroughly with a single-use towel.
    • Use clean, running water whenever possible.
    • Avoid using hot water, as repeated exposure to hot water may increase the risk of dermatitis.
    • Use towel to turn off the tap/faucet.
    • Dry hands thoroughly using a method that does not recontaminate hands.
    • Make sure towels are not used multiple times or by multiple people.
  • Liquid, bar, leaf or powdered forms of soap are acceptable.
    • When bar soap is used, small bars of soap in racks that facilitate drainage should be used to allow the bars to dry.

questions.text:
The correct sequence of events during vomiting are? 

1. Relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter 

2. Strong contractions in the stomach 

3. Inspiration against a closed glottis 

4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter 

5. Relaxation of upper esophageal sphincter 

6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine
questions.solution:
Answer: B) 6,4,3,2,1,5

Explanation:

Sequence of Events During Vomiting

  1. Reverse Peristalsis in the Small Intestine:
    • Reverse peristalsis pushes intestinal contents back into the stomach, possibly introducing bile into the vomit.
  2. Relaxation of Pyloric Sphincter:
    • In severe cases, the pyloric sphincter relaxes, facilitating the expulsion of gastric and duodenal contents.
  3. Inspiration Against a Closed Glottis:
    • A deep breath is taken while the glottis remains closed, creating negative pressure in the thoracic cavity.
  4. Strong Contractions in the Stomach:
    • Abdominal muscles and diaphragm contract, increasing intragastric pressure, propelling contents upward.
  5. Relaxation of Lower Esophageal Sphincter (LES):
    • LES relaxes, allowing stomach contents to move into the esophagus.
  6. Relaxation of Upper Esophageal Sphincter (UES):
    • UES relaxes, allowing vomitus to exit through the mouth

 

Step

Description

1. Relaxation of LES

LES relaxes to allow stomach contents to move into the esophagus.

2. Strong Contractions in Stomach

Abdominal and diaphragm muscles contract to propel stomach contents upward.

3. Inspiration Against Closed Glottis

Deep breath with glottis closed creates negative pressure for expulsion.

4. Relaxation of UES

UES relaxes, allowing vomitus to exit the mouth.

5. Reverse Peristalsis in Small Intestine

Reverse peristalsis pushes intestinal contents back into the stomach.

6. Relaxation of Pyloric Sphincter

In severe vomiting, pyloric sphincter relaxes, aiding in expulsion.

questions.text:
In the case of a patient arriving at the emergency department with a road traffic accident (RTA), what is the appropriate order of steps in their management?


	Cervial spine stabilisation
	Intubation
	IV cannulation
	CECT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2, 3, 4

Explanation:

The proper sequence of Trauma Care management for a patient presenting with an RTA (road traffic accident) is 1, 2, 3, 4.

 

Primary Survey

It aims to identify and manage the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first and follows cABCDE.

  • c: Exsanguinating external haemorrhage
    • The exsanguinating external haemorrhage from massive arterial bleeding needs to be controlled even before the airway is managed.
  • A: Airway with cervical spine control
    • Cervical spine stabilisation. (Statement 1)
    • Assessment of the patient’s airway.
    • Compromised airway requires a stepwise progression:
      • Clearing the airway by suctioning secretions or blood.
      • Simple airway manoeuvres (jaw thrust, chin lift and insertion of an oropharyngeal or nasopharyngeal airway).
      • Advanced airway manoeuvres (intubation). (Statement 2)
  • B: Breathing and ventilation
    • High-flow oxygen.
    • Assess bilateral chest raise.
    • Assess breath sounds
    • Use pulse oximetry
    • Life-threatening chest pathology (tension pneumothorax, massive haemothorax and fail segment) should be diagnosed and managed.
  • C: Circulation and haemorrhage control
    • Monitor vitals.
    • Heart sounds
    • ECG
    • Intravenous (IV) access with at least two large-bore IV cannulae (central, peripheral). (Statement 3)
    • Blood was taken for cross-match and laboratory assessment.
    • Treatment of shock.
    • Control of external bleeding.
  • D: Disability
    • Neurological examination.
    • Use required tubes like catheters, Ryle’s tube.
  • E: Exposure
    • Undress the patient
    • Hypothermia assessment.
    • Assess injuries (imaging like USG, CT scan, MRI). (Statement 4)
    • Examine joints, bones, abdomen, and other systems.
    • Look for identification marks.

 

Secondary Survey:

  • Detailed top-to-toe examinations after life-threatening injuries have been identified and managed during the primary survey.
  • Patients may be intubated and unresponsive at this point, limiting the accuracy of clinical examination.

 

Tertiary survey

  • After extubation, identify any missed ‘minor’ injuries (scaphoid fracture in the wrist or a rotator cuff tear in the shoulder).
  • These injuries have the potential to cause significant long-term disability.

questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) 50 mL/hour

 

Explanation:

Insensible water loss is the amount of water lost from the body through evaporation, such as through the skin or respiratory tract that cannot be easily measured. Normal insensible water loss is generally considered to be around 30-50 mL/hour in adults.

Insensible Water Loss

  • Definition:
    • Unconscious water loss through skin diffusion and respiration, distinct from sensible losses (urine and feces).
  • Typical Values:
    • Total loss: 600 to 800 mL/day. (~35ml-50ml/hour)
    • Skin diffusion: 300 to 400 mL/day.
    • Respiratory loss: 250 to 350 mL/day.
    • Represents 30% to 50% of total daily water loss.
  • Factors Influencing Loss:
    • Environmental conditions: Higher temperatures and lower humidity increase evaporative loss.
    • Physical activity: Increases respiratory rate, enhancing water loss.
  • Clinical Importance:
    • Key in managing fluid balance in patients, especially during surgery or in conditions affecting hydration.

Category

Value

Total Insensible Loss

600-800 mL/day

Skin Diffusion

300-400 mL/day

Respiratory Loss

250-350 mL/day

Percentage of Total Loss

30%-50%

questions.text: What does the number (14Fr) marked on the Foley catheter correspond to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Outer tube diameter

 

Explanation:

The number (14Fr) marked on the Foley’s Catheter indicates its outer tube diameter, measured in French (Fr) units, where 1 French equals 0.33 mm.

Material

LATEX - Less irritation & crust formation

Silicone Coating- for Prolonged use (up to 3 months)

Types
  • 2-way Foley catheter
  • 3-way Foley catheter

Channels

2-way Foley catheter:

  • Main channel: For drainage of urine
  • Small channel: For inflating balloon

3-way Foley catheter:

  • Main channel: for drainage of urine
  • Additional channel for irrigation

Balloon Inflation
  • 20-30 ml saline for self-retaining
  • 30-50 ml of saline for a hemostatic compression effect

Sizes (French scale)

Pediatric patients: 4, 6, 8, 10

Adult patients: 12, 14, 16, 18

Size Calculation

Outer diameter of catheter in mm = Fr/3 (Fr - French units)

E.g., if the size of the catheter is 18 French, then diameter = 18/3 = 6mm

Uses
  • To relieve urinary retention
  • To measure urine output
  • For administration of intravesical chemotherapy
  • 3 ways catheter - for Irrigation after TURP
  • May be used for supra-pubic cystostomy

Inner lumen diameter (Option A): The marked number refers to the outer diameter, not the inner lumen diameter, which impacts flow rate but is not indicated by the French size.
