Length of the tube (Option B): The French size does not represent the catheter's length, which is usually marked separately and unrelated to the outer diameter measurement.

Bulb size (Option D): The French size does not indicate the balloon or bulb size, which is specified separately and unrelated to the outer tube diameter.

questions.text: The signaling sequence in a type 2 membrane protein with N-terminal facing cytoplasm is located in?

choices.text: Both inside the membrane and at C-terminal

questions.solution:
Answer: A) Inside the membrane

 

Explanation:

  • In Type II membrane proteins, the signal-anchor sequence is a hydrophobic transmembrane domain that integrates into the lipid bilayer.
  • This non-cleavable sequence directs the protein to the membrane, anchoring it in place, with the N-terminal in the cytoplasm and the C-terminal facing the extracellular space or lumen.

Type II Membrane Proteins Overview

  • Signal-Anchor Sequence:
    • Contains a non-cleavable signal-anchor sequence that anchors the protein to the membrane, unlike type I proteins.
    • Functions as both a signal and membrane anchor during protein synthesis.
  • Orientation:
    • N-terminal is directed towards the cytoplasm.
    • C-terminal faces the extracellular space or the lumen of organelles (e.g., ER, Golgi).
  • Insertion Mechanism:
    • Insertion occurs cotranslationally into the ER.
    • The signal-anchor sequence directs the polypeptide to the translocon.
    • Positively charged amino acids before the transmembrane domain ensure proper orientation.
  • Examples:
    • Transferrin receptor and glycosyltransferases.

 

At the C-terminal (Option B): : The signal-anchor sequence is not at the C-terminal; it is near the N-terminal, which faces the cytoplasm.

 

At the N-terminal (Option C): The N-terminal faces the cytoplasm but does not contain the signal-anchor sequence, which is located near it.

 

Both inside the membrane and at the C-terminal (Option D): The signal-anchor sequence is inside the membrane but not at the C-terminal; it functions as a transmembrane domain.

questions.text: Which of the following options does not represent one of the boundaries of the triangle of safety for the insertion of an ICD in a patient with a chest x-ray showing pneumothorax?

choices.text: Lateral edge of the pectoralis major

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mid-clavicular line

 

Explanation:

The mid-clavicular line is a vertical line through the clavicle and does not define the boundaries of the Triangle of Safety.

  • It is an anatomical region in the axilla that guides the safe position for intercostal catheter (ICC) placement.
    • With the arm abducted, the apex is the axilla, and the triangle is formed by the following:
      • The lateral border of the pectoralis major - anteriorly. (Option A ruled out)
      • The lateral border of the latissimus dorsi - posteriorly. (Option D ruled out)
      • Inferiorly, by a horizontal line from the nipple (commonly the 5th intercostal space). (Option B ruled out)

 

Triangle of safety

It occurs due to closure of fast voltage gated sodium channels and opening of slow voltage gated potassium channels leading to the efflux of K+ out of the cell resulting in the restoration of the resting membrane potential.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is accurate concerning split-thickness and full-thickness skin grafts?


	Primary contractures are more in split skin grafts
	Secondary contractures are more in split skin grafts
	Primary contractures are more in full-thickness grafts
	Secondary contractures are more in full-thickness grafts
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 2 and 3

 

Explanation:

  • Primary contraction is the initial recoil of the skin graft, which is more pronounced in full-thickness grafts.
  • Secondary contraction occurs after the healing process and is commonly seen in split-thickness grafts.

 

Feature

Split-Thickness Skin Graft

Full-Thickness Skin Graft

Composition

Epidermis + part of dermis

Epidermis + full thickness of dermis

Graft Size

Large grafts can be taken

Only small grafts can be taken

Graft Survival

Easier

More difficult

Donor Site Healing

Heals spontaneously, allowing repeated grafts

Permanent defect develops, preventing repeated grafts

Graft Contraction (Option A)

Secondary contracture is more significant

Primary contracture is more significant

Common Donor Sites

Inner thigh, upper arm, flexor aspect of forearm, abdominal wall

Upper eyelid, retro auricular skin, supraclavicular skin, antecubital skin, inframammary skin, inguinal skin, genital skin, gluteal skin

Donor Site Exclusions

None

Axilla is not used as a donor site

Advantages of Harvesting

Allows calibration of thickness and large area coverage

Calibration of thickness for small but thick grafts

questions.text: Which among the following organs has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Kidney

 

Explanation:

  • The kidneys have the smallest arteriovenous oxygen difference, indicating they extract less oxygen from the blood.
  • This is due to their lower metabolic demand, as their primary function is to filter waste rather than perform energy-intensive processes.

 

The arteriovenous oxygen difference measures how much oxygen tissues absorb from the blood

 

Arteriovenous Oxygen Difference

Organs Arteriovenous oxygen difference (ml/L)

Brain

62

Kidney

14

Skin

25

Liver

34

Heart muscles

114

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding acute cholecystitis is false?

choices.text: Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG
Gold standard investigation is CT scan

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The gold standard investigation for acute cholecystitis is the HIDA (Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid) Scan, not a CT scan.
  • Non-visualization of the gallbladder on a HIDA scan indicates cystic duct obstruction, a key characteristic of acute cholecystitis, thus making it a diagnostic feature. 

Tokyo Guidelines for Acute Cholecystitis (2013/2018)

Local Signs of Inflammation:
  • Murphy's sign (Option B ruled out)
  • Right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain/ tenderness or a palpable mass.

Systemic Signs of Inflammation:
  • Fever
  • Elevated CRP
  • Elevated WBC (Option C ruled out)

Imaging Findings:
  • Gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm) (Option A ruled out)
  • Pericholecystic fluid,
  • Ultrasonographic Murphy's sign.

questions.text: What is indicated by the curve labeled as 'A' in the given oxygen dissociation curves graph?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Myoglobin

 

Explanation:

  • Myoglobin is a protein found in muscle cells that is responsible for storing and delivering oxygen to the muscle tissue.
  • The oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin is hyperbolic, because in the case of myoglobin, one molecule of hemoglobin binds with one molecule of oxygen, and complete saturation will occur.
  • Therefore, a sudden increase in saturation can be seen in a myoglobin curve.


 

Myoglobin-O2 dissociation curve:


  • The oxygen dissociation curve for myoglobin is rectangular hyperbolic.
  • This is because, in the case of myoglobin, one molecule of haemoglobin binds with one molecule of oxygen with high affinity, and complete saturation will occur.
  • Unlike haemoglobin, which has a sigmoidal curve due to cooperative binding among its four subunits, myoglobin's curve does not exhibit cooperativity.
  • This means myoglobin can efficiently bind and release oxygen at varying partial pressures, making it well-suited for oxygen storage in muscle tissues.

 

Carboxyhemoglobinemia (Option B): Carboxyhemoglobinemia shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to the left and markedly reduces the oxygen dissociation.

 

Methemoglobin (Option C): Methemoglobin is a form of hemoglobin that has been oxidized and can no longer bind to oxygen effectively due to ferric state or iron.

 

Fetal hemoglobin (Option D): Fetal hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen than adult hemoglobin. This shifts the oxygen dissociation curve to the left as marked by B.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding central venous access and peripheral venous access?


	Phlebitis is the most common complication in peripheral venous access.
	Isotonic saline and heparin are flushed to retain patency
	If an arteriovenous fistula is present in a limb, avoid peripheral venous access in the same limb.
	Vasopressors for septic shock are given in the central line to avoid limb ischemia.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 2, 3, 4

Explanation:

All four statements regarding central venous access and peripheral venous access are true.

  • Phlebitis is the most common complication in peripheral venous access
    • It refers to inflammation of the vein
    • It is a common complication of peripheral venous access.
    • It can occur due to various factors, such as chemical irritation, mechanical irritation, or infection.
  • Isotonic saline and heparin are flushed to retain patency:
    • To maintain the patency of central venous access devices (such as central venous catheters or central lines), periodic flushing with isotonic saline and heparin is commonly performed.
    • This helps prevent clot formation and maintain the functionality of the line.
  • If an arteriovenous fistula is present in a limb, avoid peripheral venous access in the same limb.
    • An arteriovenous fistula (AVF) is a surgically created connection between an artery and a vein, typically used for hemodialysis.
    • When an AVF is present in a limb, it is generally recommended to avoid peripheral venous access in the same limb to prevent damage to the AVF and maintain its functionality.
  • Vasopressors for septic shock are given in the central line to avoid limb ischemia.
    • Vasopressors for septic shock can be administered through either central venous access or peripheral venous access, depending on the clinical situation and availability of access.
    • The choice of access depends on factors such as the stability of peripheral veins, the need for continuous infusion, and the urgency of treatment.
    • Limb ischemia is a potential complication of vasopressor administration, but it is not exclusive to peripheral venous access.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a relative contraindication for breast conservative surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tumor size <4 cm

 

Explanation:

Tumor size less than 4 cm is not a relative contraindication for Breast-conserving surgery (BCS), also known as Lumpectomy.

  • It involves removing a breast tumour along with a small margin of surrounding healthy tissue while preserving the majority of the breast.
  • The goal is to remove the cancerous cells while maintaining the breast's appearance and function.

 

Contraindications of Breast-conserving surgery (BCS):

Absolute Contraindications
  • First-trimester Pregnancy
  • Multicentric Disease
  • Diffuse Suspicious microcalcifications on mammogram
  • Extensive DCIS
  • Inflammatory Breast Cancer
  • Tumors for which Clear Margins are Unobtainable with Lumpectomy
  • Homozygous for ATM Mutation

Relative Contraindications
  • Prior Radiation Therapy to the Chest Wall or Breast (Option C ruled out)
  • Active Connective Tissue Disease Involving the Skin (e.g., Scleroderma)
  • Extensive Positive Pathological Margins
  • Large Tumor Size Relative to Breast Size or Tumors >5 cm (Option A)
  • Known or Suspected Li-Fraumeni Syndrome (p53 Mutation) (Option B ruled out)
  • Known or Suspected Genetic Predisposition to Breast Cancer (e.g., BRCA1, BRCA2) (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for the condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rip stein's procedure

 

Explanation:

The image depicts Rectal Prolapse, and Ripstein’s procedure, a surgical treatment, is not a perineal approach.

  • It is the circumferential descent of the rectum through the anal canal.
  • Management of Rectal prolapse:
    • Non-Operative Management
  • Medical Treatment: Palliates symptoms of constipation and faecal incontinence with fluid intake, fibre supplements, stool softeners, and topical treatments for mucosal oedema.
  • Enemas and Suppositories: Assist in defecation and reduce symptoms.

  • Operative Management

    • Rectopexy is fixing the rectum to the sacrum by sutures or mesh after complete mobilisation of the rectum.

 

Aspect
Abdominal Rectopexy
Perineal Rectopexy

Types
  • Prosthetic or mesh rectopexy-anterior/ posterior- Well's, Ripstein (Option A)
  • Suture rectopexy- Lahaut
  • Anterior Resection
  • Resection Rectopexy
  • Mucosal sleeve resection (Delrome's) (Option B ruled out)
  • Perineal recto sigmoidectomy (Altemeier's) (Option D ruled out)
  • Posterior fixation of the rectum of Lockhardt-Mummery
  • Mickulicz Miles perineal transanal recto sigmoidectomy
  • Anal encircling (Thiersch) (Option C ruled out)

Advantages
  • Fixation of the rectum provides adequate tension to prevent recurrence.
  • Minimally invasive options (laparoscopic or robotic) offer benefits in pain control, hospital stay, and recovery time
  • Lower operative morbidity and mortality, suitable for elderly or medically unfit patients.

 

Disadvantages
  • Requires extensive dissection and fixation, which may have higher morbidity (10%-33%).
  • Risk of mesh-related complications such as erosion, infection, bowel obstruction, and migration.
  • Higher recurrence rates compared to abdominal approaches

questions.text: What is the appropriate next step in managing a 37-year-old unmarried woman who has never given birth, is sexually active, and is currently taking oral contraceptive pills, considering that her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 60 and her older sister was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at 40?

choices.text: Genetic counseling and screening for BRCA
Stop taking oral and contraceptive pills

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Genetic counseling and screening for BRCA

 

Explanation:

Given the patient's family history of breast and ovarian cancer, along with her being a 37-year-old unmarried, sexually active woman who has never given birth and is taking oral contraceptive pills, the next step in management would be genetic counselling and BRCA mutation screening.

 

Risk factors for breast cancer

 

Modifiable risk factors

Non-modifiable risk factors

Obesity: BMI > 30 (RR= 1.29)

Age

  • Median age at presentation is 60 years in the West(UK, USA), While it is around 48 years in low/middle-income nations such as India.

Nulliparous women or first pregnancy after 35 years

Sex

  • Female sex is a risk factor
  • Male sex accounts for 0.5-1% of all breast cancer

Breastfeeding is a protective factor

Ethnicity

American white, African-American Parsi in India

Use of Hormonal Replacement Therapy (HRT) >10 years (RR= 1.2)

Family history of breast cancer

  • 1 first-degree relative RR= 2
  • 2 first-degree relative RR= 3

Tobacco use (RR=1.07-1.14)

Genetic predisposition

BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations account for 70% of hereditary breast cancers

Alcohol Consumption (RR = 1.05-1.32)

Early Menarche(<12years)

Increases by around 5% for each year earlier menstruation begins RR=1.19

Radiation exposure (RR=6)

Late Menopause(>55years)

Increases by about 3% for each year later menopause begins RR=1.12

Age at first child

 
  • <20years - Less risk
  • >35years - High risk

High-risk breast lesions

  • Complex fibroadenoma RR=3
  • Papillomatosis RR=3
  • Ductal and lobular hyperplasia RR= 5
  • Lobular carcinoma in situ RR= 8-10

Routine mammography (Option B) is not recommended at age 37 as it is typically for women 40 and older and focuses on screening, not genetic risk assessment.

Stop taking oral contraceptive pills (Option C) should be based on a broader risk assessment, not just family history.

Prophylactic surgery (Option D) is an extreme measure and is typically considered only after genetic testing confirms a significant genetic risk.

questions.text: A 50-year-old alcoholic patient presents with a history of waxing and waning jaundice for the past 2 months. His CT examination reveals dilatation of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct. What is the most probable diagnosis in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Periampullary carcinoma

 

Explanation:

The scenario of an alcoholic patient experiencing fluctuating jaundice, with a CT scan showing dilation of both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct, is most likely indicative of Periampullary Carcinoma.

  • It originates in the pancreas, bile duct, or intestines close to the ampulla of Vater (the region where the common bile duct and pancreatic duct converge and enter the duodenum).
  • They can cause obstruction of both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct.
  • Clinical features:
    • Jaundice (waxing and waning) (most common)
    • A palpable, non-tender gallbladder
    • Weight loss
    • Abdominal pain
    • Nausea/vomiting
    • Pruritus
    • Fever
    • Gastrointestinal bleeding

Cholangiocarcinoma (Option A) arises from the bile ducts and can cause common bile duct dilatation. However, the waxing and waning jaundice and dilatation of the pancreatic duct, in this case, are more indicative of periampullary carcinoma. Cholangiocarcinoma usually presents with more progressive jaundice.

Common bile duct stone (Option C) can cause ductal dilatation, but the waxing and waning jaundice and pancreatic duct involvement make periampullary carcinoma more likely. Bile duct stones typically cause acute, not fluctuating, jaundice.

Head of the pancreas carcinoma (Option D) can cause ductal dilatation, but periampullary carcinoma is a more specific diagnosis given the involvement of both the common bile duct and pancreatic duct. Pancreatic cancer typically presents with continuous jaundice, not fluctuating.

questions.text: The following procedure is performed for the management of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Distal cholangiocarcinoma 

 

Explanation: 

The given image depicts the Pylorus Preserving Whipple’s Procedure (Pancreaticoduodenectomy), which is used in the management of distal cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Structures removed: Head of the pancreas, the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), the gallbladder, and a portion of the bile duct.

Types:

• Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure

• Non–Pylorus-Preserving Whipple Procedure

 

Indications

Pancreatic Cancer: Commonly treated with Whipple if cancer is localised to the head of the pancreas. 

Chronic Pancreatitis: when uncontrolled by medical management. 

Tumors in Pancreas/Surrounding Areas: Includes duodenum, distal bile duct (distal cholangiocarcinoma), and ampulla of Vater. (Option C)

Procedure Steps

Tumor Assessment: Explore the abdomen to assess tumor size, location, and spread. 

Resection: Remove the head of the pancreas, duodenum, gallbladder, and part of the bile duct; this may include partial stomach resection. 

Lymph Node Dissection: Remove and examine nearby lymph nodes.

Reconstruction

Pancreaticojejunostomy: Connect the remaining pancreas to the jejunum. Hepaticojejunostomy: Connect common bile duct to the jejunum. Gastrojejunostomy: Connect stomach to jejunum.

Anastomosis Principles

Tension-Free Connection: Achieve mucosa-to-mucosa connection for healing. 

Order of Anastomoses: Pancreaticojejunostomy → Hepaticojejunostomy → Gastrojejunostomy

Stent Placement: May use internal/external stents for small ducts.

Complications

• Pancreatic Fistula: Major issue; managed with somatostatin analogues. 

• Delayed Gastric Emptying

• Bleeding, wound infection

• Reoperation, increased mortality 

• Dumping/Bile Reflux: Common after non-pylorus-preserving Whipple, the pylorus-preserving method has uncertain benefits.

Advanced gastric carcinoma (Option A): Treatment depends on tumour location. For proximal tumours, extended gastrectomy with D2 lymphadenectomy is done; for middle tumours, total gastrectomy; and for distal tumours, subtotal gastrectomy. The Whipple procedure is specific to pancreaticoduodenal cancers, not gastric carcinoma.

Gallbladder carcinoma (Option B): Treatment involves an extended cholecystectomy, which includes removal of the liver segments, gallbladder, and surrounding lymph nodes. The Whipple procedure is not typically used unless the tumour invades the bile duct or pancreas.

Chronic calcific pancreatitis (Option D): Treatment involves enzyme supplementation, pain management with NSAIDs and opioids, and procedures like ERCP with stenting or drainage. The Whipple procedure is not the first choice; instead, pancreaticojejunostomy or drainage surgeries are preferred based on the extent of the  damage.

questions.text: A patient who had grade 3 splenic trauma was managed conservatively in the ICU. Which of the following signs on day 2 would indicate a need for surgery?

choices.text: Hemoglobin falls from 12 mg/dL to 10 mg/dL

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumoperitoneum

 

Explanation:

In a patient with grade 3 splenic trauma managed conservatively, the presence of pneumoperitoneum on day 2 is a critical sign of an Acute Abdomen, typically indicating a perforated viscus requiring urgent surgical intervention.

  • It refers to the signs and symptoms of abdominal pain and tenderness.
  • It represents an underlying surgical problem that requires prompt diagnosis and surgical treatment.
  • Causes:

 

Surgical Causes

Non-surgical Causes

Endocrine and Metabolic

  • Acute intermittent porphyria
  • Addisonian crisis
  • Diabetic crisis
  • Hereditary Mediterranean fever
  • Uremia

Hematologic

  • Acute leukemia
  • Sickle cell crisis

Toxins and drugs

  • Black widow spider poisoning
  • Lead poisoning
  • Other heavy metal poisoning
  • Narcotic withdrawal

Hemorrhage

  • Aortoduodenal fistula after aortic vascular graft
  • Arteriovenous malformation of the gastrointestinal tract
  • Bleeding gastrointestinal diverticulum
  • Hemorrhagic pancreatitis
  • Intestinal ulceration
  • Leaking or ruptured arterial aneurysm
  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome
  • Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Solid organ trauma
  • Spontaneous splenic rupture

Infections

  • Appendicitis
  • Cholecystitis
  • Diverticulitis
  • Hepatic abscess
  • Meckel diverticulitis
  • Psoas abscess

Ischemia

  • Buerger’s disease
  • Ischemic colitis
  • Mesenteric thrombosis or embolism
  • Ovarian torsion
  • Strangulated hernia
  • Testicular torsion

Obstruction

  • Cecal volvulus
  • Gastrointestinal malignancy
  • Incarcerated hernias
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Intussusception
  • Sigmoid volvulus
  • Small bowel obstruction

Perforation

  • Boerhaave syndrome
  • Perforated diverticulum
  • Perforated gastrointestinal cancer
  • Perforated gastrointestinal ulcer

Hemoglobin falls from 12 mg/dL to 10 mg/dL (Option A): A mild drop in hemoglobin may indicate blood loss but doesn't necessarily require surgery. Conservative management can continue if the patient remains stable, with surgery considered only for significant drops or signs of instability.

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture (Option B): While serious, extraperitoneal bladder rupture is not directly related to grade 3 splenic trauma and is usually managed conservatively with catheter drainage. Surgery is reserved for intraperitoneal rupture or severe complications.

Air in gallbladder (Pneumobilia) (Option D) indicates emphysematous cholecystitis, which may require surgery but is not as urgent as pneumoperitoneum, typically linked to a perforated organ and peritonitis.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased posterior tibial & dorasalis pedis pulsations
Loss of sensation over the foot
Pain on compression of the calf

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Loss of sensation over foot

 

Explanation:

The given image depicts a neurotrophic (diabetic) ulcer, where the loss of sensation in the foot is typically observed.

 

Clinical features of different ulcers are as follows:

 

 

Venous ulcer

Arterial ulcer

Neurotrophic ulcer

Pressure ulcer

Site

Gaiter’s area (area between malleolus and calf)

At distal ends of limbs, such as toes, feet and legs.

Over toe joints, under the heel, over malleoli, under the metatarsal head, etc

Seen over pressure points, most common are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, hee, malleolus, occiput, etc

Appearance

Vertically oval with a sloping edge and will not penetrate deep fascia.

Punched-out edges are seen in this type of ulcer.

Ulcers can be associated with gangrene and abscesses; osteomyelitis can be seen here.

Punched out ulcer with bone as a base.

Cause

Caused by ambulatory chronic venous hypertension due to varicose veins.

This occurs due to severe arterial insufficiency of digital and medium-sized arteries, leading to ischemia and tissue death in the region.

It is caused due to repeated trauma and ischemia due to microangiopathy in diabetic patients.

It is tissue necrosis and ulceration due to prolonged pressure on any part of the body.

Characteristics

It is initially painful, then chronically becomes painless.

It heals on rest and treatment but reforms again.

It is intensely painful, and distal pulses are not palpable, and associated with shiny skin, brittle nails and loss of hair over the region.

Numbness

Paresthesias

Burning or loss of sensation in the foot

Diabetes mellitus (also known as diabetic ulcer)

It is common in bedridden patients with head injuries, neurological deficits, and comatose and stroke-ridden patients.

Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations (Option A) suggest a vascular problem, such as peripheral artery disease, which affects blood flow to the feet. Neurotrophic ulcers are caused by nerve damage, not vascular issues.

 

Positive Trendelenburg sign (Option C) is a sign of hip or pelvic injury, indicating weakness in the gluteus medius muscle. It is unrelated to neurotrophic ulcers, which affect the feet due to nerve damage.

 

Pain on compression of cthe alf (Option D) is typically associated with compartment syndrome or deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which involves swelling or clot formation in the legs. Neurotrophic ulcers are linked to sensory loss from nerve damage, not pain from calf compression.

questions.text:
Which is the correct sequence for the correction of hypospadias?


	Urethroplasty
	Penile de-gloving
	Orthoplasty
	Glanuloplasty
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2,3,1,4

 

Explanation:

The correct sequence for the correction of Hypospadias is 2,3,1,4

  • Caused by failure of fusion of urethral folds- meatus in ventral aspect
  • Affects about 1 in 300 male live births, The most common congenital abnormality of the urethra.
  • Characterized by: Ectopic ventrally located urethral meatus, Ventral penile curvature (chordee), Incomplete dorsal hood prepuce.

 

Classification/Types:

  1. Glanular Hypospadias: Most common type
  2. Coronal Hypospadias
  3. Penile Hypospadias
  4. Penoscrotal Hypospadias
  5. Perineal Hypospadias
  6. Scrotal Hypospadias
  7. Distal penile Hypospadias

Hypospadias Repair Steps

De-gloving → Orthoplasty → Urethroplasty → Meatoplasty → Glanuloplasty → Penoplasty → Scrotoplasty

 

  • Degloving: Removal of the penile skin to expose the underlying structures. (Statement 2)
  • Orthoplasty: Correction of penile curvature and any associated penile shaft issues. This step involves mobilising and repositioning the urethral plate if necessary. (Statement 3)
  • Urethroplasty: Creation or reconstruction of the neourethra using tissue flaps or grafts to form a functional urethra. (Statement 1)
  • Providing vascularised coverage for the urethroplasty.
  • Glanuloplasty: Reconstruction of the glans penis, focusing on creating a normal appearance and aligning the meatus. (Statement 4)
  • Penoplasty: Reconstruction of the penile shaft to restore or enhance its normal appearance and function. This may involve skin flaps or grafts.
  • Scrotoplasty: Correction or reconstruction of the scrotum, which may be necessary if there are associated anomalies or for cosmetic reasons.

questions.text: Which of the following does not cause central cyanosis?
questions.solution:
Hypothermia refers to a decrease in core body temperature below the normal range. It occurs when the body temperature drops below 95 degrees Fahrenheit (35 degrees Celsius).

Hypothermia causes peripheral cyanosis.

Central cyanosis is seen due to decreased oxygen saturation or oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.

 

Methemoglobin (Option A) is oxidized hemoglobin due to nitrate exposure. This leads to a reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood and can result in central cyanosis.

 

A pulmonary arteriovenous fistula (Option B) is an abnormal connection between an artery and a vein in the lung. This can result in the bypassing of oxygenated blood from the lungs to the systemic circulation, leading to a decrease in arterial oxygen saturation and central cyanosis.


At high altitudes (Option C), the partial pressure of oxygen in the atmosphere is lower, resulting in hypobaric hypoxia. This can cause central cyanosis due to reduced oxygen availability.

questions.text:
A female patient was diagnosed with gastric cancer. On immunohistopathology, the biopsy sample was positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100. What is the diagnosis?

LCA - Leucocyte common antigen

GIST - Gastrointestinal stromal tumors

SCC - Squamous cell carcinoma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) GIST

 

Explanation:

The biopsy findings showing positive CD117 (also known as c-Kit) and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100 are characteristic of Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors (GISTs).

  • Common Locations:
    • Stomach (most common)
    • Small Intestine
    • Other Areas: Colon, rectum, and oesophagus (less common).
  • Origin: The Interstitial cells of Cajal (Gastric pacemaker cells)

  • Immunohistochemistry Markers for GISTs: (Option A)

 

Category

Marker

Expression in GISTs

Significance
 

Old Markers

CD117 (c-KIT)

Expressed in approximately 97% of GISTs

Crucial for diagnosis

CD34

Expressed in 70% GISTs

Associated with hematopoietic progenitor cells

SMA

Some GISTs show positivity

Less common compared to CD117 and CD34



 

New Markers

PDGFRA

Mutations found in approximately 5-10% of GISTs

Additional diagnostic marker

DOG1

Expressed in many GISTs, including those negative for CD117

Alternative diagnostic tool
  • Clinical features:
    • GI Bleed (most common)
    • Abdominal Pain
    • Weightloss
    • Large abdominal mass- it arises from the submucosa - hence, it is extraluminal- but expands and compresses the mucosa
    • Metastasis to liver
  • Carney’s Triad:

It is a rare syndrome characterised by the presence of three specific tumours: gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs), extra-adrenal paragangliomas, and pulmonary chondromas.

 

Adenocarcinoma (Option B) is a type of cancer that originates in epithelial cells and typically stains positive for cytokeratin, which is absent in this case. The absence of cytokeratin makes adenocarcinoma unlikely in this patient.

 

Hodgkin’s lymphoma (Option C) expresses LCA (Leucocyte Common Antigen), a marker for hematologic malignancies, especially lymphomas. Since the biopsy is negative for LCA, Hodgkin’s lymphoma can be excluded as a diagnosis.


SCC (Squamous Cell Carcinoma) (Option D) expresses cytokeratin, a marker for epithelial differentiation. Since the biopsy is negative for cytokeratin, SCC is unlikely.

questions.text: A female patient is planned for cholecystectomy. Which of the following is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery?

choices.text: Earlier return to normal physiological function
Longer duration of stay in hospital

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Longer duration of stay in hospital

 

Explanation:

Longer hospital stay is not an advantage of laparoscopic surgery.

 

Advantages of laproscopic surgery:

 

  • Less postoperative pain (Option A ruled out)
  • Better cosmesis (Option B ruled out)
  • Earlier return to normal physiology (Option C ruled out)
  • Shorter hospital stays (Option D)
  • Fewer intraoperative adhesions are created.
  • Better perception of anatomy as the image is often magnified.

questions.text: Which one of the following medications is not employed for the urgent (immediate) treatment of hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is not typically used for the immediate management of hyperkalemia. It may be used in certain situations, such as if the patient has concurrent magnesium deficiency, which can contribute to electrolyte imbalances. However, it is not the primary drug of choice for immediate intervention in hyperkalemia.

 

Calcium gluconate (Option A) is commonly used in the emergency management of hyperkalaemia. It helps stabilise the cardiac membrane and counteracts the effects of elevated potassium levels on the heart.

 

Salbutamol (Option B), a beta-2 agonist, is frequently used for the immediate management of hyperkalaemia. It promotes the cellular uptake of potassium, effectively lowering its concentration in the blood.

 

Insulin (Option C), often administered with dextrose, is a key component of emergency hyperkalaemia management. Insulin drives potassium from the bloodstream into the cells, reducing serum potassium levels.

questions.text: Severe, intractable pain in advanced rectum cancers is due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

Advanced cancers invading outside the mesorectum may infiltrate the prostate or bladder anteriorly or the sacral plexus posteriorly, giving rise to severe, intractable pain.

 

Clinical Features of Rectal Carcinoma:

  • Commonly seen in >55 years of age
  • Early Symptoms:
    • Bleeding per rectum: The most common early symptom, often bright red and painless, which can be mistaken for hemorrhoidal bleeding.
    • Tenesmus: It is an important early symptom. It is the feeling of incomplete evacuation, often present with lower rectal tumours, leading to frequent attempts to pass stool or gas.
    • Diarrhoea: Early morning diarrhoea may occur.
  • Late Symptoms:
    • Constipation can develop with rectosigmoid junction tumours.
    • Colicky pain may indicate obstruction and advanced cancers may cause severe pain due to invasion of nearby structures (prostate or bladder anteriorly or the sacral plexus posteriorly). (Option D)
    • Weight loss indicates metastatic disease.
  • Abdominal Examination Findings:
    • Early cases may be normall while obstructing tumours can show signs of subacute bowel obstruction.
    • Palpable liver enlargement may indicate liver metastases, and cachexia can be present.
    • Ascites may be found in cases of peritoneal spread.
  • Rectal Examination Findings:
    • The tumour is palpable within 7-8 cm of the anal verge, appearing as a raised, hard mass. If ulcerated, it may present as a depression with everted edges.
    • Mobility and distance from the anal sphincter complex are important for assessing resectability and surgical planning.

questions.text: A patient, who is a known case of HIV with a CD4 count of 200 cells/cu.mm, presents with 5 days of cough and high-grade fever without chills and rigors. There is no history of diarrhoea, vomiting, or nuchal rigidity. The chest x-ray is normal. What treatment will you give?
questions.solution:
Co-trimoxazole treatment is recommended for patients with HIV who present with symptoms of a respiratory tract infection and a CD4 count of less than 200 cells/cu.mm. Co-trimoxazole, a combination of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim, is commonly used in AIDS patients with cough due to its effectiveness against Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP). PJP is an opportunistic infection that affects individuals with weakened immune systems, such as those with advanced HIV/AIDS.

Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid + Azithromycin (Option A): This combination is typically used for community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), which often shows lobar infiltrates on chest X-ray. However, the normal chest X-ray and the high CD4 threshold for bacterial pneumonia make this less likely. Also, CAP typically presents with chills and rigors, which are absent here.

Amphotericin B (Option B): This is the drug of choice for disseminated fungal infections such as cryptococcal meningitis or visceral leishmaniasis. However, there is no evidence of cryptococcal infection (e.g., no headache, altered sensorium, or nuchal rigidity), and the patient’s symptoms are respiratory, not systemic.

Antitubercular treatment (ATT) (Option D): Tuberculosis (TB) is common in HIV patients, but it usually presents with chronic symptoms like prolonged cough, weight loss, night sweats, and upper lobe infiltrates on chest X-ray. The acute nature of the illness (5 days of symptoms) and normal chest X-ray make TB less likely.

Reference:

questions.text: Identify the conduction abnormality from the ECG given below?
questions.solution:
Given ECG shows progressive lengthening of PR intervals until a dropped beat occurs, which indicates Mobitz type I block. It can be further classified into two types:

  • Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach) - is characterized by a progressive prolongation of the PR interval until a beat is dropped
  • Mobitz Type II - involves intermittent blocked beats without progressive PR interval prolongation.

 

First-degree heart block (Option A) is characterized by a prolonged PR interval on the ECG. It indicates a delay in the electrical conduction between the atria and ventricles.

 

Ventricular tachycardia (Option B) is a rapid heart rhythm originating from the ventricles. On the ECG, it appears as a wide QRS complex with a heart rate exceeding 100 beats per minute.


Third-degree heart block (complete heart block) (Option C) is a severe conduction abnormality characterised by atrioventricular dissociation.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be indicated by the absence of loud S1 in mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (Option B)

Aortic regurgitation is unrelated to the production of the first heart sound (S1). Aortic regurgitation involves the leakage of blood back into the left ventricle during diastole, and it does not directly affect the closure of the mitral valve or the production of S1. Therefore, the absence of a loud S1 sound is not indicative of aortic regurgitation.

 

A calcified valve (Option A) in mitral stenosis can restrict the movement of the valve leaflets and result in a reduced or absent opening snap (OS), leading to a softer S1 sound. Therefore, the absence of a loud S1 sound is consistent with a calcified valve in mitral stenosis.

 

The intensity of the first heart sound (S1) is decreased in patients with first-degree heart block (Option C). Therefore, the absence of loud S1 is consistent with first degree heart block.

 

In mitral stenosis (Option D), the presence of a loud first heart sound (S1) is a characteristic finding. Therefore, the absence of a loud S1 sound would be inconsistent with mitral stenosis. A loud S1 is produced by mobile but stiff mitral leaflets unless the leaflets are substantially calcified. Since elevated left atrial pressure has maintained the leaflets' rather wide spacing, the loud S1 is mostly caused by increased leaflet excursion during closure.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with left-sided hemiparesis. Damage to which part of the internal capsule leads to this presentation?
questions.solution:
The posterior limb of the internal capsule contains the corticospinal tract, which is responsible for motor control of the limbs. Damage to this area can lead to contralateral hemiparesis, as seen in the patient's left-sided weakness.

 

Lacunar Strokes

Lacunar Syndrome

Location of Infarct

Supplying Vessel

Clinical Features

Pure Motor Hemiparesis

Posterior limb of internal capsule or basis pontis

Lenticulostriate arteries or paramedian pontine arteries

Face, arm, and leg weakness on one side without sensory, visual, or cognitive deficits

Pure Sensory Stroke

Ventral posterolateral nucleus of thalamus

Thalamogeniculate arteries

Hemisensory loss affecting face, arm, and leg without motor weakness

Ataxic Hemiparesis

Posterior limb of internal capsule or basis pontis

Lenticulostriate arteries or paramedian pontine arteries

Ipsilateral ataxia with contralateral pyramidal signs

Dysarthria-Clumsy Hand

Pons or internal capsule (genu)

Penetrating branches of basilar artery or lenticulostriate arteries

Dysarthria and dyspraxia of hand without significant weakness

 

Damage to the retrolentiform part (Option A) of the internal capsule would typically result in sensory deficits, such as loss of sensation or abnormal sensation, rather than hemiparesis.

 

Similar to the retrolentiform part, damage to the sublentiform part (Option B) of the internal capsule is more likely to produce sensory deficits rather than hemiparesis.

 

Damage to the anterior limb (Option C) of the internal capsule can cause a variety of symptoms, including contralateral weakness, but it usually affects the face more than the limbs.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the clinic with erythematous lesions over the exposed areas of the skin, like hands, arms, and chest. He also complains of arthralgia and breathlessness. Measuring which among the following antibodies will be useful in diagnosing the underlying conditions?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is systemic lupus erythematosus, and anti-dsDNA antibodies are specific to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), a chronic autoimmune disease.

 

These antibodies target double-stranded DNA and are found in a significant number of patients with SLE. Their presence is highly specific to SLE and is associated with lupus nephritis (kidney involvement) and other manifestations of the disease.

 

Autoantibodies of SLE

Antibodies

Antigen recognised

Clinical significance

ANA (Option D)

Multiple nuclear antigens

Best screening test for diagnosis, it is highly sensitive but not very specific for SLE.

Anti-dsDNA

DNA (double-stranded)

High titers are specific for SLE

Used to correlate with disease severity

Anti-C1q

Collagen-like determinants on C1q

Associated with active lupus nephritis, it is non-specific for SLE and can be used to correlate with disease activity. Deficiency predisposes SLE.

Anti-Sm

Protein complexes to 6 species of nuclear U1 RNA.

It is highly specific for SLE.

Anti-RNP

Protein complexed to U1 RNA

Non-specific to SLE and is associated with syndromes that overlap with rheumatic syndromes

Anti-Ro (SS-A)

Protein complexed to hY RNA 9 (primarily 60 kDa and 52 kDa)

Not very specific, it is associated with sicca syndrome and neonatal lupus (congenital heart block)

Anti-La (SS-B)

47-kDa protein complexed to hY RNA

Commonly associated with Anti-Ro antibody

Antihistone

(Option A)

Histones associated with DNA

Associated with drug-induced lupus.

Antiphospholipid

Phospholipids, β2-glycoprotein 1 cofactor, prothrombin

Usually predisposes to clotting, fetal loss and thrombocytopenia.

Anti Erythrocyte

Erythrocyte membrane

Causes autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

Antiplatelet

Surface and altered cytoplasmic antigens on platelets

It contributes to thrombocytopenia, is not very specific or sensitive, and is not used in regular practice.

Antineuronal antibody

Neuronal and lymphocyte surface antigens

Occasionally, it shows a positive correlation with active CNS lupus.

Anti Ribosomal P

Protein in ribosomes

Associated with neuropsychiatric manifestations.

 

Anticentromere antibodies (Option C) are associated with a distinct autoimmune disease called limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, also known as CREST syndrome. This condition primarily affects the skin, blood vessels, and internal organs.

questions.text: Where is the site of the lesion that leads to the occurrence of hemiballismus in a patient displaying forceful, flinging movements?
questions.solution:
Ballismus is a violent form of choreiform movement composed of wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements most frequently affecting proximal limb muscles on one side of the body (hemiballism). It is typically caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus (STN) of the basal ganglia.

Lesions in the putamen (Option A) are associated with chorea, not hemiballismus.

 

Lesions in the caudate nucleus (Option C) are associated with Huntington's disease, which causes chorea as well.

 

Lesions in the globus pallidus (Option D) can cause various movement disorders, such as dystonia or Parkinson's disease, but they are not specifically associated with hemiballismus.


 

Movement disorder

Lesions

Chorea

Lesions in the putamen

Dystonia

Lesions in the globus pallidus

Ballism/Hemiballismus

Lesion in subthalamic nucleus (STN)

Huntington’s Disease (HD)

Lesions in the caudate nucleus

Sydenham's chorea

Rheumatic heart disease

 

Condition

Description

Tremor

Rhythmic oscillation of a body part due to intermittent muscle contractions.

Dystonia

Involuntary, patterned, sustained, or repeated muscle contractions often associated with twisting movements and abnormal posture.

Athetosis

Slow, distal, writhing, involuntary movements with a propensity to affect the arms and hands (this represents a form of dystonia with increased mobility).

Chorea

Rapid, semipurposeful, graceful, dance like non patterned involuntary movements involving distal or proximal muscle groups. When the movements are of large amplitude and predominant proximal distribution, the term ballism is used.

Ballismus

Violent form of choreiform movement composed of wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements most frequently affecting proximal limb muscles on one side of the body

Myoclonus

Sudden, brief (<100 ms), jerklike, arrhythmic muscle twitches.

Tic

Brief, repeated, stereotyped muscle contractions that can often be suppressed for a short time. These can be simple and involve a single muscle group or complex and affect a range of motor activities.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in MEN 2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a characteristic feature of MEN 2B syndrome. It is a malignant tumor that arises from the C cells of the thyroid gland.

 

Explanation:

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) is a group of genetic syndromes (Autosomal Dominant) characterized by the development of tumors in multiple endocrine glands.

  • Diagnostic criteria for MEN is
    • Clinical features of 2 or more associated tumors
    • Notable Family history
    • Confirmation by genetic analysis.

 

Types of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia
 

MEN Type I

(Wermer’s syndrome)

MEN Type II

(Sipple’s syndrome)

MEN Type III

(MEN II B)

MEN Type IV

Cause

Defect of chr.11q13 causing MEN 1 gene mutation

Defect of chr.10 leading to mutation of RET gene

Variant of Type 2 MEN

Defect of chr.12 causing CDKN1B gene

Tumors

Included
  • Parathyroid adenoma (m/c)
  • Enteropancreatic adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma

 
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (m/c)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Parathyroid adenoma (Option C) (Calcium can be normal)
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (m/c)
  • Pheochromocytoma (high blood pressure)
  • Parathyroid adenoma (Presents as hypercalcemia)
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive tract tumors
    • Testicular tumors
    • Neuroendocrine tumor (Cervix)

Associated conditions
  • Angioﬁbroma
  • Collagenoma
  • Adrenocortical tumor
  • Carcinoid tumors/ Argentaﬃnoma
  • Pheochromocytoma (only in 1%)
  • Bronchopulmonary NET
  • Thymic NET
  • Gastric NET
  • Lipomas
  • Meningiomas
  • Congenital aganglionosis,
  • Hirschsprung disease
  • Marfanoid habitus
  • Medullated corneal nerve ﬁbers
  • Mucosal neuromas
  • Megacolon and Multiple diverticulae
  • Renal tumor
  • Adrenal tumor

 

Café au lait spots (Option A) are light brown patches on the skin and are commonly seen in conditions such as neurofibromatosis.

 

Optic nerve gliomas (Option D) are not typically associated with MEN 2B syndrome. They are more commonly seen in neurofibromatosis type 1.

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

 

West Syndrome

Age group

Typically occurs between 2 and 12 months of age.

Genetics

ARX Gene Mutations: In males, linked to ambiguous genitalia and cortical migration abnormalities.

Types
  • Cryptogenic (Unknown Etiology): Normal development before onset.
  • Symptomatic: Associated with developmental delays due to perinatal issues, brain malformations, metabolic disorders, or other causes.

Clinical Features
  • Infantile Epileptic Spasms: Clusters of spasms occurring mainly during drowsiness or upon waking.
  • Developmental Regression
  • Hypsarrhythmia on EEG: A chaotic, high-voltage background with multifocal spikes.

Management

First-Line Treatment: Hormonal therapy, primarily ACTH (80 mg/mL)

  • Dosage: 150 units/m² daily (75 units/m² twice daily) for 2 weeks, then taper gradually.
  • Monitoring: EEGs at 1, 2, and 4 weeks to assess response.
  • Early intervention is crucial, as a delay beyond 3 weeks can worsen the prognosis.

Alternative Treatments
  • Oral Prednisolone: Lower-cost alternative (Less effective)
  • Vigabatrin: Used as a first-line agent in West syndrome associated with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) or second-line if hormonal therapy fails. Side effects include retinal toxicity.
  • Ketogenic Diet: Considered a third-line therapy.
  • Other Medications: Valproate, benzodiazepines (nitrazepam, clonazepam), topiramate, lamotrigine, zonisamide, pyridoxine, and IVIG. These drugs can help reduce seizure frequency and severity but are not uniformly effective and may be used alongside ACTH or vigabatrin in cases with incomplete response.

Side Effects and Precautions
  • Side Effects of Hormonal Therapy: Hypertension, electrolyte imbalance, infections, hyperglycemia, and gastric ulcers.
  • Vaccination: Live vaccines are contraindicated, and other vaccines may be ineffective during and shortly after hormonal therapy.

 

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Option A) typically begins during adolescence and is characterized by morning myoclonic jerks, along with generalized tonic-clonic seizures and occasionally absence seizures. EEG findings include generalized 4-6 Hz spike-and-wave activity, often seen after waking. The most effective treatment is valproate, with alternatives such as levetiracetam, lamotrigine, or topiramate.

 

Rolandic epilepsy (Option B) is a common and self-limiting childhood epilepsy. Seizures occur during sleep or upon waking and involve facial twitching, drooling, or temporary difficulty speaking, without loss of consciousness. Symptoms resolve naturally by adolescence. Treatment options include carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine.

 

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (Option D) typically affects children aged 2-10 years and includes developmental delay, a variety of seizure types (e.g., tonic, atonic, atypical absence), and an EEG pattern showing slow spike-and-wave discharges. Treatment often involves a combination of drugs such as valproate, lamotrigine, clobazam, or topiramate.

questions.text:
Which of the following cyanotic heart diseases causes increased pulmonary blood flow?


	Ebstein anomaly
	Tetralogy of Fallot
	Transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
	Total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC)
questions.solution:
Cyanotic heart diseases with increased pulmonary blood flow are seen in transposition of the great arteries (TGA) and total anomalous pulmonary venous communication (TAPVC).

 

Pulmonary Blood Flow in Congenital Heart Diseases (CHD):

Decreased Pulmonary Blood Flow

(Normal Pulmonary Artery Pressure)

(with Pulmonary Artery Hypertension)

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) (2)

Persistent Truncus Arteriosus

Double Outlet Right Ventricle (DORV) with VSD and Pulmonary Stenosis (PS)

Tricuspid Atresia with VSD and PS

Tricuspid Atresia with Large VSD

Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD) with PS

Non-Obstructive Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) (4)

Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) with Congenitally Corrected Transposition (CCT) and PS

Single Ventricle with PS

Single Ventricle

Other Univentricular Hearts with PS

Other Univentricular Hearts with PAH

Ebstein's Anomaly (1)

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy was brought to the outpatient clinic with intentional tremors, and poor scholastic performance. His sister has similar complaints. On examination, hepatomegaly is seen. The eye finding is shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings of intentional tremors, poor scholastic performance, hepatomegaly, and the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eye point towards the diagnosis of Wilson's disease.

 

Wilson disease:

  • Also known as hepatolenticular degeneration, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by the abnormal accumulation of copper in the liver, brain, eyes, and other organs.
  • This results in elevated free copper levels, along with increased copper levels in the liver and urine, while serum ceruloplasmin levels are decreased.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Autosomal recessive (positive family history).
    • Mutation in ATP7B gene (copper transporting P-type adenosine triphosphatase (ATPase), present in chromosome 13 (13q14).
    • Decreased biliary copper excretion and diffuse accumulation of copper in the cytosol of hepatocytes.
    • Later, copper is redistributed to other tissues once the liver is saturated with copper.
  • Clinical features:
    • Liver: Asymptomatic hepatomegaly (with or without splenomegaly), subacute or chronic hepatitis, acute hepatic failure, and portal hypertension
    • Neurology: Intention tremor, dysarthria, rigid dystonia, Parkinsonism, choreiform movements, lack of motor coordination, deterioration in school performance, psychosis, or behavioral changes
    • Psychiatric manifestations: Depression, personality changes, anxiety, obsessive-compulsive behavior, or psychosis
    • Eye: KF (Kayser Fleischer) ring in Descemet membrane layer of cornea
    • Renal: Fanconi syndrome and renal failure
  • Diagnosis:
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin levels (<20 mg/dL)
    • Serum-free copper level >1.6 µmol/L
    • Urinary copper excretion (normally <40 µg/day) is increased to >100 µg/day
    • Liver biopsy (Gold standard): Hepatic copper content >250 µg/g dry weight of liver
  • Treatment:
    • Dietary intake of copper (Avoid liver, shellfish, nuts, and chocolate) should be restricted to <1 mg/day
    • Symptomatic patients: Copper-chelating agents
  • D-penicillamine
  • Triethylenetetramine dihydrochloride
  • Zinc impairs the gastrointestinal absorption of copper

 

Huntington's chorea (Option B) involves involuntary movements (chorea) and psychiatric symptoms due to a trinucleotide repeat disorder (CAG repeat), but it does not cause hepatomegaly or Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are specific to Wilson's disease.
 

Glutaric aciduria (Option C) is an autosomal recessive disorder presents early in life with hypotonia, hyperkinetic movements (dystonia, choreoathetosis), and seizures, but it does not cause hepatomegaly or Kayser-Fleischer rings like in Wilson's disease.
 

Hepatitis A (Option D) is caused by the fecal-oral route, leading to jaundice and flu-like symptoms (nausea, vomiting, mild fever), but it does not present with intentional tremors, poor scholastic performance, or Kayser-Fleischer rings, all of which are characteristic of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: Which alternative method can be used for the procedure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is height measurement in a child with a stadiometer. The alternative method for the procedure shown is arm span.

 

Ideally, height is measured using an infantometer in children <2 years of age, and a stadiometer is used in children >2 years of age.

In conditions such as scoliosis where a stadiometer cannot be used, alternatives such as arm span and upper segment to lower segment (US:LS) ratio are some of the reliable alternatives.

 

Arm span:

  • Measured on arms outstretched at 90 degrees to the body from the tip of the middle finger of one hand to the tip of the middle finger of the other hand.
  • Arm span is shorter than the length by 2.5 cm at birth, equals height at 11 years, and after that is slightly (usually, <1 cm) greater than height.

Head circumference (Option A) used to monitor the growth of the brain and skull in children up to 2 years of age. It is measured along the supraorbital ridge in the front and the occipital prominence at the back using a flexible tape. While it reflects brain growth, it does not provide an accurate estimation of height, making it unsuitable for this purpose.

Crown-rump length (Option C) is a prenatal measurement used during early pregnancy to assess fetal growth and estimate gestational age, typically from 6-8 weeks of gestation. This measurement is specific to fetuses and cannot be applied to children for height estimation.

Knee height (Option D) is used to estimate height in individuals who cannot stand, such as bedridden or wheelchair-bound adults. It involves measuring the distance from the sole of the foot to the femoral condyle.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache. He has a history of thorn prick injury a week back. What antibiotics would you give empirically to this child?
questions.solution:
The child's presentation of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache, along with a history of thorn prick injury, points towards a likely diagnosis of scarlet fever. Amoxicillin + clavulanate is the preferred empirical antibiotic as it provides effective coverage for Group A Streptococcus, the most common cause of scarlet fever.

Scarlet Fever

Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis is associated with a characteristic rash caused due to a pyrogenic exotoxin (erythrogenic toxin) produced by GAS in individuals lacking antitoxin antibodies.

Caused By

Group A Streptococcus (GAS)

Incidence and Virulence

Less common and less virulent now compared to the past, with incidence depending on toxin strains and the population immunity.

Clinical Features
  • Rash appears within 24-48 hours, starting around the neck and spreading to the trunk and extremities.
  • Rash is a diffuse, finely papular, erythematous eruption causing bright-red discoloration, which blanches on pressure.
  • Rash is accentuated in the creases of the elbow, axilla, and groin (Pastia lines) and gives the skin a goose-pimple appearance.
  • Erythematous cheeks with pallor around the mouth.
  • After 3-4 days, the rash fades, followed by desquamation starting on the face and progressing downward.
  • Desquamation may occur around fingernails, palms, and soles.
  • Tongue is coated with swollen papillae, which later give a "strawberry tongue" appearance after desquamation.
  • Pharyngitis.

Diagnosis
  • Classic scarlet fever is typically straightforward to diagnose.
  • A history of recent exposure to GAS is helpful.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying GAS in the pharynx.

Treatment

  • Antibiotic therapy should be started immediately.
  • Drug of choice: Penicillin or amoxicillin for 10 days.
  • Alternative for Penicillin Allergy: Oral cephalosporins, clindamycin, Macrolides (erythromycin, clarithromycin) for 10 days or azalide (azithromycin) for 5 days.
  • Injection: Benzathine penicillin G single dose intramuscular injection for those unlikely to complete oral therapy.

Complication

  • Suppurative Complications:
    • Cervical lymphadenitis
    • Peritonsillar abscess
    • Retropharyngeal abscess
    • Otitis media
    • Mastoiditis
    • Sinusitis
    • Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pneumonia
  • Nonsuppurative Complications:
    • Acute rheumatic fever
    • Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Image

questions.text:
An unconscious child is brought to the casualty. What is the correct sequence of the management?


	Assess breathing
	Assess pulse
	Assess response
	Start compressions
	Bag and mask ventilation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 3-1-2-4-5

 

Explanation:

 

This question follows the Paediatric Basic Life Support (BLS) algorithm. The correct sequence is as follows:

  1. Assess response (Option 3):

    • First, check if the child is responsive by tapping and shouting. If unresponsive, shout for help and proceed to airway and breathing assessment.

  2. Assess breathing (Option 1):

    • Open the airway using head-tilt chin-lift or jaw thrust and check for normal breathing for no more than 10 seconds.

  3. Assess pulse (Option 2):

    • Check the central pulse (carotid or femoral). If no pulse or pulse <60 bpm with signs of poor perfusion, start chest compressions.

  4. Start compressions (Option 4):

    • Begin high-quality CPR with a compression rate of 100–120/min and depth of 1/3rd chest diameter.

  5. Bag and mask ventilation (Option 5):

    • Provide ventilations using a bag-valve-mask (if trained and equipment is available) or continue with rescue breaths if no equipment.

 

Steps in Basic Life Support Skills:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the tape shown in the image?


	It is called Shelter's tape.
	It is used to assess severe acute malnutrition.
	Reading of 13.5 to 14.5 cm is considered undernourished.
	It is useful mainly for frontline field workers.
questions.solution:
The tape shown in the image is Shakir's tape, used to assess severe acute malnutrition, and is primarily useful for frontline field workers to quickly identify malnourished children.

 

Mid Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC)

Definition
  • MUAC is a vital measurement used primarily to assess the nutritional status of children aged 6 months to 5 years.
  • Quick and effective screening tool.
  • In infants under 6 months old, the Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) is not utilized as a measurement criterion. (G88)

Procedure
  • Ensure the child is standing straight with their left arm free of clothing. The arm should be bent at a right angle.
  • Measure the distance between the tip of the shoulder (acromion) and the tip of the elbow (olecranon). Mark the midpoint on the upper arm.
  • The child's arm should hang relaxed by their side, with the palm facing the thigh.
  • Use a MUAC tape to wrap around the marked midpoint of the arm. The tape should be snug but not tight enough to pinch the skin.
  • Record the measurement at the zero mark of the tape.

Shakir’s Tape

Shakir's tape (1) is a specific type of MUAC measuring tape designed for use in assessing malnutrition. (2)

Used by frontline field workers for nutritional screening of malnourished children. (4)

It is typically three colour-coded to facilitate easy interpretation of nutritional status. The tape is marked with different zones that correspond to various levels of malnutrition:

  • Red Zone: Indicates severe malnutrition (MUAC < 11.5 cm).
  • Yellow Zone: Indicates moderate malnutrition (MUAC between 11.5 cm and 12.5 cm).
  • Green Zone: Indicates healthy nutritional status (MUAC > 12.5 cm) (3)

 

SHAKIR’S TAPE

questions.text: A young man is brought to the hospital with high-grade fever and altered consciousness. On examination, the patient had neck rigidity and pain when bending the neck. A lumbar puncture was performed and it showed a WBC count of 1500 cells/µL, the majority being neutrophils, elevated pressure with protein of 120 mg/dL, and a glucose level of 70 mg/dL (blood glucose level - 300 mg/dL). How will you manage the index case?
questions.solution:
The young man’s presentation of high-grade fever, altered consciousness, neck rigidity, and lumbar puncture findings (elevated neutrophils, high protein, low glucose relative to blood glucose, and elevated pressure) is suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The first line of management involves the administration of a third-generation cephalosporin along with vancomycin for 10-14 days.

 

Bacterial meningitis in neonates and children

Common Causes by Age Group

Neonates

Pre-school Children

Older Children
  • Escherichia coli (gram-negative bacilli)
  • Group B streptococci
  • Listeria monocytogenes
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae

Clinical Features
  • Lethargy
  • Fever
  • Hypothermia
  • Seizure
  • Headache
  • Stiff neck
  • Irritability
  • Drowsiness
  • Vomiting

Diagnosis

Lumbar puncture (CSF analysis):

  • CSF Appearance: Cloudy or purulent
  • CSF Pressure: Elevated
  • WBC Count: Elevated (1000-5000 cells/µL)
  • Predominant Cells: Neutrophils
  • Protein: Elevated (>100 mg/dL)
  • Glucose: Low (<40 mg/dL or <40% of blood glucose)
  • Gram Stain: Positive for bacteria

Treatment
  • Immediate Management: Start with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover pathogens.
    • Third generation cephalosporins (Ceftriaxone) along with vancomycin x 10 to 14 days
  • Adjunctive Therapy: Inj. Dexamethasone started 1-2 hr before antibiotics and continued for 48 hrs - Prevents cytokine mediated CNS injury.
  • Supportive Care: Manage complications like raised intracranial pressure and seizures.

Prevention
  • Vaccines for H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae. No vaccine currently exists for group B meningococcal infections.
  • Chemoprophylaxis: Close contacts of individuals with meningococcal meningitis should receive prophylactic antibiotics like rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin or ceftriaxone to reduce the risk of secondary infections.
    • Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days
    • Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose
    • Azithromycin 500 mg single dose
    • Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose

Complications

Hearing loss (common with H. influenzae and S. pneumoniae), seizures, memory impairment, decreased intellectual function, hydrocephalus, sepsis, and risk of death

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What are the investigations to be done in this patient?


	High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)
	PT and APTT
	Bone marrow
	Peripheral blood smear
questions.solution:
The clinical features of progressive pallor and abdominal distension, along with a Mentzer index less than 13, point towards a diagnosis of thalassemia, and the investigations to be done include High-performance liquid chromatography and a peripheral blood smear.

 

Mentzer Index Calculation:

  • MCV (in fL) / RBC count (in millions per microliter).
  • Index Value:
    • > 13: Suggests iron deficiency anemia (IDA).
    • < 13: Indicates a higher likelihood of beta-thalassemia.

 

Beta thalassemia:

  • Results from mutations in the HBB gene on chromosome 11, which encodes the beta globin chains.
  • Humans have two beta globin genes, and mutations in one or both genes lead to different severities of beta-thalassemia.

Beta Thalassemias

Major (Transfusion-dependent)

Intermedia (Non-transfusion-dependent)

Minor (Trait or Carrier)

Genotype

Homozygous:

β⁰/β⁰

β⁰/β⁺

β⁺/β⁺

Variable:

β⁰/β⁺ or β⁺/β⁺ or β⁰/β or β⁺/β

Heterozygous:

β⁰/β or β⁺/β

Peripheral Smear


 

Severe microcytic anemia with target cells (Hb 3–4 g/dL)

Moderate microcytic anemia

Mild microcytic anemia

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis

HbA₂ (5% or more);

HbF (up to 95%); No HbA

HbA₂ (4% or more);

HbF (up to 50%)

HbA₂ (4% or more);

HbF (up to 5%)
  • β⁰: No beta-globin production
  • β⁺: Decreased beta-globin production

 

Feature

Beta Thalassemia Minor (Trait)

Beta Thalassemia Intermedia

Beta Thalassemia Major (Cooley's Anemia)

Genetic Mutation

One beta-globin gene mutated, and the other is functional

Both beta-globin genes mutated but allowed some beta-chain production

Both beta-globin genes are severely mutated or absent

Severity of Anemia

Mild, often asymptomatic

Moderate anaemia

Severe anaemia, evident early in life (usually within the first year)

Symptoms

Typically asymptomatic, with mild fatigue

Pallor, jaundice, delayed growth, bone deformities

Profound fatigue, failure to thrive, bone deformities, hepatosplenomegaly

Age of Onset

Usually diagnosed incidentally through routine blood tests

Variable; symptoms often arise in childhood

Symptoms present within the first year of life

Blood Transfusions

Rarely needed

Occasional transfusions, particularly during stress/illness

Regular, lifelong transfusions required

Iron Overload

Rare

May occur if frequent transfusions are given

Significant risk due to frequent transfusions; iron chelation therapy needed

Complications

None significant

Splenomegaly, growth delay, bone changes

Iron overload complications (heart, liver damage), severe growth issues

Hemoglobin Levels

Slightly reduced

Moderately reduced

Severely reduced (Hemoglobin levels often <7 g/dL without transfusions)

Hb Electrophoresis

Normal or slight increase in HbA2

Increased HbA2 and possibly HbF

Elevated HbF with very low or absent HbA

HPLC

Normal hemoglobin profile

Abnormal profile with increased HbA2 and/or HbF

Abnormal profile with high levels of HbF and very low HbA

questions.text:
How would you manage a child with status epilepticus?


	Airway and breathing
	IV Lorazepam
	Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone
	IV Fosphenytoin
questions.solution:
Management of status epilepticus includes securing airway and breathing, administering IV Lorazepam, followed by IV Fosphenytoin, and using Midazolam, Propofol, or Thiopentone for refractory cases.

Management of Status Epilepticus

Refractory status epilepsy

  • Refractory status epilepticus refers to status epilepticus that has not responded to treatment, typically despite the administration of at least two antiepileptic medications, such as a benzodiazepine and another agent.

questions.text:
A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use (24 units per day for the past 10 years) presents with seizures, altered mental status, auditory hallucinations, and secondary delusions. His last alcohol consumption was 2 days ago. What is the appropriate management for this patient?


	Diazepam
	Thiamine
	Naltrexone
	Flupenthixol depot injection
questions.solution:
• The symptoms suggest that the patient is suffering from delirium tremens, and the appropriate treatment includes benzodiazepines (diazepam) for withdrawal symptoms and thiamine to prevent neurological complications like Wernicke Encephalopathy or Korsakoff psychosis.
  • Delirium tremens is a severe withdrawal syndrome that occurs after sudden cessation of chronic alcohol consumption. It is characterized by confusion, agitation, hallucinations, autonomic hyperactivity and seizures.
  • Seizures can occur suddenly; about 1% may experience a single grand mal convulsion, typically on the second day of withdrawal.
  • Treatment of choice: Benzodiazepines.
  • Anticonvulsants are not more beneficial.

 

(Option C): Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing cravings, but it is not indicated in the acute withdrawal phase. It is more useful for maintaining abstinence once the patient has been stabilized and no longer requires acute management.

 

(Options A & B): Flupenthixol is an antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders, not alcohol withdrawal. Although the patient has auditory hallucinations and delusions, these are likely related to alcohol withdrawal, which should be treated with benzodiazepines.
