questions.text:
A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. Which of the following risks is increased in the newborn?


	Low APGAR score
	ADHD
	Persistent pulmonary hypertension
	Delayed developmental milestones
questions.solution:
• SSRI use in pregnancy has been associated with all the mentioned options.
  • Paroxetine has been linked to an increased risk of congenital heart defects when taken during the first trimester. It is classified as a Category D drug, making it the least safe option during pregnancy.

 

SSRIs in Pregnancy

Fetal outcomes
  • SSRIs generally do not increase the risk of major congenital malformations, except for paroxetine, which is associated with increased heart defect risks when taken during the first trimester.
  • Late pregnancy SSRI use can lead to Poor Neonatal Adaptation Syndrome (PNAS), which includes irritability, poor muscle tone, sleep problems, crying, irritability, hypoglycemia, and seizures.
  • Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension of the Newborn (PPHN) is a rare but serious risk.
  • Low APGAR score
  • There is an increased risk of ADHD and autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
  • Delayed Developmental Milestones

Maternal outcomes
  • It may impair platelet function and myometrial contractions, disrupting normal hemostasis and vasoconstriction, which can increase the risk of Postpartum hemorrhage.
  • They can influence serotonin levels and inhibit nitric oxide synthesis, leading to vascular changes that elevate the risk of pre-eclampsia.
  • SSRIs may worsen insulin resistance, increasing the risk of GDM during pregnancy.
  • Minimal amounts of SSRIs are present in breast milk, with no reported harmful effects in breastfed babies.

Safer SSRIs in Pregnancy
  • Citalopram,
  • Sertraline,
  • Escitalopram,
  • Fluoxetine.

questions.text: What is the observed condition in the image below, where a 10-year-old boy presents with muscle weakness in his lower limbs and a rash on his eyelids, with biopsy results indicating muscle inflammation?
questions.solution:
• Gottron’s papules are erythematous to violaceous plaques over the extensor surfaces of the knuckles, elbows, and knees.
  • They are characteristic of juvenile dermatomyositis (JDM), an autoimmune inflammatory myopathy.
  • The clinical triad includes proximal muscle weakness, heliotrope rash (violaceous rash on eyelids), and Gottron’s papules.
  • Muscle biopsy typically shows perivascular and perimysial inflammation with CD4+ T-cell infiltration.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with elevated muscle enzymes (CK, aldolase), electromyography, and MRI findings of myositis.
  • Treatment involves high-dose corticosteroids and immunosuppressants (methotrexate, IVIG).

Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM)

Feature

Description

Definition

Autoimmune inflammatory myopathy affecting muscles and skin in children

Age Group

Common in children aged 5–15 years

Muscle Weakness

Proximal muscle weakness (difficulty climbing stairs, getting up from a chair)

Skin Findings

Gottron’s papules (erythematous plaques over knuckles)

Heliotrope rash (violaceous periorbital rash)

Shawl/V-sign (rash over shoulders and chest)

Lab Findings

↑ CK, aldolase, ANA, anti-Mi-2, anti-Jo-1 antibodies

Diagnostic Tests

Muscle biopsy (perifascicular atrophy, inflammatory infiltrates), MRI, EMG

Treatment

Corticosteroids, methotrexate, IVIG

Mechanic Hands

Holster sign

Shawl sign (Option B) is incorrect because the Shawl sign is a macular erythematous rash over the shoulders, neck, and upper back, typically seen in Dermatomyositis (DM) but does not specifically describe the lesions over the hands.

Heliotrope rash (Option C) is incorrect because a heliotrope rash refers specifically to a purplish rash on the eyelids. While present in JDM, it is not the primary observation being asked in the question.

Scleroderma (Option D) is incorrect because scleroderma presents with skin thickening, tightness, and Raynaud’s phenomenon, not inflammatory myopathy with characteristic rashes like Gottron’s papules.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with the lesion given in the image below. He also mentions experiencing sensations like a spider crawling in the area of the lesion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The image shows a dermatomal distribution of grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, which is characteristic of Herpes zoster (shingles).
  • The patient reports paresthesia ("spider crawling sensation"), a common prodromal symptom due to viral reactivation affecting sensory nerves.
  • The lesion pattern is unilateral, consistent with reactivation of Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) from dorsal root ganglia.

Herpes Zoster:

Feature

Details

Etiology

Reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) from latency in sensory ganglia.

Risk Factors

Immunosuppression, aging (>50 years), stress, malignancy, chronic diseases (diabetes).

Clinical Features

Painful, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base along a single dermatome (usually thoracic, lumbar, or trigeminal).

Prodromal Symptoms

Burning, tingling, paresthesia ("spider crawling sensation"), fever, malaise before rash appears.

Complications

Postherpetic neuralgia (PHN), bacterial superinfection, ophthalmic zoster (if V1 of trigeminal nerve is involved).

Diagnosis

Clinical; Tzanck smear (multinucleated giant cells), PCR for VZV in doubtful cases.

Treatment

Antiviral therapy (acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir) within 72 hours, analgesics, corticosteroids (if severe pain).

Prevention

Zoster vaccine for elderly and immunocompromised individuals.

 

Irritant contact dermatitis (Option B) is incorrect because it results from direct skin damage due to chemical exposure, leading to erythema, scaling, and burning, rather than a vesicular dermatomal rash with neuropathic pain.

 

Allergic contact dermatitis (Option C) is incorrect because it is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction (Type IV), presenting as itchy, erythematous, and vesicular plaques in areas of contact, but lacks dermatomal distribution and prodromal neuralgia.

 

Herpes simplex infection (Option D) is incorrect because HSV causes grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, but these typically appear around the mouth (HSV-1) or genital region (HSV-2) and do not follow a dermatomal pattern.

questions.text:
Which of the following factors is responsible for non-scarring alopecia in patients?

1. Alopecia areata

2. Telogen effluvium

3. Androgenic alopecia

4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
• Non-scarring alopecia refers to hair loss without permanent follicular destruction, meaning hair regrowth is possible.
  • Alopecia areata (immune-mediated hair follicle attack), Telogen effluvium (stress-induced shedding), and Androgenic alopecia (genetic hair thinning) are all non-scarring causes.
  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia (FFA) is a scarring alopecia, meaning it causes permanent hair loss with fibrosis.

Non-Scarring vs. Scarring Alopecia:

Feature

Non-Scarring Alopecia

Scarring Alopecia

Pathophysiology

Hair follicles remain intact; regrowth is possible.

Follicular destruction with fibrosis; irreversible loss.

Examples

Alopecia areata (autoimmune)

Telogen effluvium (stress-related shedding)

Androgenic alopecia (hormonal, genetic)

Frontal fibrosing alopecia (FFA) (lichen planopilaris variant) (Option 4 ruled out)

Lupus erythematosus

Folliculitis decalvans

Clinical Findings

Smooth scalp, no scarring

Can have exclamation mark hairs (alopecia areata)

Inflammation, erythema, follicular plugging

Scalp atrophy or fibrosis

Prognosis

Usually reversible

Permanent hair loss

Treatment

Alopecia areata: Intralesional steroids, JAK inhibitors

Telogen effluvium: Treat underlying cause

Androgenic alopecia: Minoxidil, finasteride

Frontal fibrosing alopecia: Immunosuppressants, topical corticosteroids

questions.text:
Vaccination against which of the following is recommended in the elderly?

1. Varicella zoster virus

2. Rota virus

3. Influenza vaccine

4. Pneumococcal Meningitis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, and 4

 

Explanation:

Vaccination against varicella zoster virus is recommended as latent VZV Infection can reactivate as herpes zoster or shingles.

  • As age advances, cell-mediated immune responses (CMI) to VZV decline, with resultant increased incidence of reactivation as herpes zoster among older people.
  • The Influenza vaccine is highly recommended in the elderly to prevent severe disease.
  • Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPV) is given to people aged 65 and over. It helps prevent meningitis and other illnesses caused by 23 strains of pneumococcal bacteria

 

Vaccination recommended in elderly are:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine
  • Influenza vaccine
  • Varicella zoster vaccine
  • Covid 19 vaccine
  • Td vaccine

questions.text: Which of the following agents can be used as a disinfectant but not as a sanitizer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hydrogen Peroxide

 

Explanation:

Hydrogen peroxide is a powerful disinfectant. H,02 works by producing destructive hydroxyl free radicals that can attack various cell components.

  • Hydrogen peroxide is an effective disinfectant for inanimate objects and surfaces, but on animal surface it produces skin irritation, vapors may irritate the eyes and mucous membranes.
  • Hence, it is not used as a sanitizer.

 

Disinfectant:

  • A product used to kill microorganisms on inanimate objects or surfaces.
  • Examples: Alcohols, chlorine and chlorine compounds, formaldehyde, glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde, hydrogen peroxide, iodophors, peracetic acid, phenolics, and quaternary ammonium compounds.

 

Sanitizer:

  • A product used to kill microorganisms on living tissue
  • Examples: 60 and 95% alcohol, usually in the form of ethanol, isopropanol, or n-propanol.

questions.text: On Cold Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) staining, oocysts of size 8-10 um cysts are visible. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cyclospora

 

Explanation:

This Cold ZN staining reveals the presence of 4 cyclospora round oocyst-bearing sporozoites of size 8-10 um, showing variability in staining in the field.

  • Cyclosporiasis is a disease caused by Cyclospora cayetanensis, transmitted by feces or feces-contaminated food and water

 

Cryptosporidium

Infective form

Sporulated oocyst in contaminated water

Clinical features

  • In Immunocompetent patients: Self-limited watery diarrhoea.
  • In Immunocompromised patients: Chronic persistent watery diarrhoea.

Microscopy

  • Appearance: Acid-fast, round oocyst
  • Size: 4–6 microns
  • Contents: Each oocyst contains four sporozoites
  • Types of oocyst:
    • Thick-walled - excreted out from host in faeces.
    • Thin-walled - involved in autoinfection.


 

 

Isospora

Cyclospora

Sarcocystis

Infective form

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Clinical features

  • Mild fever with diarrhoea
  • Can cause chronic diarrhoea in the immunocompromised host
  • Formation of sarcocysts within the muscle fibres (Muscular sarcocystosis)
  • Nausea, abdominal pain and diarrhoea (Intestinal sarcocystosis)

Microscopy

Oocyte is oval, acid-fast, 24-36 microns and autofluorescent, containing 8 sporozoites.

Oocyte is round, acid variable, 8-10 microns and autofluorescent, containing 2 - 2 sporozoites in each wheel.

Sarcocysts are present between the muscle fibres; each cyst has numerous merozoites.


 

Pathogens causing diarrhoea in HIV-positive patients

Parasites

Cryptosporidium parvum (Most common)

Isospora belli

Cyclospora

Giardia lamblia

Entamoeba histolytica

Microsporidia spp

Bacteria

Shigella species (Most common)

Salmonella species

Campylobacter jejuni

Viruses

Cytomegalovirus

Adenovirus

Fungi

Histoplasma

Candida

questions.text: Identify the pathognomic structure given in the slide below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sclerotic Body

 

Explanation:

This is a micrograph of chromoblastomycosis caused by Phialophora verrucosa and Fonsecaea pedrosoi, showing the sclerotic bodies aka copper penny bodies, or muriform bodies.

  • The fungi produce thick-walled, single, or multicellular clusters called sclerotic or muriform bodies. There is remarkable pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia of the epidermis.

 

Chromoblastomycosis (Also known as verrucous dermatitis)

Epidemiology

It is the most common form of chromomycosis.

Common among barefoot agricultural workers and woodcutters.

Tropical region.

Causative agents

Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Fonsecaea compacta, Exophiala dermatitidis, Phialophora, Cladophialophora.

Route of transmission

Infecting fungi enter the skin by traumatic implantation.

Clinical manifestation

Warty, cutaneous nodular lesions (resemble the florets of cauliflower).

Usually confined to subcutaneous tissue of the feet and lower legs

Slow-developing lesions around the site of implantation.

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy: The lesions show the presence of the fungus as round or irregular, dark brown, yeast-like bodies with septate, called sclerotic bodies (other names: muriform bodies, copper pennies, medlar bodies).

Demonstration of these sclerotic bodies in KOH mounts or tissue sections, and by culture on Sabouraud agar.

Treatment

Medical: Amphotericin B, thiabendazole, 5-fluoro cytosine, itraconazole and (new drug) voriconazole.

Surgical excision.

questions.text:
Which of the following pairs of diseases and their corresponding populations related to parvovirus is incorrect?

1. Aplastic crises in sickle cell disease

2. Viral envelop - Naked virus

3. Erythema infectiosum - infants

4. Non-erosive arthritis - Patients of SLE
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 4


 

Explanation:

leading to the characteristic rash.

 

Clinical Manifestations of Parvovirus infections:


 
  • Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
    • Children: "Slapped cheek" facial rash.
    • Adult women: Symmetrical polyarthropathy, often in hand and knee joints.
  • Transient Aplastic Crisis:
    • Severe acute anemia in patients with pre-existing hemolytic anemia.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia:
    • Chronic anemia in immunocompromised individuals due to persistent B19 infection.
  • Non-Immune Hydrops Fetalis:
    • Fatal fetal anemia and death; occurs via transplacental transmission (30% of cases)
    • Highest risk in the second trimester.
  • Papular-Purpuric Gloves and Socks Syndrome:
    • Painful, itchy, and symmetric swelling and erythema of distal hands and feet; may mimic acute meningococcemia.

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • PCR: Highly sensitive, detects viral DNA (VP1, VP2 genes) in serum, tissue, or respiratory secretions.
  • ELISA: Detects IgM antibody (early indicator, elevated 2–3 months) and IgG against VP1 and VP2 antigens.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Detects viral antigens in fetal tissues and bone marrow.
  • Bone marrow cytology shows Giant pro-erythroblasts with multiple cytoplasmic projections that look like "dog ears" or "pseudopodia".

questions.text: Which of the following is a gram-positive organism that shows the following appearance on Ziehl-Neelsen staining?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nocardia

 

Explanation:

The gram-positive organism on Ziehl-Neelsen staining, as shown in the image, is of Nocardia.

  • It is seen as branching filamentous rods with a beaded appearance on modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining as shown in the image. Nocardia is decolorised using 1% acid alcohol.
  • Nocardia are weakly acid-fast following staining with the modified Ziehl-Neelsen.

  • Found as oral flora
  • Infections occur endogenously
  • The usual habitat is the soil
  • Infections occur exogenously

Usually only in immunocompromised

Cervicofascial, abdominal, and others.

Pulmonary, CNS forms, Actinomycetoma

Sulfur granules are hard and not emulsifiable, consist of branching filamentous bacilli, and are surrounded by clubs (sun-ray appearance)

questions.text: The image below shows the structure of a virus, which of the following proteins act as oncogenes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) E6, E7

 

Explanation:

HPV has two oncoproteins, E6 and E7, which are responsible for the development of HPV-induced carcinogenesis.

  • E6 will inactivate p53, and E7 will inactivate the RB gene, which leads to cancer.
  • They act as oncogenes.

questions.text: If a patient's plasma contains elevated levels of interferon beta, it is indicative of a probable infection caused by-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Virus

 

Explanation:

Interferon beta (IFN-β) is produced by fibroblasts in response to viral infections, particularly when the body detects the presence of viral RNA or other viral components. Elevated levels of IFN-β are typically indicative of a viral infection because it plays a role in the innate immune response, helping to limit viral replication.

Interferons (IFNs):

  • Types:
    • IFN-α: Produced by macrophages, has antiviral action.
    • IFN-β: Produced by fibroblasts, also has antiviral action.
    • IFN-γ: Produced by T helper cells, does not have antiviral action but plays a role in cell-mediated immunity (CMI).
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • IFNs do not directly act on viruses but stimulate host cells to produce proteins that inhibit protein synthesis and viral replication.
  • Innate Immunity:
    • IFNs are part of innate immunity, nonspecific, and produced quickly after infection (within hours).
    • Unlike antibodies, they don’t have immunological memory.
  • Inducers:
    • IFN production is triggered by agents like RNA viruses (e.g., togaviruses, vesicular stomatitis virus), double-stranded RNA, bacterial endotoxin, and synthetic polymers.
  • Preparations:
    • Human IFNs: Prepared via DNA recombinant technology.
    • Pegylated IFNs: IFN-α linked to polyethylene glycol, resulting in slower absorption, decreased clearance, and more sustained serum levels. Administered once a week.
  • Clinical Applications:
    • Topical: Used for rhinovirus infections, genital warts, and herpetic keratitis.
    • Systemic: Used for chronic hepatitis B, C, and D infections.
    • Antiproliferative Action: Used to treat cancers (e.g., hairy cell leukemia, Kaposi’s sarcoma) and autoimmune diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis).

 

Bacteria (Option B), Fungi (Option C), and Mycoplasma (Option D): While infections caused by these pathogens may also trigger immune responses, they typically don't induce the production of interferon beta in the same way viruses do. Instead, bacterial infections often activate other components of the immune system, such as neutrophils and macrophages, and induce the release of cytokines like interleukin-1 or tumor necrosis factor (TNF), rather than IFN-β.

questions.text: Petechial rash is seen in all of the following, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Roseola infantum

 

Explanation:

Roseola infantum/Sixth disease/exanthem subitum is caused by herpes virus 6.

  • It is characterized by fever and characteristic nagayama spots,
  • Nagayama spots: Erythematous, rose pink, non-pruritic papules after fever.

 

  • The child's sudden high fever, followed by a rose-coloured maculopapular rash, indicates roseola infantum, primarily caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6). While HHV-6 causes the condition, HHV-7 is related and can cause similar illnesses.
  • HHV-6 shows some antigenic cross-reactivity with HHV-7, and both bind to T-cells via CD46
  • HHV-6 has 2 variants, i.e. A and B.
  • Both HHV 6 & 7 spreads through saliva.

Conditions caused

HHV 6
  • In children: Sixth disease/ Roseola/ Exanthem Subitum (sudden high fever followed by a distinctive rash)
  • In adults: Infectious mononucleosis-like symptoms and focal encephalitis
  • In Immunodeficient - Pneumonia and Disseminated disease.

HHV 7

Causes Sixth disease/ Roseola/ Exanthem Subitum in children

questions.text: Which of the following is the false statement regarding statins?

choices.text: Although HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors substantially reduce the risk of cardiovascular events, there is a mild increase in lipoprotein a (Lpa) levels.
These drugs should not be stopped even in severe conditions like injury, surgery etc.
They can be given with verapamil and other enzyme inhibitors
With long-term use, there is a slight increase in the incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.solution:
• Statins are a class of drugs that lower cholesterol levels by inhibiting the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, which is responsible for the synthesis of cholesterol in the liver.
  • They are widely used to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events such as heart attack and stroke.
  • Statins should not be given with verapamil, as it is a cytochrome 3A4 enzyme inhibitor that can increase the levels of statins in the blood, leading to increasing risk of myopathy.

Although HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors substantially reduce the risk of cardiovascular events, there is a mild increase in lipoprotein a (Lpa) levels (Option A): It is a true statement regarding statins. It is well established that statins substantially reduce the risk of cardiovascular events. However, there are a mild increase in lipoprotein (Lpa) levels, which is a risk factor for cardiovascular disease.

These drugs should not be stopped even in severe conditions like injury, surgery etc (Option B): Statins should not be stopped abruptly, even in severe conditions such as injury or surgery, as it can increase the risk of cardiovascular events.

With long-term use, there is a slight increase in the incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus (Option C): Long-term use of statins has been associated with a slight increase in the risk of developing type 2 diabetes mellitus. This risk is modest and primarily affects those who are already at risk (e.g., people with metabolic syndrome or prediabetes). The cardiovascular benefits of statins, however, far outweigh this small increase in diabetes risk.

questions.text: A young man sustained a scorpion sting 2 hours ago. On examination, his blood pressure is 168/100 mm Hg; HR, 72 beats/minute and respiratory rate, 32 breaths/ minute. He also complains of breathlessness. How do you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
• Prazosin is an alpha-1 blocker that can reduce blood pressure by causing vasodilation and stabilized blood pressure.
  • It is commonly used in the management of scorpion sting-induced hypertension and pulmonary edema, as it helps to reduce vascular resistance, lower blood pressure, and improve tissue perfusion.
  • It is a useful choice for managing hypertension and potential pulmonary edema in this patient.

 

Metoprolol (Option A) is a beta blocker, which, by blocking beta receptors, can fail to address the underlying cause of hypertension (which is largely driven by alpha-adrenergic stimulation), and this may lead to poor blood pressure control or even worsening of hypertension.

 

Ivabradine (Option B) is an If-channel inhibitor used mainly for heart rate control in conditions like chronic heart failure or angina, but it's not effective for managing blood pressure or respiratory distress.

 

Furosemide (Option D) is a loop diuretic that helps reduce fluid volume and can lower blood pressure. However, they don't directly counteract the underlying causes of hypertension (such as sympathetic overstimulation in scorpion stings) or improve respiratory distress related to bronchoconstriction.

questions.text:
Match the following drugs in Column A with their contraindications in Column B.


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			
				Morphine
				Amiodarone
				Vigabatrin
				Estrogen preparations
			
			
			
			
				QT prolongation
				Thromboembolism
				Pregnancy
				Haad injury
questions.solution:
Correct match of contraindications:

A. Morphine → 4. Head injury: morphine and other opioids depress the respiratory system. This effect can worsen intracranial pressure (ICP), which is a significant concern in patients with head injuries.

B. Amiodarone → 1. QT prolongation: Prolongs QT interval, potentially leading to arrhythmias like Torsades de pointes.

C. Vigabatrin → 3. Pregnancy: Vigabatrin is contraindicated in pregnancy as it increases the risk of fetal malformations.

D. Estrogen preparations → 2. Thromboembolism: Estrogen can increase the coagulability of the blood, leading to a higher risk of clot formation. This risk is particularly significant in individuals who are already at risk for thromboembolic events hence it is contraindicated.

questions.text: Identify the pattern of abrasion shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ligature mark

 

Explanation

 

  • A ligature mark is pressure abrasion caused by the application of a constricting force using a cord-like object (e.g., rope, wire) around the neck.
  • It is commonly observed in cases of hanging or strangulation.
  • Characteristics include a continuous or interrupted band-like mark, which may show the texture or pattern of the ligature material.
  • The location and orientation of the mark can help distinguish hanging from manual strangulation.



 

Pressure abrasion (Option A): Caused by sustained pressure of a blunt object against the skin.

 

Graze abrasion (Option B): Occurs when the skin is scraped against a rough surface.

 

Imprint abrasion (Option D): A patterned abrasion caused when a textured object presses into the skin, leaving a distinct impression.

 

Learning Objective:

 

Postmortem Abrasion Vs Antemortem Abrasion

 

Feature

Postmortem Abrasion

Antemortem Abrasion

Image

Intra-vital reaction or congestion

Absent

Present

Site

Typically found on bony prominences

Can occur on any part of the body

Color of abrasion

Yellowish-white or pale

Reddish-brown to dark brown

Scab formation

Absent or minimal

Present and well-formed

Exudates

Less or absent

Increased (due to inflammatory reaction)

Elevation (Scab)

More raised due to active healing

Bleeding/ Color changes

No active bleeding

Active bleeding with clot formation

No healing process

Healing starts with inflammation

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency room after poisoning with an unknown substance. Muscarinic poisoning was suspected, and he was treated for the same. What is the possible presenting feature that led to the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The most likely presenting feature of muscarinic poisoning in this scenario is bradycardia, which occurs due to the parasympathetic stimulation of the heart's muscarinic receptors.
  • The most common causes of muscarinic poisoning are organophosphate insecticides, carbamate insecticides or nerve agents, which inhibit acetylcholinesteras.e
  • Muscarinic receptors are a type of acetylcholine receptor that are found in various organs of the body, including the heart, lungs, and digestive system.
  • Muscarinic poisoning leads to the accumulation of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft, which can cause excessive stimulation of muscarinic receptors.
  • Manifestations of Muscarinic poisoning (DUMBBELSS) :
  1. D-Diarrhea
  2. U-Urination
  3. M-Miosis
  4. B-Bronchospasms, bronchorrhea, bradycardia
  5. E-Excitation, Emesis
  6. L-Lacrimation
  7. S-Salivation, sweating

 

Mydriasis (Option A) is typically seen in sympathomimetic toxicity or anticholinergic poisoning, not muscarinic poisoning. In muscarinic poisoning (parasympathetic nervous system), the pupils typically constrict (miosis).

 

Diuresis (Option B) is not typically associated with muscarinic poisoning. However, it generally leads to symptoms like increased salivation and sweating, rather than diuresis.

 

Muscle fasciculations (Option C) can occur in cases of acetylcholinesterase inhibitor poisoning, but they are not specific to muscarinic receptors and can also be seen with nicotinic receptor activation.

questions.text: Identify the postmortem change given in the following image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Marbling

 

Explanation

  • Marbling is a postmortem change characterized by a branching, vein-like pattern on the skin due to the breakdown of hemoglobin and bacterial proliferation (e.g., Clostridium welchii) within blood vessels.
  • The discoloration results from the conversion of hemoglobin to sulfhemoglobin, producing a greenish-black appearance.
  • Starts at 24 hours, visible between 36-48 hours.
  • Helps in determining time since death.


 

Tattooing (Option B):

  • Tattooing refers to the deposition of gunpowder particles on the skin during close-range firearm discharge.
  • It appears as punctate abrasions and is unrelated to postmortem decomposition.

Lividity (Option C):

  • Lividity, or postmortem hypostasis, is the pooling of blood in dependent areas of the body after death.
  • It results in a purplish-red discoloration, but it lacks the branching pattern seen in marbling.

Filigree burns (Option D):

  • Filigree burns occur when an electrical current flows through the skin, creating a pattern that resembles lace or a branching network.
  • It is a premortem finding, not a decomposition change.


 

Learning Objective:

 

Putrefaction

  • Stimulated by bacterial activity (primarily Clostridium welchii or Clostridium perfringens).
  • Three stages of change:
    • Color change .
    • Gas formation (producing bloating and distention).
    • Liquefaction of tissues (softening and breakdown of tissues).
  • Color changes:
    • Green discoloration in the right iliac fossa due to hydrogen sulfide produced by bacteria.
    • Starts in 12-18 hours in summer and 1-2 days in winter.
  • Putrefaction sequence:
    • Non-gravid uterus is the last organ to decompose in females.
    • Prostrate is the last organ to decompose in males.

  • Factors inhibiting Putrefaction ( Mnemonic CMS ):
    • Strychinine
    • Metallic poison ( Arsenic,Antimony,Thallium )
    • CO , Cyanide & Carbolic acid.

 

Post-mortem luminescence:

  • Emission of light from the body due to bacterial or fungal activity (e.g., Photobacteria and Armillaria).

questions.text: Hooch tragedy is related to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Methanol

 

Explanation

  • A "hooch tragedy" refers to incidents of poisoning caused by the consumption of illicit or adulterated alcohol.
  • Methanol, a toxic alcohol, is often found in illegally brewed liquor as a contaminant.
  • Ingesting methanol leads to metabolic acidosis, blindness, and potentially fatal outcomes due to its toxic metabolites, formaldehyde and formic acid.

 

Phosphorus (Option A): Phosphorus poisoning typically occurs due to ingestion of rodenticides or fireworks, causing severe gastrointestinal and hepatic damage. It is not related to hooch tragedies.

 

Mercury (Option B): Mercury poisoning occurs due to exposure to mercury compounds, causing neurological and renal toxicity. It is unrelated to alcohol adulteration.

 

Ethanol (Option C): Ethanol is the active ingredient in alcoholic beverages and is generally not the cause of toxicity in hooch tragedies. The issue "hooch tragedy" occurred when ethanol was adulterated with methanol.

questions.text: 'A' kills 'B' with a knife. Another person 'Z' saw 'A' with a knife in the park a few minutes before the murder. 'Z' gives this statement in a court of law. What kind of evidence is it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Indirect

 

Explanation

  • Indirect evidence, also known as circumstantial evidence, does not directly prove the fact in question but supports it through inference.
  • In this case, 'Z' saw 'A' with a knife shortly before the murder, which does not directly prove that 'A' killed 'B', but it is a relevant circumstance that can be linked to the crime.

Types of Evidences

Feature

Documentary Evidence

Oral Evidence

Expert Evidence

Definition

Written or printed documents produced for court inspection

Statements made before the court by witnesses

Opinion from a person specially skilled in the relevant field

Legal Admissibility

Admissible as primary evidence

Admissible; allows cross-examination

Admissible under specific conditions (Sec. 39, BSA)

Reliability

High, if properly maintained

Can vary; subject to witness credibility

High, if from a qualified expert

Specific Medical Examples

Medical certificates, hospital records, lab reports

Doctor's testimony, nurse's account of patient care

Medical examiner's report, specialist's opinion on treatment

Circumstantial evidence or indirect evidence: It is the evidence consisting of collateral facts from which an inference may be drawn and are consistent with the direct evidence, such as finding blood on the clothes of the accused.

Direct (Option A): Direct evidence provides immediate proof of a fact, such as an eyewitness seeing the murder occur. Here, 'Z' did not witness the murder itself, so the evidence is not direct.

 

Hostile (Option C): A witness becomes hostile when they deviate from their original statement or intentionally withhold information to favor the accused. There is no indication that 'Z' was hostile in this case.

 

Hearsay evidence (Option D):

  • Any evidence that is offered by a witness of which he/she does not have direct knowledge but his/her testimony is based on what others have said. For example, a relative overhearing a conversation between doctors discussing a possible misdiagnosis.
  • Since 'Z' personally saw 'A' with the knife, this is not hearsay.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and was started on first-time antitubercular drugs. Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the synthesis of the marked layer shown in the image?
questions.solution:
• The marked layer in the image is the mycolic acid layer, which is a characteristic feature of the cell wall of Mycobacterium species.
  • Isoniazid is a first-line antitubercular drug that is commonly used in the treatment of TB. It works by targeting the synthesis of mycolic acids.
  • Isoniazid inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acids by targeting the enzyme enoyl-ACP reductase, which is involved in the synthesis of long-chain fatty acids.
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, isoniazid disrupts the synthesis of mycolic acids, leading to the loss of structural integrity and permeability barrier of the mycobacterial cell wall. This, in turn, leads to the death of the bacterial cell.

questions.text: A lady who had undergone mastectomy for breast cancer is being treated with tamoxifen. How long should it be stopped before she can conceive?

choices.text: Can be stopped and conceived soon after stopping

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 3 months

Explanation:

  • Tamoxifen is a selective serotonin receptor inhibitor used in breast cancer. According to the American Association of Clinical Oncology, a woman taking tamoxifen has to discontinue the drug 3 months before planning to conceive.
  • Tamoxifen is contraindicated during pregnancy due to its potential teratogenic effects; it should be stopped 3 months after attempting to conceive to allow it to be sufficiently cleared from the body. (Option A, C, D ruled out)

questions.text: A male patient presented with a history of consuming an unknown substance. He exhibited increased sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, and bradycardia. What is management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Atropine

 

Explanation

  • The symptoms described—sweating, lacrimation, diarrhea, and bradycardia—are consistent with cholinergic toxicity, commonly caused by organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.
  • Atropine is the first-line treatment for cholinergic toxicity. It is a muscarinic receptor antagonist that counteracts the effects of excessive acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors, reducing secretions, bradycardia, and other parasympathetic symptoms.

 

Symptoms

Muscarinic: Lethargy, Salivation, Diarrhea, Lacrimation, Urination, Miosis, Muscle weakness, Bronchorrhea, Bronchospasm, Bradycardia, Emesis (Mnemonic: DUMBBELLS)

Nicotinic: Muscle weakness, Fasciculation, Areflexia, Muscle paralysis

CNS: Headache, Tremor, Confusion, Slurred speech, Coma, Convulsion

Laboratory Diagnosis
  • RBC/True Cholinesterase (specific)
  • Plasma/Pseudocholinesterase (Most common)
    • Falls rapidly with organophosphorus poisoning
    • Inexpensive, sensitive)
  • Atropine test: If 2 mg of Atropine relieves symptoms, it confirms OP poisoning
  • P-nitro phenol test for confirmation.

Management
  • Resuscitative measures (Airway-Breathing-Circulation)
  • Decontamination
  • Gastric lavage with 1:5000 KMnO4
  • Activated charcoal
  • Atropine sulfate (2-4 mg IV every 10-15 minutes until atropinization)
  • Signs of atropinization: Heart rate>80 beats/min, pupils no longer pinpoint, clear chest on auscultation with no wheeze, systolic BP>80mmHg, Dry axillae
  • Oximes (Pralidoxime) to decrease muscarinic and CNS symptoms
    • removes phosphate group
    • reduces atropine requirement

Cause of Death

Respiratory Muscle Paralysis (RMP)

 

 

Calcium gluconate (Option B): Used primarily for hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, or calcium channel blocker toxicity. It does not address cholinergic symptoms.

 

Pralidoxime (Option C): Pralidoxime (2-PAM) reactivates acetylcholinesterase inhibited by organophosphates. It is used alongside atropine but is not the initial management step. Atropine is given first to stabilize the patient.

 

Obidoxime (Option D): Similar to pralidoxime, obidoxime is an oxime used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase. However, it is not the primary treatment for immediate symptom control.

 

Learning Objective:
