questions.text: Identify the correct match, regarding the drug and its adverse effect.:
questions.solution:
• Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker used for the treatment of hypertension, angina, and arrhythmias. One of the most common gastrointestinal side effects of verapamil is constipation.
  • It works by blocking the influx of calcium ions into smooth muscle cells, which reduces the force of contraction and dilates the blood vessels.
  • This is thought to occur because verapamil can slow down the contractions of the intestinal muscles, leading to reduced motility and increased transit time.
  • Other gastrointestinal side effects of verapamil may include nausea, vomiting, abdominal discomfort and diarrhea.

Hydralazine - heart failure (Option A): Hydralazine is a vasodilator that is used to treat hypertension and heart failure. It works by relaxing the smooth muscle cells in the blood vessels, which reduces peripheral resistance and increases blood flow to the heart. Hydralazine is not known to cause heart failure; it may be used to treat heart failure in certain patients.

Atenolol - hemolytic anemia (Option B): Atenolol is a beta-blocker used to treat hypertension, angina, and certain arrhythmias. It works by blocking the action of the beta-adrenergic receptors, which reduces the heart rate and cardiac output. Hemolytic anemia is not a known side effect of atenolol.

Aliskiren - hypokalemia (Option C): Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor used to treat hypertension. It works by blocking the activity of renin, an enzyme that plays a key role in regulating blood pressure. Hypokalemia (low potassium levels in the blood) is not a known side effect of aliskiren. Aliskiren can, however, cause other electrolyte imbalances, such as hyperkalemia (high potassium levels in the blood).

questions.text:
Which of the following are seen in patients with chronic arsenic poisoning?

 

1. Raindrop pigmentation 

2. Peripheral neuritis 

3. Mees line 

4. Luminous vomit
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2, 3 are correct

 

Explanation

Chronic arsenic poisoning commonly presents with raindrop pigmentation, peripheral neuritis, and Mees lines, making Option A the correct answer.

 

Clinical manifestations of Arsenic Poisoning:

 

Acute Arsenic Poisoning

Chronic Arsenic Poisoning

Dermal

  • Hair loss
  • Mees lines (Aldrich-Mees line or Reynold’s line): Transverse bands of opacity in nails.
  • Melanosis (neck, eyelids, nipples)
  • Bowen’s disease
  • Facial oedema
  • Hyperkeratosis
  • Black foot disease (Peripheral gangrene)
 
  • Hyperpigmentation (raindrop pattern)
 
  • Skin cancer (commonly squamous cell carcinoma).

Ocular

  • Conjunctivitis
  • Lacrimation

Dimension of Vision

Gastrointestinal

  • Abdominal pain
  • Metallic taste
  • Garlicky odour
  • Dysphagia
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhoea (bloody or rice water)
  • Anorexia
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Weight loss

Airway

Upper airway irritation
  • Nasal septum perforation
  • Laryngitis
  • Bronchitis

Liver

Fatty degeneration
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Cirrhosis

Kidney

  • Oliguria
  • Uraemia

Nephritic changes

Neurological

  • Hyperpyrexia
  • Convulsions
  • Coma
  • Encephalopathy
  • Polyneuritis (glove & stocking type)

 

  • Tremor
  • Ataxia
  • Limb tenderness
  • Difficulty in walking

Haematological

–
  • Anaemia
  • Leucopenia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Basophilic stippling (Rare in arsenic poisoning and common in lead poisoning)
  •  
  • Karyorrhexis
  • Pancytopenia

Cardiac

  • Tachycardia
  • Hypotension
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Hypertension
  • Myocarditis

 

Luminous vomit: This is not associated with chronic arsenic poisoning but can occur in acute poisoning due to phosphorus ingestion.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is the new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium?
questions.solution:
• Pembrolizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) receptor on T cells.
  • It is a type of immunotherapy known as an immune checkpoint inhibitor, which works by blocking the PD-1 receptor, thereby enabling the immune system to recognize and attack cancer cells.
  • It was approved by the FDA in 2019 for the treatment of advanced or recurrent endometrial cancer that is microsatellite instability-high (MSI-H) or mismatch repair deficient (dMMR).

Nivolumab (Option A) & Ipilimumab (Option C): They both are other immune checkpoint inhibitors that the FDA has approved for the treatment of various types of cancer, including melanoma and lung cancer, but they have not been specifically approved for the treatment of endometrial cancer.

 

Trastuzumab (Option D) is a HER2-targeted therapy (monoclonal antibody) used in HER2-positive breast cancer and gastric cancer, but it is not relevant for endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: The image provided shows a wound. What type of wound is it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Contusion

 

Explanation

  • A contusion, commonly known as a bruise, results from blunt force trauma causing blood vessels under the skin to rupture.
  • It appears as discoloration of the skin due to subcutaneous bleeding without an open wound. The image likely shows this characteristic discoloration.

 

Abrasion (Option B): An abrasion involves superficial damage to the skin, such as scraping, which removes the epidermis. It does not typically involve subcutaneous bleeding as seen in the image.

 

Laceration (Option C): Lacerations are irregular tears in the skin caused by blunt or sharp trauma. They are characterized by jagged wound edges, which are not visible in the provided image.

 

Stab wound (Option D): A stab wound is caused by a pointed object penetrating the skin. It is characterized by a deep, narrow wound, which is inconsistent with the image.


 

Mechanism of injury of contusions

  • A contusion or bruise is a leak of blood into the tissues due to the rupture of blood vessels (veins, venules, arterioles) caused due to injury by a blunt object.
  • Some blunt objects that can cause contusions are fist, stones, sticks, bar, whip, hammer, axe, wooden handle, poker, foot with shoe or boot, etc.

Factors influencing the formation of bruises

Condition and type of tissues
  • Vascular and loose tissues may form large bruises even with a small degree of violence.
    • Examples: face, vulva, and scrotum.
  • Firm fibrous tissues, strongly supported tissues, and those covered by a thick dermis produce a comparatively small bruise for moderate trauma.
    • Examples: abdomen, back, scalp, palms, and soles.
  • Injury of tissues over bony surfaces shows prominent bruising.

Age

  • Children bruise easily.
  • Older people bruise easily.

Gender

  • Women bruise more easily than men.
  • Obese people bruise easily due to the high volume of subcutaneous tissue.

Colour of the skin

  • Bruising is more easily visible in fair-skinned people than in dark-skinned people.
  • Contusions are better felt in dark-skinned people than seen.

Natural diseases

  • Prominent bruising is seen with minor trauma in patients with:
    • Arteriosclerosis
    • Whooping cough in children due to violent coughing can cause bruising
    • Purpura hemorrhagica
    • Leukemia
    • Hemophilia
    • Scurvy
    • Vitamin K
    • Prothrombin deficiency
    • Phosphorus poisoning
    • Older persons on systemic steroids

Gravity shifting of the blood

  • In deep bruises, blood tracks along the fascial planes and may cause the bruise at a different site.
  • This is called ectopic bruising or percolated or migratory contusion.
  • Examples:
    • Spectacle hematoma or black eye in blunt trauma to the forehead.
    • Bruise behind ear due to basal skull fracture (Battle’s sign).
    • Bruise in the neck from fracture of the jaw.
    • Bruise around the ankle from a kick on the calf.

 

 

 

Learning Objective:

 

Medicolegal importance of bruises:

  • Reexamination after 24 hours is advisable as the bruises appear clearly by this time.
  • Age of injury is determined by color changes.
  • The degree of violence is evaluated by their size.
  • Patterned bruises give details about the object/weapon used.
  • A bruise is grievous when the internal organs are affected.
  • Fabricated bruises are used to falsely accuse someone or in defense of a crime.
  • Postmortem staining should be differentiated from a bruise.
  • Character and manner of injury may be known from the distribution of bruises (six penny bruises from the force of fingertips).

questions.text:
True statement regarding the administration of 5 alpha - reductase inhibitor is / are :


	Reduces dihydrotestosterone levels
	Reduces testosterone levels
	Elevates PSA levels
	Decreases PSA levels
questions.solution:
• 5-alpha reductase inhibitors are a class of medications that inhibit the enzyme 5-alpha reductase, which is responsible for converting testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT).
  • DHT is a potent androgen that plays a key role in the development of male-pattern baldness and the enlargement of the prostate.
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, it reduces the levels of DHT, which can help prevent hair loss and shrink the prostate in affected individuals. (Statement 1)
  • It reduces PSA levels primarily by lowering DHT, which in turn reduces the size and activity of the prostate. (Statement 4) (Statement 2 ruled out)
  • It does not reduce testosterone levels, they only block the conversion of testosterone to DHT, so testosterone levels usually remain the same or only slightly affected. (Statement 3 ruled out).

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg of paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it actually contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called?
questions.solution:
• A misbranded drug is one that is labelled incorrectly or in a misleading manner. In this case, the manufacturer labels the drug as containing 500 mg of paracetamol, but quantitative analysis reveals that it actually contains only 200 mg.
  • This discrepancy between the stated and actual content makes the drug misbranded because the label does not reflect the true contents of the product.

 

Types

Description

Example

Spurious Drugs

(Counterfeit Drugs)

(Option A)

Have no active ingredient
  • 500 mg paracetamol tablet → when checked, it contains no paracetamol in it.
  • Made by illegal people other than the manufacturer to copy the drug.

Misbranded Drugs

(Option D)

Low-quality drugs
  • 500 mg tablet → when checked, it contains only 200 mg.
  • Made by the same manufacturer to increase profit.

Adulterated Drugs

(Option B)

Addition of harmful or unwanted excipients
  • Cough syrup made in India containing ethylene glycol → when checked, GMP guidelines do not approve these substances.
  • Ethylene glycol is harmful and not approved as an excipient by GMP.

 

Unethical Drug (Option D): The term "unethical drug" is not a standard regulatory term. It may informally refer to drugs or drug practices that are deemed unethical for various reasons. However, the issue in the scenario is incorrect labelling, not an ethical concern regarding the drug's use; hence this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs is associated with the increased risk of fractures?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Rosiglitazone

Explanation:

Rosiglitazone is associated with an increased risk of fractures, particularly in women, due to reduced bone formation and increased bone resorption.

Adverse Effects of Thiazolidinediones (Pioglitazone, Rosiglitazone):

  1. Weight Gain and Edema:
    • Common adverse effects; average weight gain of 2–4 kg in the first year.
    • Weight gain and edema are more pronounced when combined with insulin.
  2. Fluid Retention:
    • Dose-related; contributes to reduced hematocrit.
    • Macular edema reported with both rosiglitazone and pioglitazone.
  3. Heart Failure Risk:
    • Long-term use associated with up to a 2-fold increased risk.
    • Due to plasma volume expansion, not reduced myocardial contractility.
    • Contraindicated in moderate-to-severe heart failure.
    • Use cautiously in patients with compensated heart failure, especially with insulin.
  4. Cardiovascular Events:
    • Rosiglitazone: Previously restricted due to concerns about MI/stroke; later data show neutral effect.
    • Pioglitazone: Mildly reduces risk of cardiovascular events; showed benefit in preventing stroke, MI, and diabetes in insulin-resistant patients.
  5. Bone Fracture Risk:
    • Increased in women.
    • Consider osteoporosis risk before starting.
  6. Liver Effects:
    • Pioglitazone and rosiglitazone lower transaminases; reduce hepatic steatosis.
    • Effective in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).
    • Rare cases of liver injury reported; contraindicated in active liver disease.

questions.text: The active metabolite of cyclophosphamide is :
questions.solution:
• The active metabolite of cyclophosphamide is 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide.
  • Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapy drug that requires metabolism in the liver by CYP2B6 to form its active metabolite.
  • 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide can then spontaneously decompose to form aldophosphamide, which is ultimately converted into phosphoramide mustard, a highly reactive compound that causes DNA crosslinking and kills rapidly dividing cells, which is the mechanism by which cyclophosphamide exerts its anti-cancer effect.

Hemorrhagic cystitis is a known adverse effect of cyclophosphamide. It occurs when acrolein, a toxic metabolite, forms, irritating the bladder mucosa and causing hemorrhage.

 

Aldophosphamide (Option A) is an intermediate metabolite but not the primary active metabolite. It is formed from 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide.

  • Aldophosphamide undergoes spontaneous breakdown to form phosphoramide mustard, which is the ultimate active cytotoxic agent.

 

4-Ketocyclophosphamide (Option C) is an inactive metabolite formed by oxidation of 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide.

 

Carboxyphosphamide (Option D) is also an inactive metabolite, formed by oxidation of cyclophosphamide. It is a non-toxic metabolite and has no role in the drug's cytotoxic effects.

questions.text: A hospital is conducting a study to check the efficacy of stains in multiple centers. There are 4-5 patients, and half of them receive the drug, and the other half receive the placebo. Neither the patients nor clinicians know which drug is being administered. What phase of the clinical trial describes the above scenario?
questions.solution:
The described study involving multiple centres, placebo control, and double-blinding fits the criteria of Phase 3 clinical trial.

 

  • Phase-3 trial:
    • Design: Double-blinded RCT
    • Purpose:
  • Find the optimal drug dose
  • Confirm efficacy
  • Safety is priority
  • Called a therapeutic confirmatory trial
  • Called multi-site trial (done on a heterogeneous population)
  • Drugs get market approval


 

Phase

Name

Blind & control

Subjects

Purpose

0

Microdosing study

Open-label trial

2 - 5 healthy volunteers

Check the target binding and the pharmacokinetics of the drug

1

(Option A)

Human Pharmacology and Safety

Open-label trial

20 - 50 healthy volunteers

To evaluate

  • Drug safety- the most important
  • MTD (maximum tolerable dose), loading dose, and drug half-life.
  • drug pharmacokinetics (absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion)

2

(Option C)

Therapeutic exploratory

Randomized clinical trial (RCT)

200 - 500 patients

To explore drug efficacy

3

Therapeutic Confirmatory

Double-blinded RCT

2000 - 5000 patients

To Find the optimal drug dose and confirm its efficacy

4

(Option D)

Post-marketing Surveillance

Open-label trial

Larger population being treated on the approved drug
  • To Find hidden/missed/rare adverse effects.
  • Evaluate compliance: long-term side effects
  • Drug interactions & Food interactions

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding memantine?


	Its therapeutic effect is due to its action on NMDA
	It is reserved for moderate to severe diseases.
	It is used as monotherapy and should not be used with other cholinesterase inhibitors .
	It is given at a daily dose of 1- 30 mg / day.
questions.solution:
• Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist which works by modulating the activity of the NMDA receptors involved in glutamate signalling. (Statement 1)
  • It is used for moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. (Statement 2)
  • It is used alongside cholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., donepezil) in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease, particularly in moderate to severe stages. (Statement 3 ruled out)
  • It is started with 5 mg/day PO, and increased by increments of 5 mg/day each week; the maintenance target dose (> 5 weeks) is 20 mg/day PO, in two divided doses 12 hours apart. (Statement 4 ruled out)

questions.text: A patient with erectile dysfunction is given sildenafil. The penile erectile function is found to be improved after the therapy. Which of the following mediates the action of sildenafil ?
questions.solution:
• Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitor. Its action is mediated through the cGMP (cyclic guanosine monophosphate) pathway.
  • Mechanism of action:

 

Sildenafil

↓

Inhibits phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) enzyme

↓

Prevents cGMP degradation

↓

Increases cytosolic cGMP levels

↓

Prolongs activation of GMP-dependent protein kinase

↓

Inhibits myosin light chain kinase dephosphorylation

↓

Smooth muscle relaxation in the corpus cavernosum

↓

Increased blood flow

↓

Sustained penile erection

 

cAMP (Option A) plays a role in other pathways related to vasodilation, especially in adrenergic pathways (e.g., beta-adrenergic agonists like adrenaline), but it is not the primary mediator in sildenafil’s mechanism.

 

Calcium (Option C): Drugs that influence calcium signalling are often involved in muscle contraction, vasoconstriction, or other processes requiring calcium influx. Some examples include calcium channel blockers. Sildenafil's action is not mediated through calcium.

 

Phosphatidyl glycerol and inositol phosphate (Option D) are involved in the phosphoinositide signalling pathway.

  • This signalling pathway involves the activation of G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), which activate phospholipase C to produce inositol trisphosphate (IP₃) and diacylglycerol (DAG).
  • These molecules mediate calcium release and other cellular responses. They do not mediate sildenafil’s action.

questions.text: Which of the following side effects is more commonly seen with oxcarbazepine than with carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Hyponatremia

Explanation:

  • Carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine are both antiepileptic drugs (AEDs) used in the treatment of epilepsy, bipolar disorder, and neuropathic pain.
  • While most adverse effects of oxcarbazepine are similar to those of carbamazepine, hyponatremia is more commonly observed with oxcarbazepine.
  • Oxcarbazepine causes SIADH by increasing ADH levels, which enhances kidney water retention, leading to hyponatremia.
  • Carbamazepine can also cause SIADH, but it is generally less potent than oxcarbazepine in this effect.
  • All the remaining options are more prominent with Carbamazepine.

Adverse effects of Carbamazepine

Adverse Effects

Description

Neurotoxicity

Sedation, dizziness, vertigo, diplopia, and ataxia

Gastrointestinal Effects

Vomiting and diarrhoea occur with higher doses.

Acute Intoxication

Coma, convulsions, cardiovascular collapse.

Haematological

Agranulocytosis, aplastic anaemia.

Hypersensitivity Reactions

Rashes (Option C), photosensitivity, hepatitis, lupus-like syndrome.

Water Retention and Hyponatremia

Due to enhanced antidiuretic hormone (ADH) action, it is more common in the elderly.

Teratogenicity

Increased incidence of minor fetal malformations.

Hepatic function

(Option D)

It is associated with elevated levels of gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)-liver enzymes

Hypotension

(Option A)
  • It can cause hypotension, particularly orthostatic hypotension, due to its CNS depressant effects, it is not very common.
  • Oxcarbazepine, although structurally similar, tends to have a lower incidence of hypotension.

questions.text: A patient is brought with altered sensorium and seizures. The attendant showed the laboratory report, which revealed elevated transaminases. Which of the following can be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient is presenting with altered sensorium and seizures, and the laboratory report shows elevated transaminases, indicating potential liver dysfunction.
  • Oxazepam is a benzodiazepine that is metabolized solely by conjugation, which does not rely on the liver's cytochrome P450 enzymes.
  • This makes it a safer option in liver dysfunction compared to other benzodiazepines.

 

Midazolam (Option A) is metabolized by the cytochrome P450 enzyme system in the liver. In patients with elevated transaminases or liver dysfunction, the metabolism of midazolam may be impaired, hence it is unsafe in the given situation.

 

Diazepam (Option B) is another benzodiazepine like midazolam. It is also metabolized by the cytochrome P450 system, and in a patient with liver dysfunction, its metabolism may be slowed. Hence, it is not preferred.

 

Alprazolam (Option C) is also a benzodiazepine that is commonly used in mood disorders, but not seizures. It is also metabolized in the liver; hence it is not ideal in given conditions.

questions.text: An anti–arrhythmic drug is shown to have the following effect. It is effective in both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
• Quinidine is a Class 1a antiarrhythmic and is effective in treating both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias.
  • It works by blocking sodium channels, which leads to decreases in the influx of sodium ions during the depolarization phase of the cardiac action potential. This leads to a reduction in the conduction velocity and prolongation of the refractory period in cardiac tissues, helping to suppress abnormal electrical impulses and arrhythmias.

 

Tocainide (Option A) is also a sodium channel blocker that belongs to class 1b antiarrhythmics ,and it is used to treat only ventricular tachycardia.

 

Propranolol (Option B) is a non-selective beta-blocker and belongs to class 2 antiarrhythmics, it is used in chronic treatment to prevent arrhythmias in Long QT Syndrome (LQTS) and Catecholaminergic Polymorphic Ventricular Tachycardia (CPVT). It is also used in Atrial Fibrillation, but is not as effective as quinidine in treating ventricular arrhythmias.

 

Lignocaine (Option D) is also a Class 1b antiarrhythmic that is primarily effective in treating ventricular arrhythmias, but It is not typically used for atrial arrhythmias.

questions.text:
Which of the following is false regarding disulfiram?


	Does not stop cravings
	Accumulates acetaldehyde
	Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase
	Maintenance dose is 250 mg
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Only 3

Explanation:

  • Disulfiram does not inhibit alcohol dehydrogenase. Instead, it inhibits acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, an enzyme responsible for converting acetaldehyde to acetic acid.
  • It does not reduce the psychological cravings for alcohol but acts as a deterrent to alcohol consumption and is often used as an adjunct in the treatment of alcohol dependence. (Statement 1 ruled out)
  • MOA : Disulfiram ö Inhibition of Aldehyde Dehydrogenase (ALDH) ö Accumulation of Acetaldehyde ö Unpleasant symptoms, including flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache, palpitations, sweating, shortness of breath, and hypotensio,n ö Creates a strong negative association between alcohol consumption and the discomfort. (Statement 2 ruled out)
  • The starting dose of Disulfiram is 500 mg orally (1-2 weeks), followed by a maintenance dose of 250 mg (Statement 4 ruled out).

questions.text: G6PD (Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase) can manifest with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
• Primaquine is an antimalarial drug that can cause hemolysis in individuals with G6PD deficiency.
  • Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is an X-linked genetic disorder that impairs red blood cell protection against oxidative stress, leading to hemolytic anemia when exposed to certain triggers like medications, foods, or infections.
  • Primaquine generates reactive oxygen species (ROS), which normally would be neutralized by G6PD, but in G6PD deficiency, oxidative damage accumulates, leading to hemolytic anemia in these individuals.

 

Mefloquine (Option B) is another antimalarial drug, it is generally not known to cause hemolysis in G6PD-deficient individuals.

 

Penicillin (Option C) is an antibiotic that is not typically associated with hemolysis in G6PD-deficient individuals.

 

Tetracycline (Option D) is an antibiotic, and there is no significant association between tetracycline use and hemolysis in G6PD-deficient individuals. It does not cause oxidative stress in red blood cells in the same way as drugs like primaquine.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs is a β2 agonist?


	Dopexamine
	Dipivefrine
	Fenoldopam
	Mirabegron
questions.solution:
Drugs that act as β2 agonists from given options are Dopexamine and Dipivefrine, hence the correct answer is 1,2.

  • β2 agonists are drugs that specifically stimulate β2 adrenergic receptors, they are primarily found in the smooth muscles of the bronchi (lungs), blood vessels, and other tissues. Activation of β2 receptors typically leads to bronchodilation, vasodilation, and other effects like muscle relaxation.

 

Dopexamine:

  • It is a synthetic catecholamine structurally related to dopamine and has a strong β2 agonist activity, moderate activity at DA1 and DA2 receptors, and β1 agonist activity.
  • It is used in shock and heart failure to improve heart function and renal perfusion.

 

Dipivefrine:

  • It is a prodrug of epinephrine (adrenaline), primarily used in the treatment of glaucoma.
  • It metabolizes into epinephrine, and activates α and β receptors, leading to increased aqueous humor outflow in the eye and decreases the production of aqueous humor by vasoconstriction, thus lowering intraocular pressure. It has β2 agonist activity but is mainly used for its effect on the eye.

 

Fenoldopam: (Option A, B and D ruled out)

  • It is a D1 receptor agonist, it has a moderate affinity for α2 receptors, but no significant affinity for D2, α1, or β adrenergic receptors.
  • It is used as a rapidly acting vasodilator for short-term control in severe hypertension e.g., malignant hypertension with end-organ damage. (usually <48 hours),

 

Mirabegron: (Option B and D ruled out)

  • It is a β3 adrenergic receptor agonist, which activates β3 receptors in the detrusor muscle of the bladder, leading to detrusor muscle relaxation, increasing the bladder capacity and reducing the urgency to urinate.
  • It is used to manage overactive bladder.
  • It is a moderate CYP2D6 inhibitor, so care must be taken with drugs metabolized by CYP2D6 (e.g., digoxin, metoprolol).

questions.text: What could be the most probable diagnosis for an elderly woman who is experiencing abdominal pain and swelling, considering her past medical history of scoliosis? Please refer to the provided X-ray image of the woman's upright abdomen for further information.

choices.text: Large bowel obstruction due to sigmoid volvulus
Large bowel obstruction due to faecolith
Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation

questions.solution:
The Omega sign, coffee bean sign, or bent tube sign on a plain abdominal X-ray is classic for sigmoid volvulus. It results from twisting of the sigmoid colon, leading to a large, dilated, U-shaped loop with an apex pointing toward the diaphragm.

 

Sigmoid volvulus is common in elderly patients, especially those with a history of chronic constipation or conditions like scoliosis, which may cause colonic redundancy or altered anatomy.

 

Sigmoid Volvulus

Caecal Volvulus
  • Sigmoid volvulus arises in the pelvis, specifically the left lower quadrant.
  • It extends towards the right upper quadrant.
  • It has an ahaustral appearance (lack of haustra).
  • Causes obstruction of the distal large bowel, leading to dilation of the ascending, transverse, and descending colon.
  • A few gas-fluid levels may be seen.
  • Coffee-Bean Sign: The condition is characterized by a distended sigmoid loop with an inverted U shape, known as the coffee-bean sign (or kidney bean sign).
  • Whirlpool Sign: The whirl, or whirlpool sign is observed when the bowel rotates around its mesentery, resulting in whirls of the mesenteric vessels.
  • The torsion is located in the ascending colon above the ileocecal valve.
  • Caecal volvulus arises in the right lower quadrant.
  • It extends towards the epigastrium or left upper quadrant.
  • The colonic haustral pattern is maintained.
  • The distal colon is usually collapsed, and the small bowel is distended.
  • One gas-fluid level may be seen.
  • Definitive Sign: Upward displacement of the appendix and obstruction of the large bowel is a definitive sign of cecal volvulus.
  • May show a U-shaped distended bowel segment and signs of ischemia, including mural thickening, infiltration of the mesenteric fat, and pneumatosis intestinalis.
  • Whirlpool Sign: A whirl sign may be apparent due to tight torsion of the mesentery from a twist between the afferent and efferent loops.
  • Coffee Bean Appearance: A "coffee bean" appearance may be seen in a loop of transverse colon.
  • Bird's Beak Sign: Abrupt cut-off with “bird's beak” tapering at the distal cecum is characteristic.
  • Central appendix sign: Abnormal appendix position near midline.

Large bowel obstruction due to faecolith (Option B): This is incorrect because faecoliths are typically seen as radio-opaque masses in the colon and do not produce the characteristic "coffee bean sign."

 

Cecal volvulus (Option C): This is incorrect because cecal volvulus shows a dilated cecum displaced to the midline or left upper quadrant, not the classic U-shaped appearance of sigmoid volvulus.

 

Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation (Option D): This is incorrect because small bowel obstruction typically shows multiple air-fluid levels and dilated loops of the small intestine. A perforation would present with free air under the diaphragm on an upright X-ray, not a coffee bean sign.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1. Football sign
			
			
			a. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
			
		
		
			
			2. String sign
			
			
			b. Achalasia cardia
			
		
		
			
			3. Rat tail sign
			
			
			c. Ileocecal TB
			
		
		
			
			4. Inverted umbrella sign
			
			
			d. Pneumoperitoneum
questions.solution:
Football sign (d): Pneumoperitoneum

  • Seen on abdominal X-rays, the football sign indicates free intraperitoneal air outlining the peritoneal cavity, creating the appearance of an "American football."

String sign (a): Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

  • Refers to a thin, elongated pyloric canal seen on upper GI contrast studies, characteristic of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

Rat tail sign (b): Achalasia cardia

  • A tapering of the distal oesophagus with smooth narrowing on barium swallow, resembling a rat tail, is indicative of achalasia.

Inverted umbrella sign (c): Ileocecal tuberculosis

  • A deformity of the ileocecal region with contracted cecum and pulled-up ileum, resembling an inverted umbrella, is typical of ileocecal TB.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with fatigue. Investigations reveal the following: Hemoglobin (Hb): 5 gm%, low mean corpuscular haemoglobin (MCH), and low mean corpuscular volume (MCV). The peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
The laboratory findings and peripheral smear indicate iron deficiency anaemia, characterized by microcytic, hypochromic RBCs, anisocytosis, and poikilocytosis.

  • Iron deficiency anaemia can result from dietary lack, impaired absorption, increased iron requirement (pregnancy), or chronic blood loss (gastrointestinal bleeding).
  • Clinical features include Koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic glossitis, oesophagal webs, pica and intestinal malabsorption, affecting overall nutritional status.

 

Iron studies commonly used in the diagnosis of iron deficiency anaemia (IDA):

Iron Study

Interpretation in Iron Deficiency Anemia

Serum Ferritin

Low (< 30 ng/mL) indicates depleted iron stores.

Serum Iron (Fe)

Low levels are seen in iron deficiency anaemia.

Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)

Increased TIBC reflects the increased capacity of transferrin to bind iron in response to low iron stores.

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW)

Increased RDW is often seen in iron deficiency anaemia

Bone Marrow Aspiration and Iron Staining

Confirmatory test

 

Learning Objective:

 

Microcytic Anaemia

Normocytic Anaemia

Macrocytic Anaemia
  • Sideroblastic anemia.
  • Iron deficiency anaemia.
  • Thalassemia.
  • Anaemia of chronic disease.
  • Lead poisoning.
 

(Mnemonic- SITAL)
  • Acute Blood Loss
  • Hemolytic Anaemia(hereditary spherocytosis)
  • Anaemia of Chronic Disease
  • Bone Marrow Disorders (e.g., Aplastic Anaemia)
  • Renal Disease
  • Endocrine Disorders (e.g., Hypothyroidism)
  • Early stages of iron deficiency anaemia
  • Vitamin B12 Deficiency
  • Folate Deficiency
  • Alcohol Abuse
  • Liver Disease
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Myelodysplastic Syndrome

questions.text: The following image shows an instrument used to estimate haemoglobin levels. What does it measure?
questions.solution:
• The image depicts a device known as the Sahli hemoglobinometer, which is used to estimate haemoglobin levels in blood.
  • The hemoglobinometer works by adding a dilute acid to a small sample of blood, causing the formation of acid hematin, a derivative of haemoglobin formed when haemoglobin reacts with an acid.
  • This acid hematin is then compared to a standard colour chart to determine the haemoglobin concentration.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is iron in tissues stained?
questions.solution:
• Iron in tissues is stained using Prussian blue.
  • This staining technique relies on the reaction between Fe3+ ions and ferrocyanide ions to form an insoluble blue pigment.
  • When tissue sections are treated with a solution of potassium ferrocyanide and hydrochloric acid, any iron present in the tissue reacts with the ferrocyanide, producing the blue pigment.
  • This stain is specific for iron and is frequently employed to detect iron deposition in conditions like hemochromatosis and hemosiderosis.

Prussian blue stain

Iron

Masson Trichrome

Differentiate Collagen & muscle fibers

Fite-Faraco stain

Leprosy

PAS stain

Glycogen

questions.text: A woman presents with nodular lesions, 4-6 mm in size, on the inner thighs and peri-anal region. The lesions appear pale, and histopathological examination reveals multiple intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies consistent with Henderson-Patterson bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of pale, nodular lesions on the inner thighs and peri-anal region, along with the presence of Henderson-Patterson bodies, is characteristic of Molluscum contagiosum.

  • Henderson-Patterson bodies are eosinophilic inclusion bodies that are diagnostic for Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV) infection.
  • The virus primarily infects the skin, causing characteristic lesions that are typically described as pearl-like, dome-shaped, and umbilicated.
  • The lesions are generally painless and self-limiting, though they can persist for months or even years.

Molluscum Contagiosum:

  • Caused by: Poxvirus (MCV-1 to MCV-4)
    • MCV-1 is the most common.
    • MCV-2 is often sexually transmitted.
  • Common in:
    • Children (2-12 years): Spread through direct contact or shared items (e.g., towels).
    • Adults: Typically sexually transmitted, affecting genitals, lower abdomen, buttocks, and inner thighs.
  • Incubation period: Approximately 6 weeks.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Pearly, dome-shaped papules with a dimpled centre.
    • Papules are 1-5 mm in diameter.
    • The central waxy core contains cytoplasmic viral inclusions.
  • Common sites in children: Trunk, arms, and legs.
  • Common sites in adults: Genitals, lower abdomen, buttocks, and inner thighs.
  • Microscopic examination:
    • Lesion Characteristics: Cup-like, verrucous epidermal hyperplasia.
    • Diagnostic Structure: Molluscum body, a large (up to 35 µm), ellipsoid, homogeneous cytoplasmic inclusion.
    • Found in the stratum granulosum and stratum corneum.
    • Eosinophilic in the stratum granulosum.

Pale blue hue in the stratum corneum.

Trichodysplasia Spinulosa (Option A) is a viral infection that predominantly affects immunocompromised individuals, especially organ transplant recipients. It typically manifests as follicular papules and spiny nodules on the face, neck, and upper extremities. Histologically, it shows hyperkeratosis, follicular plugging, and hair shaft abnormalities.

Condyloma acuminata (Option B), or genital warts, is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV) and is a sexually transmitted infection. These warts usually appear as flesh-coloured, cauliflower-like growths in the genital and perianal regions. Histologically, they are characterized by hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, and koilocytosis, where squamous cells exhibit a clear halo around the nucleus.

Donovanosis (Option D), also called granuloma inguinale, is a bacterial infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents as painless nodules or ulcers in the genital and perianal regions. Histologically, it shows granulomatous inflammation with Donovan bodies, which are large, rod-shaped, intracytoplasmic bacteria

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines does not cause the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction?
questions.solution:
IFN-gamma, produced by activated T cells and NK cells, regulates Th1 immune responses but is not typically involved in the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction. Instead, TNF-alpha, IL-6, and IL-8 play a key role in this reaction.

 

Jarisch-Herxheimer Reaction:

  • It is a dramatic but self-limited inflammatory response that can occur after the initiation of treatment for syphilis. It is characterized by:
    • Fever
    • Chills
    • Myalgia (muscle pain)
    • Headache
    • Tachycardia (increased heart rate)
    • Increased respiratory rate
    • Elevated circulating neutrophil count
    • Vasodilation with mild hypotension
  • This reaction is believed to be triggered by the release of lipoproteins from dying Treponema pallidum organisms.
  • The reaction occurs in approximately 50% of patients with primary syphilis, 90% of those with secondary syphilis, and in a smaller proportion of individuals with later-stage disease.
  • Symptoms typically subside within 12–24 hours.
  • In patients with secondary syphilis, erythema (redness) and oedema (swelling) of cutaneous lesions may worsen temporarily.

 

TNF alpha (Option A) is a pro-inflammatory cytokine produced by macrophages and T cells, playing a central role in inflammation. It is implicated in the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction, where cytokine release following antibiotic treatment temporarily worsens symptoms.

IL-6 (Option B) is a pro-inflammatory cytokine produced by immune cells, fibroblasts, and endothelial cells, regulating immune responses and inflammation. It contributes to the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction by amplifying the systemic inflammatory response.

IL-8 (Option C) is a chemokine that recruits and activates neutrophils, playing a role in infection and inflammation. It contributes to the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction by enhancing neutrophil recruitment and activation.

questions.text: The type of cancer that rarely spreads through the lymphatic system is:
questions.solution:
BCC (basal cell carcinoma) is typically localized, grows slowly, and has a low metastasis potential. It rarely spreads to lymph nodes or distant organs, making it less likely to disseminate than SCC (Squamous Cell Carcinoma), MCC (Merkel Cell Carcinoma), or malignant melanoma.

 

Metastasis (distant spread)

  • All cancers are going to show metastasis except:
    • BCC (Basal cell carcinoma / Rodent's ulcer)
    • Brain Tumor/Glioma
  • Types of metastatic spread:
    • Hematogenous spread
    • Lymphatic spread
    • Transcoelomic spread
    • Direct seeding of body cavities or surfaces

 

Hematogenous spread

Lymphatic spread

Transcoelomic spread

Veins are more prone to invasion than arteries due to their thinner walls.

Tumours use existing lymphatic vessels at their margins. Follows natural routes of lymphatic drainage.

Tumour invades the serosal wall of the coelomic cavity, releasing tumour fragments into coelomic fluid, which is implanted elsewhere in the body cavity.

Seen in most of the sarcomas.

Seen in most carcinomas.

Seen in Krukenberg tumour in the ovary due to metastasis from gastric carcinoma to the ovary.

Exceptions:

  • Synovial sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma


*These tumours are spread by the lymphatic route.

Exceptions:

  • HCC
  • RCC
  • Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Choriocarcinoma


*These tumours are spread by a hematogenous route.

  

 

Direct Seeding of Body Cavities or Surfaces:

  • It occurs when malignant neoplasms spread to anatomical spaces that lack physical barriers, such as the peritoneal cavity (more commonly), but they can also affect other body cavities, such as the pleural, pericardial, subarachnoid, and joint spaces.
  • Examples include:
  1. Pseudomyxoma peritonei is characterized by the presence of a gelatinous neoplastic mass filling the peritoneal cavity arising from the rupture of mucus-secreting appendiceal (most common cause) or ovarian carcinomas.
  2. Gastric carcinoma can spread to the distal end of the peritoneal cavity (Pouch of Douglas) and is known as the ‘Blummer shelf.’
  3. Medulloblastoma from the cerebellum spreads to the spinal cord by ‘Drop metastasis.’

 

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) (Option A) arises from squamous cells in the outermost skin layer and can occur in the skin, lips, mouth, throat, esophagus, lungs, and other organs. It has a higher metastatic potential than basal cell carcinoma, often spreading via the lymphatic route.


 

Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) (Option B) is a rare, aggressive skin cancer arising from touch-sensitive Merkel cells. It typically occurs on sun-exposed areas like the head, neck, and arms and has a high tendency to spread via the lymphatic system.


 

Malignant melanoma (Option D) is an aggressive skin cancer arising from melanocytes, with a high potential for lymphatic and hematogenous metastasis to organs like the liver, lungs, brain, and bones. Early detection and treatment are crucial for better outcomes.

questions.text: Blood transfusion requires screening of donor blood for all of the following infections except:
questions.solution:
Dengue fever is a viral illness transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. Unlike some other diseases listed, routine screening for dengue in donated blood is not typically performed. This is because mosquitoes primarily transmit dengue rather than through blood transfusions.

 

Screening for transfusion-transmitted infections:

The following infections can be transmitted by blood transfusion.

Viral

Bacterial

Parasites

Others

Hepatitis (A, B, C, G)

HIV (I & II)

HTLV (I & II)

CMV

EBV

Parvovirus B19

Syphilis

Malaria

Babesiosis

Trypanosoma cruzi

Creutzfeldt-
Jakob disease
  • Plasma processing methods have been shown to inactivate most recognized infectious organisms, except for non-lipid-enveloped viruses and prions.
  • All clinically relevant blood components transmit prion disease following a single blood transfusion.
  • Malaria can also be transmitted by most blood components (red cells, platelets, white-cell concentrates, cryoprecipitates, and frozen red cells after thawing and washing).
    • Transmission from single-donor FFP has not been reported.
  • In India, the following five diseases are screened:
    • HBV (Option D)
    • HCV (Option A)
    • HIV (Option C)
    • Malaria
    • Syphilis
  • Screening for the diseases mentioned above is mandatory, and transfusing unscreened blood is a medical offence.

questions.text:
Match the following microscopic appearance and the respective tumour in which they are seen

 


	
		
			
			Microscopic appearance
			
			
			Tumor
			
		
		
			
			1. Schiller Duval bodies
			
			
			a. Krukenberg tumor
			
		
		
			
			2. Presence of teeth, hair, etc
			
			
			B.  Granulosa cell tumor
			
		
		
			
			3. Signet ring cells
			
			
			C. Yolk sac tumour
			
		
		
			
			4. Call-Exner bodies
			
			
			d. Teratoma
questions.solution:
Microscopic Appearance

Tumor

Schiller Duval bodies

Yolk sac tumour

Presence of teeth, hair, etc.

Teratoma

Signet ring cells

Kruckenberg tumor

Call-Exner bodies

Granulosa cell tumor

 

Yolk Sac tumour or endodermal sinus tumour:

  • Common in infants and children up to 3 years old.
  • Morphology:
    • Gross: Solid grey-white with a gelatinous or mucoid appearance.
    • Microscopy:

50% of the tumours show a lace-like network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or spindled cells with endodermal sinuses (Schiller-Duval or glomerular bodies).

  • Eosinophilic, hyaline-like globules containing α-fetoprotein (AFP) and α1-antitrypsin are present.

 

Granulosa cell tumour:

  • Originates from granulosa cells of the ovarian follicle.
  • Occurs in postmenopausal women (adult type) or at any age (juvenile type)
  • Juvenile cases may present with precocious sexual development, while adults may experience abnormal uterine bleeding and endometrial hyperplasia (which can lead to carcinoma)
  • Microscopically, Call-Exner bodies and coffee bean nuclei are observed
  • Elevated inhibin levels, CD99 positivity, and FOXL2 mutations are seen.

Signet ring cells:

  • They are typically associated with Krukenberg tumours, which are metastases of diffuse gastric carcinoma to the ovaries.
  • Grossly, Krukenberg tumours often present with bilateral, symmetric ovarian enlargement with an intact capsule.
  • Signet ring cells contain mucin that pushes the nucleus to the periphery, creating a "signet ring" appearance.

Teratoma: Teratomas in adult males are typically large, ranging from 5 to 10 cm in diameter, with a heterogeneous appearance consisting of various organoid structures, such as neural tissue, muscle, epidermis, cartilage, thyroid gland, or intestinal wall.

 

  • These elements may be mature or immature, sharing histologic features with fetal or embryonic tissue.
  • Microscopically, these structures are embedded in a fibrous or myxoid stroma.

questions.text: A patient suffering from cholelithiasis underwent cholecystectomy. The image of the specimen is shown below. Which of the following is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The image shows a characteristic finding of a gallbladder polyp, which typically presents as a raised, pedunculated lesion on the gallbladder mucosa.
  • They are often benign and can be composed of cholesterol, adenomas, or inflammatory tissue.
  • Gall bladder polyp is a pre-malignant condition presenting with cholecystitis & biliary colic.
  • Types
    • Cholesterol polyp (More common)
    • Adenomatous polyp (Has malignant potential)
  • Risk factors for malignancy in adenomatous polyp:
  • Coexistence of gallstones
  • Age > 60 years
  • Increase in size
  • Size > 10 mm

 

Cholesterolosis (Option A): Often referred to as "strawberry gallbladder" (Option C), it occurs when cholesterol deposits accumulate in the gallbladder wall, giving it a speckled, yellowish appearance.



 

Adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder (Option C) is the most common form of gallbladder cancer, arising from glandular cells and often associated with chronic cholecystitis, gallstones, and older age.

  • It is more common in women.
  • Early stages are usually asymptomatic, but as the tumour progresses, symptoms like right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and weight loss may occur.
  • HER2/neu overexpression and elevated CA 19-9 levels can aid in diagnosis and prognosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker of natural killer cells?
questions.solution:
CD94 is a marker associated with natural killer (NK) cells and plays a role in regulating their activity and interactions with other immune cells.

 

Natural Killer cell (NK) :

  • Produced by a large granular lymphocyte.
  • Constitutes 5 to 10% of circulating blood lymphocytes.
  • Function:
    • It can be part of both innate and adaptive immunity.
    • Innate immunity:
      • Directly kill the virus-infected cells or tumour cells.
    • Adaptive immunity:
      • Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity.
  • Markers for NK cells: CD 16, CD 56, CD 94.
  • CD 56: The role is still not fully understood.
  • CD 16: Detect and bind to Fc fragment of IgG on target cells and kill the cell by perforins and by releasing toxins and granzymes.
  • Nk cells have 2 different kinds of receptors.
    • Activating receptors: NKG2D.
    • Inhibitory receptors: CD94, CD 96 (these prevent self-cells from being attacked by NK cells).
  • Cytokines produced by Nk cells :
    • IFN-Y: (Cytokine majorly responsible for granuloma formation). This cytokine leads to the activation of macrophages in epithelioid cells.
  • Cytokines responsible for the proliferation of NK cells: IL-2 and IL-15.

CD68 (Option A): A marker of macrophages and other monocytes, not NK cells.

CD3 (Option B): Found on T cells, particularly T cell receptors.

CD25 (Option C): The alpha chain of the IL-2 receptor, primarily expressed on activated T cells.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is NOT caused by high-risk strains of human papillomavirus (HPV)?
questions.solution:
Laryngeal papillomas are benign lesions primarily associated with HPV serotypes 6 and 11. These serotypes are known to cause condyloma acuminatum and are commonly associated with laryngeal lesions, particularly in children and young adults

 

Types of HPV
 

Cutaneous involvement

HPV 1, 2, 3 (low risk)
  • Filiform wart
  • Verruca Plantaris

HPV 5, 8 (high risk)
  • Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis
 

Mucosal involvement

HPV 6, 11 (low risk)
  • Condyloma Acuminatum
  • Recurrent laryngeal papillomas

HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35 (high risk)
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

HPV 16 (High risk)
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Oropharyngeal SCC

HPV 18 (High risk)
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma cervix
  • Anogenital carcinoma


 

Cutaneous involvement

Benign Warts

  
  • Common Skin Warts (Verruca Vulgaris): Small, hard, rough growths on the skin; commonly seen in children (associated with serotypes 2, 4, 27, 57).
  • Flat Warts (Verruca Plana): Also prevalent among children.
  • Plantar Warts (Verruca Plantaris): Benign lesions commonly found in adolescents (linked to serotype 1).

Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis
  • Rare autosomal recessive conditions may progress to squamous cell carcinoma, especially in sun-exposed areas.
  • Associated with serotypes 5, 8, 9, 12, 17, 20, 36, and 47.

Mucosal involvement

Anogenital Warts

  
  • It is also known as Condyloma Acuminatum.
  • A sexually transmitted infection in adults, associated with HPV serotypes 6 and 11.

Head and Neck Lesions

  
  • Benign: Recurrent laryngeal papillomas, especially in children (serotypes 6, 11).
  • Malignant: Laryngeal and esophageal carcinomas (serotypes 16, 18)

Carcinoma Cervix
  • Mainly squamous cell carcinoma, linked to high-risk serotypes like 16, 18, 31, 33, and others.
  • Serotype 16 alone accounts for ~50% of cases, while serotypes 16 & 18 together cause ~70% of cervical cancers.

questions.text: A boy presents with recurrent episodes of melena. On examination, there is eczema of the skin with multiple petechiae. His platelet count is low, with normal RBC and WBC counts. Which of the following is the diagnostic investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient's presentation of recurrent melena (indicative of gastrointestinal bleeding), eczema, petechiae (small skin haemorrhages), and low platelet count with normal RBC and WBC counts suggests Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (WAS), an X-linked recessive disease characterized by the triad of:
    • Thrombocytopenia
    • Eczema
    • Recurrent infections
  • It is caused by mutations in the gene located at Xp11.23, which encodes the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP).
  • WASP belongs to a family of proteins that are believed to link membrane receptors, such as antigen receptors, to cytoskeletal elements.
  • IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal.
  • Paradoxically, the levels of IgA and IgE are often elevated. Patients are also prone to developing B-cell lymphomas.
  • WASP may be involved in cytoskeleton-dependent responses, including cell migration and signal transduction.
  • It may lead to early death. The only treatment is hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation.

 

Anti-platelet antibodies (Option B) are typically found in conditions like immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), but the patient's history and presentation point more toward WAS.

 

Bone marrow biopsy (Option C) is generally used to assess hematologic disorders like leukaemia or myelodysplastic syndromes, which do not match this case.

 

Electron microscopy (Option D) is helpful for diagnosing certain intracellular abnormalities, but it's not the first diagnostic test for WAS.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue and dyspnea for 2 weeks. On examination, pallor is noted, and haemoglobin is found to be 6 gm/dL. What is the likely finding seen on the peripheral smear?
questions.solution:
• An elderly woman with fatigue, dyspnea, and severe anaemia (Hb 6 g/dL) suggests iron deficiency anaemia (IDA).
  • The peripheral smear typically shows microcytic hypochromic cells, the hallmark of IDA.
  • While poikilocytosis can be present, microcytosis and hypochromia are more characteristic.
  • Iron deficiency anaemia can result from dietary lack, impaired absorption, the increased iron requirement (pregnancy), or chronic blood loss (gastrointestinal bleeding).
  • Clinical features: Koilonychia, alopecia, atrophic glossitis, oesophagal webs, pica and intestinal malabsorption, affecting overall nutritional status

In iron deficiency anaemia (IDA), a peripheral blood smear can reveal characteristic changes.

  • Hypochromic Red Blood Cells: The RBCs appear pale due to decreased haemoglobin content.
  • Microcytic Red Blood Cells: RBCs are smaller than normal due to decreased haemoglobin synthesis.
  • Anisocytosis: There is significant variation in the size of RBCs.
  • Poikilocytosis: RBCs may show abnormal shapes, such as pencil cells, target cells (codocytes), and occasionally, elliptocytes.

questions.text: In a patient with Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome, graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) does not occur. Which of the following causes it?

choices.text: MHC Class II deficiency in lymphocytes
MHC Class I deficiency in lymphocytes

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) MHC Class II deficiency in lymphocytes

Explanation: 

Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome (BLS) caused by MHC Class II deficiency (most common form) prevents the development of CD4+ T cells, which are essential for initiating graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

 

Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome:

  • Typically caused by mutations in transcription factors essential for the expression of Class II MHC genes.
    • The absence of Class II MHC molecules leads to the underdevelopment of CD4+ T cells, which play a crucial role in cellular immunity and assist B cells. As a result, Class II MHC deficiency results in a combined immunodeficiency.
  • Additionally, other forms of the syndrome can be caused by mutations in antigen receptor chains or signalling molecules critical for the maturation of T or B cells.

 

Complement deficiency (Option A) does not affect T cell function or MHC expression, making it unrelated to GVHD, which requires donor T cell recognition of host MHC.

 

MHC Class II deficiency in lymphocytes (Option C) describes the cause of Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome but does not directly cause GVHD; instead, it prevents CD4⁺ T cell development, making GVHD unlikely.

 

MHC Class I deficiency in lymphocytes (Option D) affects CD8⁺ T cell function but does not significantly impair CD4⁺ T cell-mediated GVHD, which relies on MHC Class II recognition.

questions.text: Investigations of a patient being evaluated for leukaemia revealed a WBC count of 450,000/μL, with eosinophilia and basophilia. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A very high WBC count (450,000/microliter) with eosinophilia and basophilia is suggestive of Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML).


 

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)

Category

Description

Genetics

Philadelphia chromosome t(9;22)

Origin

Myeloid lineage

Etiopathogenesis

BCR-ABL fusion gene from t(9;22) increases tyrosine kinase activity, leading to uncontrolled myeloid proliferation. Radiation exposure is a risk factor.

Clinical Features
  • Affects adults.
  • Presents with splenomegaly, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and abdominal discomfort.
  • It can progress to blast crisis, resembling acute leukaemia.

Diagnosis
  • Bone marrow aspirate to confirm.
  • FISH detects the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

Bone Marrow aspirate findings.
  • Presence of scattered macrophages with abundant wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm, called sea-blue histiocytes or pseudo-Gaucher cells.
  • The marrow is markedly hypercellular due to massively increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursors (elevated eosinophils and basophils)
  • Increased megakaryocytes, commonly with small, dysplastic forms called dwarf megakaryocytes.
  • Normal or slightly decreased erythroid progenitors (increased myeloid: erythroid ratio).
  • Increased deposition of reticulin fibres.

Management

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) like Imatinib.


 

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) (Option A):

  • Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolations
  • They contain fat (Oil Red O Positive)
  • Hand mirror-shaped cells

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) (Option D):

  • Blasts ≥ 20%
  • Myeloblasts with AuerRods

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) (Option C):

  • Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cell): Due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation
  • Convent girl appearance: Lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML):

  • Leukocytosis
  • Cell Types: Neutrophils( multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)
  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules helps leukocytes roll over endothelial cells in vessels?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) E-selectin

Explanation:

E-selectin is a molecule expressed on endothelial cells that facilitates the initial rolling of leukocytes along the vessel wall during the inflammatory response.

 

Leukocyte Adhesion to Endothelium: In normal blood flow, leukocytes are pushed to the edges of the vessel. In inflammation, stasis causes leukocytes to slow down and interact with endothelial cells. This interaction involves selectins and integrins, which mediate the rolling and firm adhesion of leukocytes.

  • Selectins: These are responsible for the initial rolling interactions. There are three types:
    • L-selectin on leukocytes
    • E-selectin on endothelial cells
    • P-selectin on both platelets and endothelial cells

The ligands for selectins are sialylated oligosaccharides on mucin-like glycoproteins. Cytokines like TNF and IL-1 upregulate the expression of selectins, promoting leukocyte rolling along the vessel wall.

  • Integrins: After rolling, leukocytes bind more firmly to the endothelium via integrins, such as VLA-4 and LFA-1 (CD11a (Option D) & CD18), which interact with endothelial ligands like VCAM-1 and ICAM-1. This firm adhesion halts the rolling process and allows leukocytes to flatten and spread on the endothelial surface.

 

Migration: Once firmly adhered, leukocytes migrate through the endothelial layer in a process called transmigration. It is facilitated by adhesion molecules like PECAM-1 (CD31) (Option B). After exiting the vessel, leukocytes follow the chemotactic gradient toward the site.

 

Cadherins (Option A) are adhesion molecules involved in maintaining cell-cell interactions in tissues, especially in epithelial cells, but they are not directly involved in the rolling of leukocytes on endothelial cells during inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about hereditary spherocytosis?

choices.text: Gallstones develop by 4-5 years of age
Splenectomy does not protect against developing gallstones
At least 25% of cases have a family history of hereditary spherocytosis
High MCH is pathognomonic of HS

questions.solution:
25% of cases have a family history, as hereditary spherocytosis is often inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern (75% of cases show an autosomal dominant pattern).

 

Hereditary spherocytosis (HS) is an inherited disorder caused by intrinsic defects in the red cell membrane skeleton that render red cells spheroid, less deformable, and vulnerable to splenic sequestration and destruction.

 

It has an autosomal dominant inheritance (75%) characterized by ankyrin mutation and an autosomal recessive inheritance characterized by spectrin mutation.

 

Pathophysiology of hereditary spherocytosis:

  • Most specific morphologic finding: Spherocytosis – dark-staining (hyperchromic) spherocytes lacking a central zone of pallor.
  • Other features: Reticulocytosis due to increased red cell turnover.
  • Clinical features: Anemia, splenomegaly, jaundice, and increased risk of gallstones.
  • Severity: Ranges from asymptomatic to severe hemolytic anaemia requiring transfusions.
  • Complications:
    • Early: Neonatal jaundice, hemolytic crises.
    • Late: Gallstones, rarely iron overload.

questions.text: B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time. Which phenomenon is it due to?
questions.solution:
B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies simultaneously due to alternative RNA splicing. This process allows the same gene for the heavy chain to be spliced in different ways to produce both IgM and IgD isotypes.

 

  • The IgM and IgD are both produced from the same heavy chain gene but are differentiated through this splicing mechanism.
  • During this process, the RNA transcript for the heavy chain is spliced in two different ways, one to produce IgM and the other to produce IgD.
  • Both these antibodies have the same antigen-binding specificity but differ in their constant regions, which define their isotypes.

 

Somatic hypermutation (Option A) occurs after antigen exposure and increases antibody affinity, but it does not affect the simultaneous expression of IgM and IgD.

 

Affinity maturation (Option C) is a process that occurs during the immune response to improve the affinity of antibodies, not to generate multiple antibody classes at the same time.

 

Allelic exclusion (Option D) ensures that only one allele of the immunoglobulin gene is expressed in a B cell at any given time, which helps in maintaining clonal specificity, but it does not explain the co-expression of IgM and IgD.

questions.text: Which of the following shows maximum amplitude on thromboelastography?
questions.solution:
• Thromboelastography (TEG) measures the viscoelastic properties of blood as it clots.
  • The maximum amplitude (MA) on TEG reflects the strength of the clot, which is primarily determined by the number and function of platelets and the fibrinogen concentration.
  • The platelets contribute most significantly to the clot's strength and the MA value.

 

Thromboelastography (TEG) is a diagnostic tool used to evaluate coagulation profiles and guide management with transfusions and hemostatic therapies. Studies show that TEG can reduce blood product usage by up to 40%, decrease postoperative length of stay, and lower the risk of reoperation.

 

TEG measures the viscoelastic properties of blood as clotting occurs. The resulting data is plotted on a graph with time on the x-axis and amplitude (clot strength) on the y-axis. Key values include:

  • Reaction time (R): The time it takes for the clot strength to reach an amplitude of 2 mm.
  • Kinetics (K): The time from R to when the amplitude reaches 20 mm.
  • α-angle: The angle formed by a line from R to the point where K intersects with the 20 mm amplitude mark.
  • Maximum amplitude (MA): The highest amplitude reached.
  • Lysis at 30 minutes (Ly30): The per cent decrease in amplitude 30 minutes after MA (or 60 minutes in some cases).

Inference:

  • A prolonged R time may indicate coagulation factor deficiency or anticoagulation.
  • A decreased α-angle can result from hypofibrinogenemia
  • Low MA can be due to thrombocytopenia or platelet dysfunction.
  • Increased Ly30 indicates hyperfibrinolysis, often seen in severe trauma or with thrombolytic therapy.

Based on the TEG findings, targeted blood products can be administered to normalize coagulation. For example:

  • Fresh frozen plasma for prolonged R time
  • Cryoprecipitate for decreased α-angle
  • Platelets for decreased MA
  • Tranexamic acid or aminocaproic acid for increased Ly30.

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever, night sweats, and weight loss for 2 months. On examination, non-tender rubbery nodes are palpable in the supraclavicular and inguinal regions on both sides. A peripheral smear shows the presence of binucleated cells. Which of the following markers will be seen in this condition?


	CD15
	CD30
	CD19
	CD3
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation of fever, night sweats, weight loss, and non-tender rubbery lymph nodes suggests Hodgkin lymphoma, supported by the presence of binucleated Reed-Sternberg cells in the peripheral smear.
  • CD15 and CD30 are specific markers for Reed-Sternberg cells in Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • CD19 and CD3 are typically markers for B cells and T cells, respectively, and are not characteristic of Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • Hodgkin lymphoma typically spreads in an orderly, contiguous manner from one lymph node group to the next adjacent group without skipping areas.

 

Feature

Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL)

Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL)

Age of presentation

Bimodal distribution peaks in young adults (15-35 years) and older adults (over 55).

It is more common in older adults but can occur at any age.

Localisation

More often localised to a single axial group of nodes (cervical, mediastinal, para-aortic)

More frequent involvement of multiple peripheral nodes.

Pattern of Spread

Orderly spread by contiguity.

Non Contiguous spread

Involvement of Mesenteric Nodes and Waldeyer Ring

Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring are rarely involved.

Waldeyer ring and mesenteric nodes are commonly involved.

Extranodal Presentation

Extranodal presentation is rare.

Extranodal presentation is common.

 

WHO Classification of Hodgkin lymphoma:

1. Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma (CHL)

  • Nodular Sclerosis Hodgkin Lymphoma
  • Mixed Cellularity Hodgkin Lymphoma
  • Lymphocyte-Rich Hodgkin Lymphoma
  • Lymphocyte-Depleted Hodgkin Lymphoma

2. Non-classical lymphoma: Nodular Lymphocyte-Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (NLPHL)

  • (CD20, CD45, and BCL-6 are expressed in Non-classical Nodular Lymphocyte-Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma.

questions.text: Senile atrophy occurs due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Chronic ischemia from progressive arterial occlusion leads to tissue atrophy. In older adults, reduced cerebral blood flow due to atherosclerosis causes senile atrophy of the brain.

 

Loss of innervation (denervation atrophy) (Option A): Skeletal muscle metabolism and function rely on nerve supply. Damage to the nerves results in atrophy of the muscle fibres they innervate.

Inadequate nutrition (Option B): Severe protein-calorie malnutrition, such as marasmus, causes the breakdown of skeletal muscle proteins for energy after fat stores are depleted, leading to muscle wasting (cachexia). This is common in chronic inflammatory diseases and cancer. In cachectic states, excessive TNF production contributes to appetite suppression and lipid depletion, further exacerbating muscle atrophy.

Decreased workload (disuse atrophy) (Option C): Immobilization of bones, such as through a plaster cast or prolonged bed rest, leads to rapid muscle atrophy. Initially, the decrease in cell size is reversible upon resumption of activity. However, with prolonged disuse, muscle fibres shrink in size and number (due to apoptosis), and muscle atrophy may be accompanied by increased bone resorption, resulting in disuse osteoporosis.
