questions.solution:
Cytokine

Effector Cell

IL-4

B cells

IL-5

Eosinophils

IL-9

Mast cells

IL-13

Dendritic cells

 

Interleukins & functions:

Interleukin (IL)

Function

IL-1

Promotes fever and inflammation and activates T cells and macrophages.

IL-2

Stimulates growth and activation of T cells, critical for adaptive immunity.

IL-3

Supports growth and differentiation of hematopoietic cells (blood cell precursors).

IL-4

Stimulates B cell differentiation and promotes IgE production and Th2 response.

IL-5

Stimulates eosinophil differentiation and activation.

IL-6

Induces fever and acute-phase reactant production and supports B cell differentiation.

IL-7

Essential for T and B cell development and survival.

IL-8 (CXCL8)

Attracts neutrophils to sites of infection (chemotaxis).

IL-9

Promotes mast cell growth and regulates Th2 responses.

IL-10

Anti-inflammatory; inhibits Th1 responses and macrophage activity.

IL-12

Stimulates Th1 cell differentiation and enhances cytotoxic activity of T and NK cells.

IL-13

Modulates immune responses and activates macrophages.

IL-17

Promotes inflammation and recruitment of neutrophils, which are involved in autoimmunity.

IL-21

Stimulates B cell differentiation, plasma cell generation, and Th17 response.

IL-22

Induces antimicrobial peptide production and supports tissue repair.

IL-23

Promotes Th17 differentiation and inflammatory responses.

questions.text:
A patient is diagnosed with B-cell leukaemia. Which of the following are poor prognostic factors?


	Hyperdiploidy
	Age <1 year
	t(9:22)
	t(4:11)
questions.solution:
Hyperdiploidy is generally associated with a better prognosis in B-cell leukaemia, particularly in acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL)

 

Prognostic factors in ALL:

Favorable Prognostic factors

Unfavorable prognostic factors

  • Age: 1-10 years
  • Leucocyte count < 50000/µl
  • Hyperploidy
  • t (12:21)
  • L1 ALL
  • Response to treatment
  • Early Pre B-cell ALL
  • Female
  • Extreme age group: <1 year or >10 years
  • Hypoploidy
  • t(9:22) and t(4:11)
  • L2 and L3 ALL and mature B cell ALL
  • Total leukocyte count >50,000/cubic.mm
  • Black males
  • Organomegaly
  • CNS Leukemia
  • Absence of CD10
  • Remission> 14 days

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. identify the cause
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option B)

Explanation

Staphylococcus aureus does not show nodular involvement, it causes Botryomycosis (or bacterial pseudomycosis or pyoderma vegetans) given in image which is a rare chronic bacterial granulomatous disease.

  • It usually involves the skin and rarely viscera. The most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Disease caused by staphylococcus

Key features

Primary infection

Furuncle

Superficial skin infection develops in hair follicles, sebaceous gland, or sweat gland.

Carbuncle

Development of one or more abscesses in adjacent subcutaneous tissues due to the spread of infection from a furuncle.

Impetigo

The exfoliative toxin produced causes bullous impetigo, characterized by blisters.

Non-bullous impetigo is caused by streptococcus.

Acute osteomyelitis

Bacterial growth usually concentrates in a terminal blood artery of the metaphysis of a long bone, resulting in bone necrosis and persistent suppuration.

Necrotizing pneumonia
  • Caused by strains producing the PVL leukocidin.
  • Localized, destructive abscesses

Endocarditis
  • In drug addicts
  • Due to bacteremia

Toxins mediated

Scalded skin syndrome

Erythema and intraepidermal desquamation in neonates caused by exfoliative toxin

Toxic shock syndrome
  • TSST-1 (Toxic Shock Syndrome Toxin)
  • Early findings: Fever, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain
  • Later: Shock, renal, and hepatic injury, MODS
  • Tampon-associated

Staphylococcal food poisoning
  • Vomiting is prominent without fever.
  • Ingestion of enterotoxin-contaminated food causing acute vomiting and diarrhea within 1 to 5 hours of ingestion

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option B)

Explanation

Northern blotting is a technique used to detect RNA sequences. It involves the separation of RNA samples by gel electrophoresis, transfer to a membrane, and hybridization with a labeled probe specific to the RNA of interest.

 

Types

Target

Features

Southern blotting

(Option A ruled out)

DNA sequences

It involves separating DNA fragments by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using labelled probes to identify specific sequences

Northern blotting

RNA sequences

(Option B)

The process is similar to DNA blotting but focuses on RNA. (Option D ruled out)

Western blotting

(Option C ruled out)

Proteins

This technique specifically detects and analyses proteins in a complex mixture. It involves separating proteins by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using specific antibodies to detect the proteins.

Eastern blotting

Post-translational modifications

It refers to specialised Western blotting techniques that detect specific post-translational modifications of proteins, such as phosphorylation or glycosylation.

Southwestern blotting

DNA-binding proteins

Combines Southern and Western blotting elements to identify proteins that bind to specific DNA sequences.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that arises from the marked part.
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Abducens nerve

 

Explanation:

The abducens nerve (CN VI) arises from the pontomedullary junction, specifically from the ventral surface of the brainstem, near the midline.

It travels forward to innervate the lateral rectus muscle, which controls abduction of the eye (lateral movement).

 

Attachment of the nerves to the brain:

  • 1, 2 - Forebrain
  • 3- Arises from ventral midbrain
  • 4- Dorsal midbrain (cannot see its origin in the Anterior view of the brainstem)
  • 5- Lateral pons
  • 6, 7, 8- Ponto medullary junction (from medial to lateral respectively)
  • 9, 10, 11- Lateral to olives (from superior to inferior respectively)
  • 12- Between pyramid and olives

 

Oculomotor nerve (option A): The oculomotor nerve (CN III) arises from the midbrain (interpeduncular fossa), not the pontomedullary junction.

 

Glossopharyngeal nerve (option B): The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) emerges from the medulla, specifically the postolivary sulcus, above the vagus nerve, not from the pontomedullary junction.

 

Facial nerve (option D): The facial nerve (CN VII) also arises from the pontomedullary junction, but it is located laterally, near the cerebellopontine angle. The abducens nerve is more medial, while the facial nerve is lateral to it.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with swelling in the upper diaphyseal part of the tibia. X-ray of the swelling showed a periosteal reaction. A histopathological image of the biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry was positive for synaptophysin and MIC2. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer- (Option B)

Explanation

The clinical scenario, along with the image showing small, round, uniform cells and positive immunohistochemistry for synaptophysin and MIC2 (CD99) in the diaphysis of long bones like the tibia, is characteristic of Ewing sarcoma.

 

Ewing’s sarcoma:

  • It is a malignant bone tumour characterized by primitive round cells without obvious differentiation.
  • Approximately 80% of patients are younger than 20 years of age.
  • Males are affected slightly more often than Females.
  • It usually arises in the diaphysis of long tubular bones, especially the femur and in the flat bones of the pelvis, and presents as a painful, enlarging mass.
  • The most common mutation (>90% of the cases) is t(11;22)(q24;q12).
  • Morphology:
    • The tumour is soft, tan-white, and frequently contains areas of haemorrhage and necrosis.
    • It comprises sheets of uniform, small, round cells with scant cytoplasm that may be clear due to abundant glycogen.
    • Homer-Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) are rounded cell clusters with a central fibrillary core; their presence indicates neuroectodermal differentiation.
    • Specific markers: CD99+ (MIC2) positive.
    • Fibrous septae may also be present, but there is little stroma.
    • Geographic necrosis may be prominent.
  • Chemotherapy-induced necrosis is a positive prognostic indicator.

 

Osteosarcoma (Option A) is a type of bone cancer originating from cells that produce new bone tissue. It often presents with pain and swelling in the affected bone, and X-rays may show a characteristic "sunburst" or "spiculated" appearance. Histologically, osteosarcoma is characterized by the production of osteoid, a bone-like substance formed by the tumour cells.

Metastatic Neuroblastoma (Option C) is a cancer that develops from immature nerve cells and most commonly occurs in young children. It can originate in areas like the adrenal glands or nerve tissues in the neck, chest, or abdomen. While it may metastasize to the bone and cause lytic lesions, it is not typically associated with a periosteal reaction or positive immunohistochemistry for synaptophysin and MIC2.

Osteoclastoma (Option D), also known as a giant cell tumour of bone, is a benign tumour that mainly affects young adults. It is characterized by multinucleated giant cells and osteoclast-like cells. X-rays usually show a lytic lesion with a "soap bubble" appearance. However, it is not typically associated with a periosteal reaction or positive immunohistochemical findings for synaptophysin and MIC2.

questions.text: Which foramen in the skull is created by the union of three bones?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Foramen lacerum

Explanation:

The foramen lacerum is formed by the union of three bones:

  1. Sphenoid bone (anteriorly)
  2. Temporal bone (petrous part) (laterally)
  3. Occipital bone (posteriorly)

It is located at the base of the skull and is filled with fibrocartilage in vivo, meaning no major structures pass through it directly. The internal carotid artery passes over the foramen lacerum but does not pass through it.



 

Foramen of Middle Cranial Fossa

Structures Passing through

Foramen Rotundum

Maxillary Nerve

Foramen Ovale
  • Mandibular nerve
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary vein
  • Occasionally, the Anterior trunk of the middle meningeal vein

Foramen Spinosum
  • Middle meningeal artery and vein,
  • Emissary vein
  • Nervus spinosus(Meningeal branch of mandibular nerve)

Foramen Lacerum

A triangular opening at the base of the skull, but in living individuals, it is filled with cartilage, and no major structures pass through it.

  • Foramen lacerum contributed by 3 bones-temporal, occipital and sphenoid
  • The internal carotid artery and nerve plexus traverse its superior end;
  • The nerve to the pterygoid canal passes through its anterior wall.
  • The meningeal branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery and an emissary vein pass through it.

 

Foramen magnum (option B): It is entirely within the occipital bone and does not involve three bones. It allows passage of the medulla oblongata, vertebral arteries, and spinal accessory nerve (CN XI).

 

Foramen rotundum (option C): This is part of the sphenoid bone only. It transmits the maxillary nerve (V2) of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Foramen jugulare (option D): Formed by the temporal and occipital bones, but not three bones. It allows passage of the internal jugular vein, glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), vagus nerve (CN X), and accessory nerve (CN XI).
